PART II - CODE OF ORDINANCES

div.head: Chapter 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS
div.p: Sec. 1-1. - Code designated and cited. The ordinances embraced in the following chapters and sections shall constitute and be designated the "Code of Ordinances, City of Moultrie, Georgia," and may be so cited. (Code 1967, § 1-1) Sec. 1-2. - Definitions and rules of construction. In the construction of this Code and of all ordinances, the following rules shall be observed, unless such construction would be inconsistent with the manifest intent of the mayor and council: City. The term "the city" or "this city" shall be construed as if the words "of Moultrie" followed it. City manager. Whenever the term "manager" or "city manager" is used, it shall mean the city manager of the City of Moultrie. Computation of time. Whenever a notice is required to be given or an act to be done a certain length of time before any proceeding shall be had, the day on which such notice is given or such act is done shall be counted in computing the time, but the day on which such proceeding is to be had shall not be counted. Councilmember. The term "councilmember" shall mean any person elected to that office and shall include those persons who hold other offices who by the terms of the Charter are ex officio. County. The term "the county" or "this county" shall mean the County of Colquitt, Georgia. Delegation of authority. Whenever a provision appears requiring the head of a department of the city to do some act or make certain inspections, it is to be construed to authorize the head of the department to designate, delegate and authorize subordinates to perform the required act or make the required inspection unless the terms of the provision or section designate otherwise. Gender. A word importing the masculine gender only shall extend and be applied to females and to firms, partnerships and corporations as well as to males. Interpretation. In the interpretation and application of any provision of this Code, it shall be held to be the minimum requirements adopted for the promotion of the public health, safety, comfort, convenience and general welfare. Where any provision of this Code imposes greater restrictions upon the subject matter than the general provision imposed by the Code, the provision imposing the greater restriction or regulation shall be deemed to be controlling. Joint authority. All words giving a joint authority to three or more persons or officers shall be construed as giving such authority to a majority of such persons or officers. Judge. The term "judge," where used in this Code, shall mean the judge of the municipal court, except where otherwise stated. Keeper and proprietor. The terms "keeper" and "proprietor" shall mean and include the persons, firms, associations, corporations, clubs and partnerships, whether acting by themselves or through a servant, agent or employee. Limits, corporation, city. The terms "limits," "corporation" or "city" shall mean the corporate limits of the city, the legal boundary of the City of Moultrie. Mayor. Whenever the term "mayor" is used, it shall mean the mayor of the City of Moultrie. Mayor and council. Whenever the term "mayor and council" is used, it shall be construed to mean the mayor and council of the City of Moultrie. Month. The term "month" shall mean a calendar month. Name of officer. Whenever the name of an officer is given, it shall be construed as though the words "of the City of Moultrie" were added. Nontechnical and technical words. Words and phrases shall be construed according to the common and approved usage of the language, but technical words and phrases and such others as may have acquired a peculiar and appropriate meaning in law shall be construed and understood according to such meaning. Number. A word importing the singular number only may extend and be applied to several persons and things as well as to one person and thing. Oath. The term "oath" shall be construed to include an affirmation in all cases in which, by law, an affirmation may be substituted for an oath, and in such cases the terms "swear" and "sworn" shall be equivalent to the terms "affirm" and "affirmed." Or, and. The term "or" may be read "and," and the term "and" may be read "or," if the sense requires it. Owner. The term "owner," applied to a building or land, shall include any part owner, joint owner, tenant in common, tenant in partnership, joint tenant, or tenant by the entirety, of the whole or of a part of such building or land. Person. The term "person" shall extend and be applied to associations, clubs, societies, firms, partnerships and bodies politic and corporate as well as to individuals. Personal property. The term "personal property" shall include every species of property except real property, as described in this section. Preceding, following. The terms "preceding" and "following" shall mean next before and next after, respectively. Premises. Whenever the term "premises" is used, it shall mean a place or places. Property. The term "property" shall include real and personal property. Public place. The term "public place" shall mean any park, cemetery, schoolyard or open space adjacent thereto, or any area available and/or accessible to the public. Real property. The term "real property" shall include lands, tenements and hereditaments. Residence. The term "residence" shall be construed to mean the place adopted by a person as his place of habitation and to which, whenever he is absent, he has the intention of returning. When a person eats at one place and sleeps at another, the place where such person sleeps shall be deemed his residence. Seal. The term "seal" shall mean the city seal or the seal of the corporation. Signature or subscription. The term "signature" or "subscription" of a person shall include a mark when the person cannot write. State. The term "the state" shall be construed to mean the State of Georgia. Street. The term "street" shall be construed to embrace streets, avenues, boulevards, roads, alleys, lanes, viaducts and all other public highways in the city. Tenant, occupant. The term "tenant" or "occupant," applied to a building or land, shall include any person holding a written or oral lease or who occupies the whole or a part of such building or land, either alone or with others. Time. Words used in the past or present tense include the future as well as the past and present. Week. The term "week" shall be construed to mean seven days. Written or in writing. The term "written" or "in writing" shall be construed to include any representation of words, letters or figures, whether by printing or otherwise. Year. The term "year" shall mean a calendar year. (Code 1967, § 1-2; Ord. No. 2014-148, § 1, 8-5-2014) State Law reference— Construction of statutes, definitions, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-1 et seq. Sec. 1-3. - Catchlines of sections. The catchlines of the several sections of this Code printed in boldface type are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the contents of the section and shall not be deemed or taken to be titles of such sections nor as any part of the section nor, unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when any of such sections, including the catchlines, are amended or reenacted. (Code 1967, § 1-3) Sec. 1-4. - Effect of repeal of ordinances. (a) The repeal of an ordinance shall not revive any ordinances in force before or at the time the ordinance repealed took effect. (b) The repeal of an ordinance shall not affect any punishment or penalty incurred before the repeal took effect, nor any suit, prosecution or proceeding pending at the time of the repeal, for an offense committed or cause of action arising under the ordinance repealed. (Code 1967, § 1-4) Sec. 1-5. - Severability of parts of Code. It is hereby declared to be the intention of the mayor and council that the sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses and phrases of this Code are severable, and if any phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section of this Code shall be declared unconstitutional by the valid judgment or decree of any court of competent jurisdiction, such unconstitutionality shall not affect any of the remaining phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs and sections of this Code, since the same would have been enacted by the mayor and council without the incorporation in this Code of any such unconstitutional phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section. (Code 1967, § 1-5) Sec. 1-6. - Official city time. Time referred to in ordinances, resolutions, rules and regulations of the city shall mean Eastern Standard Time or Eastern Daylight Time, whichever is applicable, and acts and deeds of commission prohibited after a named hour or before a named hour shall be held and understood to mean such hour by Eastern Standard Time or Eastern Daylight Time, whichever is applicable, and wherever any reference to time is made in any of the ordinances and regulations of the city, such rules, ordinances and regulations are hereby amended to provide that the time provided therein shall be and hereby made Eastern Standard Time or Eastern Daylight Time, whichever is applicable, in accordance with the laws of this state. (Code 1967, § 1-6; Ord. No. 533, § 1, 10-20-1987) Sec. 1-7. - Amendments to Code; effect of new ordinances; amendatory language. (a) All ordinances passed subsequent to this Code which amend, repeal or in any way affect this Code may be numbered in accordance with the numbering system of this Code and printed for inclusion herein. In the case of repealed chapters, sections and subsections or any part thereof, by subsequent ordinances, such repealed portions may be excluded from the Code by omission from reprinted pages affected thereby. The subsequent ordinances as numbered and printed or omitted, in the case of repeal, shall be prima facie evidence of such subsequent ordinances until such time that this Code and subsequent ordinances numbered or omitted are readopted as a new Code by the mayor and council. (b) Amendments to any of the provisions of this Code may be made by amending such provisions by specific reference to the section number of this Code in the following language: "That section ____________ of the Code of Ordinances, City of Moultrie, Georgia, is hereby amended to read as follows: …." The new provisions may then be set out in full as desired. (c) In the event a new section not heretofore existing in the Code is to be added, the following language may be used: "That the Code of Ordinances, City of Moultrie, Georgia, is hereby amended by adding a section (or article or chapter) to be numbered ____________ , which said section reads as follows: …." The new section may then be set out in full as desired. (d) All sections, articles, chapters or provisions desired to be repealed should be specifically repealed by section, article or chapter number, as the case may be. (Code 1967, § 1-7) Sec. 1-8. - Altering Code. It shall be unlawful for any person in the city to change or amend, by additions or deletions, any part or portion of this Code or to insert or delete pages or portions thereof or to alter or tamper with such Code in any manner whatsoever except by ordinance or resolution or other official act of the mayor and council, which will cause the law of the City of Moultrie, Georgia, to be misrepresented thereby. Any person violating this section shall be punished as provided in section 1-9. (Code 1967, § 1-8) Sec. 1-9. - General penalty; continuing violations. (a) Whenever in this Code or in any ordinance of the city any act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or an offense or whenever in such Code or ordinance the doing of any act is required or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful, where no specific penalty is provided therefor, the violation of such provision of this Code or any such ordinance shall be punished by a fine not to exceed $1,000.00 or imprisonment in the city jail for not more than 100 days, or work in the work gang on the public streets or on such public works as the authorities may employ the work gang for not more than 100 days, or by any one or more of these punishments, subject to all limitations contained in the Charter of the city. Each day any violation of this Code or of any ordinance shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. (b) In addition to the penalties provided in subsection (a) of this section, any condition caused or permitted to exist in violation of any of the provisions of this Code or any ordinance shall be deemed a public nuisance, and may be abated by the city as provided by law, and each day that such condition continues shall be regarded as a new and separate offense. (Code 1967, § 1-9; Ord. No. 612, § 1, 5-7-1991) Sec. 1-10. - Judgments and sentences to run consecutively. All judgments and sentences imposed or ordered by the judge shall run consecutively unless otherwise specifically expressly provided by the judge in such judgment or sentence. (Code 1967, § 1-10; Ord. No. 2014-148, § 2, 8-5-2014) Sec. 1-11. - Extraterritorial jurisdiction over property devoted to public purposes. div.head: Chapter 2 - ADMINISTRATION[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Courts, ch. 34; elections, ch. 38; administration of flood damage prevention regulations, § 54-41 et seq.; law enforcement, ch. 66; libraries, ch. 70; planning, ch. 86; taxation, ch. 102; utilities, ch. 110.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 2-1. - Fiscal year. The fiscal year of the city is hereby fixed from October 1 through September 30 of each year. (Code 1935, § 450; Code 1967, § 2-1) Sec. 2-2. - Radioactive fallout protection in city buildings. (a) Incorporation in construction. Every officer, board, department, commission or agency of the city charged with the duty of preparing specifications, or awarding or entering into contracts for the design, erection or construction of buildings or other structures, including additions to existing structures, for the city shall incorporate or cause to be incorporated in such buildings or other structures protection from radioactive fallout for at least its normal anticipated occupancy which shall meet or exceed the minimum space and protection criteria recommended by the Defense Civil Preparedness Agency, United States Department of Defense, unless exempted from such shelter requirements in accordance with subsection (b) of this section. (b) Exemptions. The city council may exempt buildings or other structures from the requirements of subsection (a) of this section where it finds that the addition of fallout protection will create, in the building or other structure, an additional net cost in excess of three percent in the construction of such building or that other factors make it unnecessary or impracticable to incorporate fallout protection in the design or construction of such building or structure. (c) Purpose of requirements. It shall be the policy of the city council that fallout shelter protection shall be incorporated into all city buildings or structures to the fullest extent practicable in order to provide protection against the effect of radioactive fallout for the greatest possible number of people in the event of nuclear attack upon the United States or an accidental nuclear explosion. (Code 1967, § 2-19; Ord. No. 134, §§ 1—3, 12-4-1973) Secs. 2-3—2-30. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - COUNCIL[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- Cross reference— Elections, ch. 38.
Sec. 2-31. - Organization meeting; order of business. At the first meeting after the election and organization of a new council, the following order of business shall be observed: (1) Fixing the mayor's salary for his term. (2) Fixing the salaries of the councilmembers for their term. (3) Election and fixing the salary of the city attorney for his term. (4) Election and fixing the salary of the city manager for his term. (5) Election and fixing the salary of the city recorder for his term. (6) Election of members of the board of trustees of the public library. (7) Election of the board of tax assessors. (8) Election of members of the city planning commission. (9) Election of the board of zoning appeals. (10) Naming the standing committees. (11) Election of mayor pro tem. (Code 1935, § 358(a); Code 1967, § 2-2) Charter reference— Authority to determine own rules and order of business, § 8(a); council to choose at first meeting: city manager, city attorney, city recorder, board of trustees of public library, board of tax assessors, city planning commission, board of zoning appeals, § 18; mayor pro tem, § 13; council meetings, § 20. Sec. 2-32. - Permanent committees. (a) At the first meeting in each year after the election and qualification of the new council, the mayor shall appoint the following committees: (1) Alcoholic beverage. (2) Finance, contracts. (3) Insurance. (4) Retirement and employee benefits. (5) Property, planning and growth. (6) Spence Field. (7) Traffic, paving and cemetery. (8) Intergovernmental. (9) Appointments. (b) Each committee shall be composed of at least three members of council, the exact number above three to be in the discretion of the mayor, except that the alcoholic beverage committee shall be composed of the full council. (Code 1935, § 350; Code 1967, § 2-3; Ord. No. 605, § 1, 11-6-1990; Ord. No. 629, § 1, 8-18-1992; Ord. No. 663, § 1, 2-1-1994; Ord. No. 687, § 1, 1-17-1995; Ord. No. 713, § 1, 1-16-1996; Ord. No. 774, § 1, 1-20-1998; Ord. No. 829, § 1, 1-18-2000; Ord. No. 2015-167, § 1, 4-21-2015) Sec. 2-33. - Duties of councilmembers. It shall be the duty of each councilmember to act on committees under appointment of the chairman, to attend to such executive duties as the council in session shall require, and to perform any and all other duties which shall be lawfully required by the mayor and council, or either of them. (Code 1935, § 351; Code 1967, § 2-4) Sec. 2-34. - Order of business. At all regular meetings the following order of business shall be observed: (1) Reading and approving minutes of previous meetings. (2) Reports of the standing committees. (3) Report of special committees. (4) Report of the treasurer. (5) Unfinished business. (6) Petitions and communications read and acted upon. (7) Resolutions, orders and ordinances. (8) Other business. (Code 1935, § 358(b); Code 1967, § 2-5) Sec. 2-35. - Parliamentary procedure. The proceedings of the council shall be governed by the general rules of parliamentary law and practice as set out in Robert's Rules of Order, Newly Revised, so far as applicable, and not in conflict with the special rules of the council. (Code 1935, § 366; Code 1967, § 2-6) Sec. 2-36. - Voting. All questions shall be put by the chairman to a viva voce vote, and an affirmative vote of three councilmembers shall determine all questions except as otherwise specifically provided. However, any member may require the yeas and nays upon any question and a record thereof to be inscribed in the minutes. (Code 1935, § 360; Code 1967, § 2-7) Charter reference— Quorum; vote required, § 21. Sec. 2-37. - Regular and special meetings. The time and place of regular meetings of the city council shall be on the first and third Tuesday evenings in each month, in the council chambers, and at such hour as the mayor and councilmembers shall from time to time direct. Special meetings of the council shall be called at any time, by the mayor or four of the councilmembers, for the transaction of such business as shall require immediate action. It shall be the duty of the mayor or mayor pro tem to give each and every councilmember then in the city notice of such special meeting. (Code 1935, § 357; Code 1967, § 2-8) Sec. 2-38. - Approval of minutes of previous meeting. When the minutes of any meetings shall have been approved by the council, the minutes shall be signed by the mayor or chairman, countersigned by the clerk, and then recorded in the minute book. (Code 1935, § 359; Code 1967, § 2-9) Sec. 2-39. - Reconsideration of subjects in minutes of previous meeting. Before the minutes of any preceding meeting are signed by the mayor and clerk, any councilmember may move to reconsider any question, motion, order or resolution or other subject, in such minutes, and if such motion to reconsider shall receive a majority of the votes present, the subject matter of reconsideration shall be the immediate order of business. (Code 1935, § 364; Code 1967, § 2-10) Sec. 2-40. - Referral of matters to committees. The council may refer any matter to the appropriate committee, which committee shall report thereon before any action is had or taken. (Code 1935, § 363; Code 1967, § 2-11) Sec. 2-41. - Petitions, other communications. The council may require petitions or other communications to be in writing, signed by the parties petitioning. (Code 1935, § 363; Code 1967, § 2-12) Secs. 2-42—2-70. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES[3] Footnotes: --- (3) --- State Law reference— Applicability of workers' compensation law, O.C.G.A. § 34-9-3.
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 2-71. - Oath to be taken. All officers, whether elective or appointive, shall take an oath for the faithful performance of their duties, except in cases where a particular oath is prescribed by the Charter or this Code. (Code 1935, § 369(a); Code 1967, § 19-3) Sec. 2-72. - Bond required. (a) The bond required of all officers and other persons, whomsoever, shall be made payable to the city, except in cases differently prescribed by the Charter or this Code, and the bonds shall be attested by the mayor and council or some officer authorized by law to attest deeds. (b) The condition of the official bonds shall be for the faithful and proper performance of the duties of the officer (naming the office) and such other condition as is prescribed by the Charter or this Code. (c) The obligation of official bonds given by officers of the city shall be binding jointly and severally on the principal and sureties thereto for: (1) Any breach of a condition while the officer continues in the office or discharge of the duties thereof. (2) The discharge of the duties required of such officer by the laws or ordinances passed subsequently to the execution of such bond. (3) The use and benefit of each and every person who may be injured by any wrongful act committed under color of such office or by failure to perform or by negligent performance of the duties imposed by the laws and ordinances. (d) Such bonds shall not be discharged by a single recovery, but recoveries by different persons or by the same person for different injuries may be had until the full penalty shall have been paid by the principal and his sureties. (e) Official and other bonds given to the city for any purpose shall not be vitiated by reason of any nonconformity to the laws and ordinances, but shall be binding as if drawn and executed as prescribed. (f) Sureties on bonds may be relieved, in the discretion of the council, when such officer shall give security. But the sureties so relieved shall be liable for any damages arising or caused prior to such release. Such officer failing to give other security shall be discharged. (Code 1935, § 369(b)—(f); Code 1967, § 19-4) Sec. 2-73. - Mayor's emergency police powers. In addition to any and all powers enumerated in the city Charter and Code, the mayor, as the chief executive of the city, shall have the further emergency powers as follows: (1) The mayor shall have the right to declare an emergency when, in his opinion, one or more of the following conditions exist: a. There is extreme likelihood of danger of destruction of life or property due to unusual conditions. b. Unusual or extreme weather conditions, making use of city streets or areas difficult or impossible. c. Civil unrest, commotion or uprising is imminent or exists. d. There is a stoppage or loss of electrical power affecting a major portion of the city. (2) After declaration of such emergency the mayor, as chief executive, shall have the right to exercise the power to: a. Use employees of the city to assist in the safety and preservation of life, limb and property of citizenry of the city. b. Close streets and sidewalks and delineate areas within the city wherein an emergency exists. c. Impose emergency curfew regulations. d. Close business establishments within the affected area. e. Close any and all municipally owned buildings and other facilities to the use of the general public. f. Do any and all acts necessary and incidental to the preservation of life, limb and property of the citizenry of the city. (3) No emergency as set forth in this section may be effective for more than 72 hours after the declaration of an emergency by the mayor. However, upon declaration of a second or further emergency to exist, the emergency powers as set forth in this section may be exercised during such further emergency period, but never for more than 72 hours in one declared emergency period. (4) No emergency period shall extend beyond the next regular, special or called meeting of the mayor and council. (5) The declaration of an emergency as to a portion of the city shall specify with exactness the area in which the emergency is declared to exist. (Code 1967, § 2-18; Ord. No. 9-1969, § 1, 11-7-1969) Sec. 2-74. - Salary, expense allowance for city manager. (a) The salary of the city manager shall be and is hereby fixed at the sum of $65,000.00 per annum to be paid monthly beginning October 1, 1996. (b) In addition to the foregoing salary the city manager shall be paid the sum of $100.00 per month as car expense for the operation of his car for city business. (Code 1967, § 2-13.1; Ord. No. 16-1970, §§ 1, 2, 8-26-1970; Ord. No. 18-1971, § 1, 12-21-1971; Ord. No. 22-1972, § 1, 11-21-1972; Ord. No. 126, § 1, 11-6-1973; Ord. No. 172, § 1, 11-5-1974; Ord. No. 224, § 1, 7-20-1976; Ord. No. 259, § 1, 10-11-1977; Ord. No. 288, § 1, 12-19-1978; Ord. No. 305, § 1, 9-18-1979; Ord. No. 333, § 1, 10-21-1980; Ord. No. 358, § 1, 9-15-1981; Ord. No. 652, § 1, 10-5-1993; Ord. No. 677, § 1, 10-4-1994; Ord. No. 707, § 1, 10-3-1995; Ord. No. 729, § 1, 10-8-1996) Sec. 2-75. - Purchasing authority of city manager. The city manager shall be the purchasing agent for the city by whom all the purchases of supplies for departments under his control, as herein provided, and all contracts for printing shall be made, and he shall approve all vouchers for same; provided that all contracts or agreements made by him requiring the expenditures of money to the amount of $500.00 or more shall be approved by the council. In the capacity of purchasing agent he shall conduct all sales of personal property which the council may authorize to be sold, and which have become unnecessary or unfit for the city's use; all such sales shall conform to such regulations as the council may from time to time prescribe. In any case of purchase or sale, if an amount in excess of $500.00 is involved, opportunity for competition shall be given. (Code 1967, § 19-1) Sec. 2-76. - Duties of city clerk. It shall be the duty of the clerk to: (1) Attend every meeting of the council and keep a complete record of all the proceedings in the minute book. (2) Issue all summons, writs, processes, and other papers which shall lawfully be required of him for the enforcement of the laws and ordinances. (3) Issue all licenses to persons applying for same, when such person shall comply with the requirements thereto, and keep a record of same in a license book, where shall be stated the name of the licensee and his business, the date when the license is issued, the term for which it is granted and the amount of money received therefor. (4) Preserve and keep all records, communications, petitions, ordinances and all original documents of every kind and description, filed alphabetically, so as to be easily and quickly accessible for reference and examination. (5) Transcribe from the minute book to the ordinance book all ordinances which shall be passed upon their third reading by the council and properly index such ordinances when so transcribed. (6) Keep a police docket in which he shall enter the names of all parties charged with offenses against the city laws and ordinances, the character of the offense charged, the date of the trial and the judgment of the person trying the same. (7) Issue warrants for the arrest of offenders against the laws and ordinances when such shall be required. (8) Publish such citation as shall be lawfully required. (9) Receive tax returns, make up the tax digest and collect taxes due the city. (10) Collect all fines and forfeitures, unless the board requires such done by some other officer. (11) Collect all rents for water and lights, and all monies due the city not herein otherwise provided for. (12) Keep a cash book in which shall be entered every item of money collected, from whom, for what purpose, and the date collected, and the cash book shall also show when, to whom, and for what purpose each and every disbursement of such funds is made. (13) Prepare and submit at the first meeting of the board in each month a trial balance, showing all monies received and disbursed by him as per subsections (11) and (12) of this section. (14) Keep an account book in which shall be recorded an itemized statement of all accounts paid by the city and the date when each account is paid. (15) Perform all duties which shall be lawfully required of him. (16) Give such bonds as may be required and approved by the city council. (Code 1935, § 353; Code 1967, § 2-14) Charter reference— Duties of city clerk, § 14. Sec. 2-77. - Treasurer's qualifications, duties. (a) No person shall be eligible to the office of treasurer until he shall have resided in the city continuously for two years, and he shall be required to give such bond as may be required and approved by the city council. (b) The treasurer shall receive such compensation as shall be prescribed by the council at the first meeting after election, which shall not be increased or diminished during the term of his service. (c) The treasurer shall be custodian of all monies belonging to the city, shall deposit such money in one or more solvent banks in the city, and shall receive and pay out only such monies as are prescribed by laws and ordinances. (d) The treasurer shall keep a book, in which shall be kept a cash account showing each and every sum of money received by him, from whom, for what and the date it was received. He shall also enter in the book each and every sum disbursed by him, showing the date, to whom, and for what purpose such payment was made. He shall also keep a separate account of the sinking fund showing the dates and amount of each collection or allotment, and shall also show the date of each particular payment, to whom paid, the number of the bond, and the year in which such bond or the coupon thereof was issued. He also shall keep a separate account of the school fund. (e) He shall appear before each regular session of the council, present a trial balance, showing the condition of the treasury as prescribed in subsection (d) of this section, and shall also present each and all of his books for the inspection of the council. (f) It shall be unlawful for him to pay out any money for any purpose except upon written order of the mayor or chairman of the council, which order shall be countersigned by the clerk, and shall bear the seal of the clerk. (g) At the end of his term of service he shall deliver, on demand, to his successor, all money, books and property in his possession for which he may be liable, taking his successor's receipt therefor, and make a final report to the council at its next regular meeting. (Code 1935, § 354; Code 1967, § 2-15) Charter reference— Duties of treasurer, § 14. Sec. 2-78. - Compensation of city attorney. The city attorney will receive an annual retainer as the council shall determine at the time of election to be paid in monthly installments with the usual deductions for FICA and insurance. The city attorney will keep time for services rendered and will charge such on an hourly rate to be agreed upon at the time of election. When and if these charges exceed the annual retainer, the city attorney will bill the city for these additional services and will be paid therefor. (Code 1935, § 356(d); Code 1967, § 2-13; Ord. No. 532, § 1, 10-20-1987; Ord. No. 797, § 1, 1-19-1999) Charter reference— City attorney; office; duties, § 15. Sec. 2-79. - Officer as surety on appearance bond to municipal court prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any elective officer of the city to be or become surety on any appearance bond returnable to the municipal court. (Ord. of 10-20-1953; Code 1967, § 2-16; Ord. No. 2014-149, § 1, 8-5-2014) It shall be unlawful for any elective officer of the city to be or become surety on any appearance bond returnable to the recorder's court. (Ord. of 10-20-1953; Code 1967, § 2-16) Sec. 2-80. - Eligibility of marshal. No person shall be eligible to the office of the marshal of the city who has not attained the age of 26 years and who is not of good moral character. (Code 1935, § 23(b); Code 1967, § 19-5) Charter reference— Eligibility of marshal, § 17. Sec. 2-81. - Compensation of mayor and city council. Pursuant to the provisions of section 12 of article II of the city charter and the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 36-35-4, the compensation of the mayor and the members of the council is hereby established as follows: (a) Each member of the council shall receive as salary the sum of $495.00 per month and a travel allowance of $100.00 per month; (b) The mayor shall receive a salary of $580.00 per month and a travel allowance of $150.00 per month. (Ord. No. 848, § 1, 8-15-2000) Editor's note— Ord. No. 848, adopted Aug. 15, 2000, did not specifically amend § 12 of the charter nor specifically create § 2-81. Said section was enacted at the discretion of the editor to better fit the format of the code. Sec. 2-82. - Claims against the city. (a) For claims against the city for money damages for injuries to persons or property that are presented to the city pursuant to the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 36-33-5, the city council delegates to the city manager the authority to consider and act upon the claims as set forth in O.C.G.A. § 36-33-5. The act of the city manager in performing such functions shall be considered the act of the city council for purposes of the requirements of O.C.G.A. § 36-33-5. Nothing contained herein shall prohibit the city manager from presenting such claims to the city council for review and comment as he deems appropriate. This provision shall be effective as to all claims presented after the effective date of the ordinance from which this section is derived and to all claims presented before such effective date and as to which no action has been taken as of said effective date. (b) By virtue of this section, all actions taken by the city manager on such claims made before the introduction of the ordinance from which this section is derived are hereby ratified by the city council, and any such previous actions on the part of the city manager shall be deemed to have been the actions of the city council. (Ord. No. 911, § 1, 3-16-2004) Secs. 2-83—2-110. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - SOCIAL SECURITY
Sec. 2-111. - Old-age and survivors insurance to be extended to city employees. It is hereby declared to be the policy and purpose of the city to extend at the earliest date possible under the agreement entered into by the state and the Federal Security Administration, to the employees and officials thereof, and its instrumentalities, not excluded by law or by this division, the benefits of the system of old-age and survivors insurance as authorized by the federal social security act, the state enabling act (O.C.G.A. § 47-18-1 et seq.), and amendments thereto. In pursuance of the policy, and for that purpose, the city shall take such action as may be required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations. (Ord. of 9-2-1958, § 1; Code 1967, § 19-16) Sec. 2-112. - Mayor, city manager authorized to execute agreement. The mayor, or city manager, is hereby authorized and directed to execute all necessary agreements and amendments thereto with the employees' retirement system of the state and officials as provided for in section 2-111 hereof, not to include any elected officials, but to include any employees that are in positions covered by a public retirement system, in the manner by the law provided. (Ord. of 9-2-1958, § 2; Code 1967, § 19-17) Sec. 2-113. - Withholdings authorized, payment to state agency. Withholdings from salaries or wages of employees and officials for the purpose provided for in section 2-111 hereof are hereby authorized to be made in the amounts and at such times as may be required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations, and shall be paid over to the state agency. (Ord. of 9-2-1958, § 3; Code 1967, § 19-18) Sec. 2-114. - City's contribution. There shall be appropriated from the general funds such amounts at such times as may be required by applicable state or federal law or regulations for employer's contributions, administrative expenses, and a guaranty fund to ensure that the state will not incur any debt or loss as a result of the agreement referred to in section 2-112 of this division. Such funds shall be paid over to the employees' retirement system of the state in accordance with regulations established by the agency. (Ord. of 9-2-1958, § 4; Code 1967, § 19-19) Sec. 2-115. - Records and reports. The city shall keep such records and make such reports as may be required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations. (Ord. of 9-2-1958, § 5; Code 1967, § 19-20) Sec. 2-116. - Unauthorized personnel excluded. There is hereby excluded from this division any authority to make any agreement with respect to any position, or any employee or official not authorized to be covered by applicable state or federal laws or regulations. (Ord. of 9-2-1958, § 6; Code 1967, § 19-21) Sec. 2-117. - Agreement releasing social security escrow deposits authorized. The mayor is hereby authorized and directed to execute an agreement amending the original plan and agreement with the employees' retirement system of the state, in substantially the form attached to Ordinance No. 11-1967 as exhibit A, providing for the release of social security escrow deposits. (Ord. No. 11-1967, 11-21-1967; Code 1967, § 19-22) Sec. 2-118. - Rules and regulations pertaining to collections from city employees, payments and reports. The city agrees to abide by the rules and regulations of the employee's retirement system of the state, hereinafter called the "state agency," in regard to collections from city employees and in making reports and payments to the state agency. (Ord. No. 11-1967, 11-21-1967; Code 1967, § 19-23) Sec. 2-119. - Pledge of state grant funds; additional deposits. The city hereby pledges an amount which it would receive in state grant funds as security for assurance that it will make collections from its employees, submit required reports, and remit payments to the state agency as agreed to in its plan of coverage of employees for social security benefits. The city further agrees that if the amount of state grant funds which it is entitled to receive in a calendar year is less than its annual payment to the state agency, as may be determined by the state agency, then the city shall deposit in escrow, when so notified in writing by the state agency and in accordance with its rules and regulations, an amount which, when added to the city's state grant funds, would total an amount sufficient to meet its obligations of reporting and remitting collections to the state agency. (Ord. No. 11-1967, 11-21-1967; Code 1967, § 19-24) Secs. 2-120—2-145. - Reserved. DIVISION 3. - RETIREMENT PLAN[4] Footnotes: --- (4) --- Charter reference— Retirement plan, art. XIII.
Subdivision I. - In General[5]
Footnotes: --- (5) --- Editor's note— Ord. No. 2010-90, §§ 1—14, adopted Dec. 7, 2010, amended Art. III, Div. 3, Subd. I, in its entirety to read as herein set out. former Art. III, Div. 3, Subd. I, §§ 2-146—2-166, pertained to the same subject matter. See the Code Comparative Table for complete derivation.
Sec. 2-146. - Plan amended and restated. The City of Moultrie, Georgia (the "employer") established a retirement plan for employees of the City of Moultrie effective January 1, 1966 (the "plan") and the employer hereby amends and restates the plan effective January 1, 2015 through which will be provided retirement and other benefits to the city's employees through a trust fund established for that purpose. This plan is considered to be in the public interest in attracting and retaining better qualified personnel in the city's service and in providing greater personal security to its employees in their old age. This plan is intended to provide a governmental qualified defined benefit pension plan under Internal Revenue Code Section 401(a) and 414(d). The benefits described in the plan are provided for the exclusive benefit of the participants and their beneficiaries. The plan shall be maintained at city hall. Certain provisions of this plan may be effective as of dates earlier or later than January 1, 2015, and shall be so designated. (Ord. No. 2010-90, § 1, 12-7-2010; Ord. No. 2016-177, § 1, 1-5-2016) Sec. 2-147. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Accrued benefit means the retirement income to which a participant will be entitled at his normal retirement age, based upon the actual number of years of service completed by the participant as of the date of determination and his compensation (if applicable) in those years of service. Actuarial equivalent or actuarial equivalence means, with respect to a benefit calculated under this plan, any benefit that has the same present value on the date the benefit payment commences, using a seven percent interest rate per annum and the unisex mortality table in effect on the date benefits commence, as proscribed by the Commissioner of the Internal Revenue Service for purposes of Code Section 417(e)(3). Effective prior to January 1, 2010, the plan used a seven percent interest rate per annum and a 50 percent and 50 percent blend of the 1983 Group Annuity Table for males and females. Authorized leave of absence means any temporary layoff or any absence authorized by the employer under the employer's standard personnel practices provided that all persons under similar circumstances must be treated alike in the granting of such authorized leaves of absence and provided further that the participant returns within the period of authorized absence. An absence due to service in the Armed Forces of the United States shall be considered an authorized leave of absence to the extent required by federal law. Average monthly compensation means the average of the participant's compensation over the 36 consecutive months within the most recent ten-year period of service which produces the highest such average; provided however if an employee has not been employed continuously in service, his separate periods of service will be aggregated for purposes of this section as if he has been employed in service continuously during such aggregated period. If the employee's aggregated period of service is less than three years as of his date of termination of employment, his average monthly compensation will be determined as his average monthly compensation for his entire period of service. The following rules shall be applied to determine a participant's average monthly compensation: (1) Only compensation earned or deemed to have been earned during a period for which the participant is receiving service or is an eligible employee may be counted towards average monthly compensation. (2) Compensation shall be counted in the year paid, even if earned in a prior year. (3) Only compensation earned or deemed to have been earned before January 1, 2018, may be counted towards average monthly compensation. No compensation earned on or after January 1, 2018, shall be taken into account in determining a participant's accrued benefit under the plan. Beneficiary means any individual(s), trust, estate or other entity or entities designated by the participant in accordance with procedures established by the plan administrator to receive any death benefits under the plan. Any beneficiary designation shall be void if the participant revokes the designation. If a married participant fails to designate a beneficiary, or if the designated non-spouse primary beneficiary fails to survive the participant and the participant has not designated a contingent beneficiary, or if both the designated non-spouse primary beneficiary and contingent beneficiary fail to survive the participant, the beneficiary shall be (a) the participant's eligible spouse, or; (b) if no eligible spouse is alive, the participant's eligible dependent(s), or (c) if no eligible dependents, the participant's estate. If an unmarried participant fails to designate a beneficiary, or if the designated beneficiary fails to survive the participant and the participant has not designated a contingent beneficiary, or if both the designated beneficiary and contingent beneficiary fail to survive the participant, the beneficiary shall be the participant's eligible dependents, if any, and if none, the participant's estate. For the purposes of this section, revocation of prior beneficiary designations will occur when a participant files a new valid designation with the plan administrator. Nothing in this definition of beneficiary shall be interpreted to allow a participant to designate a beneficiary, or to be entitled to a death benefit, that is not otherwise provided under the terms of this plan. Board means the board of trustees of the plan. City means the City of Moultrie, Georgia. Code means the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as amended. A reference to a specific provision of the Code shall include such provision and any applicable Treasury Regulation pertaining thereto. Compensation means the basic salary or wage paid to the employee by the employer, which is subject to withholding for purposes of federal income taxes plus amounts not includible in the gross income of the employee by reason of Code Sections 125, 402(e)(3), 402(h)(1)(B) 403(b), 414(h), 457(h) and effective July 1, 2003, Code section 132(f)(4); provided however, compensation will not include bonuses, overtime pay, expense allowances, or any other irregular or special compensation payments. Except with respect to qualified participants (as defined below), in no event shall the compensation of a participant taken into account under the plan for any plan year exceed (i)$200,000.00 for plan years beginning on or after January 1, 1989, (ii) $150,000.00 for plan years on or after the later of (a) January 1, 1996 or (b) the 90th day after the opening of the first legislative session that begins on or after January 1, 1996, or (iii) for plan years beginning on or after January 1, 2002, the limitations of Code Section 401(a)(17) in effect as of the beginning of the plan year (i.e., $265,000.00 for 2015). For purposes of applying the $150,000.00 limit for the 1996 plan year, if any employee is the spouse or a lineal descendant of an employee (provided the lineal descendant is younger than age 19 by the end of the plan year) who is one of the ten "highly compensated employees" (within the meaning of Code Section 414(q)) paid the greatest amount of earnings (determined without regard to the $150,000.00 limit, as adjusted) during the plan year, the employee shall not be treated as a separate employee. The limitations set forth in the preceding paragraph shall be subject to adjustment annually as provided in Code Section 401(a)(17)(B) and Code Section 415(d); provided, however, that the dollar increase in effect on January 1 of any calendar year, if any, is effective for the plan year. The limit described in the previous paragraphs shall not apply to any qualified participant. A qualified participant is any participant who first became a participant in the plan before January 1, 1996. The plan year limitations in effect as of the beginning of the plan year in which each 12-month period used to determine average monthly compensation begins shall apply to compensation paid during such 12-month period. Disability or disabled means the participant is or would be entitled to disability retirement benefits under the federal Social Security Act. Early retirement age means (1) the date the participant has both attained age 55 and accrued 15 or more years of service; or (2) the date the participant's age plus his number of years of service equals 80 or more. Early retirement date shall mean the date as of which the participant actually commences his retirement income that is the first day of any month after the participant has attained his early retirement age but before his normal retirement age. Effective date means January 1, 2015, the effective date of this amendment and restatement. The plan was originally effective as of January 1, 1966. Eligible dependent means a minor unmarried child (natural or adopted) of the participant or any child (natural or adopted) regardless of age, who because of physical or mental impairment and is dependent on the participant or the eligible spouse for substantially all his maintenance or support. Eligible employee means any full-time employee other than the following: (a) Employees who are regularly scheduled to work less than 35 hours per week or six months per year; (b) Temporary employees; (c) A nonresident alien who receives no earned income from an employer which constitutes income from sources within the United States; (d) A leased employee; (e) An employee classified by the employer as a leased employee, regardless of whether such employee is a leased employee within the meaning of Code Section 414(n)(2); or (f) A person who is initially classified by the employer as an independent contractor or leased employee for purposes of the withholding and payment of employment taxes, even if such person is later determined, whether by the employer or otherwise, to be a common law employee of the employer. (g) Effective January 1, 2018, no employee shall be eligible to participate in the plan if not already actively participating as of December 31, 2017. Eligible spouse means, as of any applicable date, a person who was married to the participant on the earlier of the date of the participant's death or the date payment of the participant's retirement income commenced; provided, however, for purposes of section 2-150 and the pre-retirement survivor annuity, eligible spouse means the person who was married to the participant continuously during the one-year immediately preceding the participant's death. Employee means any person employed by the employer as a common law employee, any person on authorized leave of absence from the employer, and any person who is a leased employee. Employer means the City of Moultrie, Georgia. Employment means the service of an employee with the employer. Entry date means the first day of the calendar month coincident with or next following the completion of six months of full-time employment with the employer. Fiduciary means any party named as a fiduciary in article 10 of the plan. Any party shall be considered a fiduciary of the plan only to the extent of the powers and duties specifically allocated to such party under the plan. Full-time employee means a permanent employee who is regularly scheduled to work at least 35 hours per week. Fund means the money and other properties held and administered by the board of trustee(s). Interest means the interest credited on participant contributions. Interest shall be compounded annually at five percent. Interest shall stop accruing as of the date that this plan is terminated. Late retirement date means, for a participant who continues his employment beyond his normal retirement date, the first day of the month coincident with or immediately following such participant's termination of employment. Leased employee means any person who is described in Code Section 414(n)(2), which defines leased employee to mean any individual who provides services to an employer if: (1) Such services are provided pursuant to an agreement between an employer and any other person; (2) Such person has performed such services for an employer (or for an employer and related persons) on a substantially full-time basis for a period of at least one year; and (3) Such services are performed under the primary direction or control of an employer. Normal form means a monthly retirement income payable as a life annuity which ceases upon the participant's death. Normal retirement age means the later of age 65 or ten years of service. Effective for participants hired on and after February 1, 2014, normal retirement age means the later of age 67 or ten years of service. Normal retirement date means the first day of the month coincident with or next following the participant's normal retirement age. Other rules. A defined term, such as "retirement," will normally govern the definitions of derivatives therefrom, such as "retire," even though such derivatives are not specifically defined and even if they are or are not initially capitalized. Singular and plural nouns and pronouns shall be interchangeable as the factual context may allow or require. The words "hereof," "herein," "hereunder" and other similar compounds of the word "here" shall mean and refer to the entire plan and not to any particular provision or section. Parental leave means an absence from work because of the pregnancy of the employee, the birth of a child of the employee or the placement of a child with the employee in connection with the adoption of that child by the employee, or for purposes of caring for that child for a period beginning immediately following such birth or placement. Participant means a person who is actively an employee who is or becomes eligible to participate in the plan as provided in section 2-148. Participant contribution means the amount that participants contribute to the plan through salary reduction in accordance with section 2-153(b) of the plan. Plan or plan and trust means the retirement plan and trust for the employees of the City of Moultrie. Plan administrator or administrator means the employer or an individual or individuals or a committee designated by the employer for purposes of conducting the day to day activities of the plan. Plan year means the 12-month period from October 1 through September 30th except as follows: (1) For periods prior to January 1, 1986, the plan year was the calendar year. (2) January 1, 1986 through September 30, 1986 was a short plan year. Pre-retirement survivor annuity means as defined in section 2-150. Qualified military leave means the period of an employee's leave of absence for active duty for training and service in the Army, Navy, Air Force, Marines, or Coast Guard of the United States of America (or any Reserve or National Guard components thereof when engaged in active duty training, inactive duty training, or full-time National Guard duty) and the commissioned corps of the United States Public Health Service or any other category of persons designated by the President of the United States in a time of war or emergency, but only if the employee was employed in service of the employer immediately preceding the leave and the employee: (1) Returns to service no later than seven days after the termination of active duty of 30 days or less duration; (2) Applies in writing for service within 14 days after the termination of active duty of 31 to 181 days duration; (3) Applies in writing for service within 90 days after termination of active duty of more than 181 days duration (or such additional period as may be necessitated by hospitalization or convalescence due to illness or injury incurred or aggravated in the performance of military service as may be required by the Uniformed Services Employment and Reemployment Rights Act of 1994); or (4) Receives a discharge that is other than dishonorable. The period of military leave may not exceed five years except for training and involuntary active duty extensions or where required to complete an initial period of obligated military service. Retirement or retirement date means the date on which the participant actually ceases employment for early retirement, normal retirement, or late retirement, whichever is applicable. Retirement income means any amount payable to or on behalf of a participant, beneficiary or eligible spouse in accordance with the provisions of the plan. Service means the measurement of a participant's employment with the employer that is used to determine the amount of his benefits under the plan, vesting and eligibility. Service shall be all years and completed months (but not partial months) during which an individual is an eligible employee under this plan and is receiving compensation from the employer or is on an authorized leave of absence or qualified military leave, subject to the following rules: (a) Service shall not be granted for periods during which the employee is not an eligible employee; (b) Service shall not be granted for any time prior to January 1, 1983; (c) Service shall not be granted for any period during which the eligible employee fails to make required participant contributions; (d) Service shall be granted for the time period between the eligible employee's first date of hire and the eligible employee's entry date; and (e) Partial years of service shall be credited in increments of one-twelfth of a year, with one calendar month equal to one-twelfth of a year. Spouse means the person to whom the participant is legally married under the laws of the State of Georgia, except that, effective as of June 26, 2015, the term "spouse" means the person to whom the participant is legally married. Spouse shall not include domestic partners or other similar relationships that are not denominated as marriage. Termination of employment shall mean the first to occur of the following events: (a) Voluntary resignation from service of the employer; or, (b) Discharge from the service of the employer; or, (c) Death. Notwithstanding the foregoing, an employee who ceases to be actively employed by reason of an authorized leave of absence shall not be considered as having a termination of employment, but nothing herein shall preclude an employee on an authorized leave of absence from having a termination of employment on account of the events described in (a), (b) and (c) above. Treasury regulation means regulations pertaining to certain Code Sections as issued by the Secretary of the Treasury. Trust fund means the trust or any other pool of assets established by the employer to hold assets that will be applied to fund the benefits under the plan. Trustee means the persons appointed by the governing authority to be members of the board that oversees the trust fund. (Ord. No. 2010-90, § 2, 12-7-2010; Ord. No. 2014-142, § 1, 2-4-2014; Ord. No. 2014-162, § 1, 11-18-2014; Ord. No. 2015-168, § 1, 5-19-2015; Ord. No. 2016-177, § 2, 1-5-2016; Ord. No. 2017-183, § 1, 3-7-2017; Ord. No. 2017-190, §§ 1, 2, 10-17-2017) Sec. 2-148. - Participation. (a) Participation. (1) Entry date. An eligible employee shall first become a participant as of the first day of the month coincident with or next following the completion of six month of service with the employer. (2) Participant contributions. An eligible employee must make participant contributions, as defined in section 2-147, to the plan as a condition of plan participation. (3) Cessation of participation. A participant shall cease participation in the plan as of the date on which the employee no longer meets the definition of eligible employee or upon his termination of employment. (4) Parental leave. A participant who is on parental leave shall continue participation in the plan. (5) Other leaves of absence. A participant who is absent from work due to qualified military leave, an authorized absence pursuant to the Family and Medical Leave Act of 1993 and other leaves of absence authorized by the employer shall continue participation in the plan. (b) Participation and rehire. (1) Status as a participant. A participant's participation in the plan shall continue until the participant ceases to have any accrued benefit under this plan. See section 2-149(d)(3) for provisions regarding the disposition of the accrued benefit of a non-vested participant upon a termination of employment. (2) Rehire of employee with less than ten years of service. An eligible employee who was a participant in this plan, had fewer than ten years of service at the time of his termination of employment, received a distribution of his participant contributions plus interest and who is subsequently rehired by the employer, shall be treated as a new employee upon rehire, unless he or she repays to the plan all amounts received from the plan after termination of employment. (3) Rehire of employee with more than ten years of service. An eligible employee who was a participant in this plan, had ten years of service or more at the time of his termination of employment and who is subsequently rehired by an employer, shall have all his service restored; provided however, if prior to rehire, the participant received all amounts due under the plan, service shall not be restored unless the participant repays to the plan all of the amounts received plus interest. (c) Not contract for employment. Participation in the plan shall not give any employee the right to be retained in the employer's employ, nor shall any employee, upon dismissal from or voluntary termination of his employment, have any right or interest in the trust fund, except as herein provided. (d) Effective January 1, 2018, no employee hired or rehired on or before October 1, 2017 shall begin participating in the plan. (Ord. No. 2010-90, § 3, 12-7-2010; Ord. No. 2016-177, § 3, 1-5-2016; Ord. No. 2017-190, § 3, 10-17-2017) Sec. 2-149. - Retirement dates and benefits. (a) Normal retirement. (1) Amount. A participant who retires on his normal retirement date shall be entitled to a monthly retirement income paid in the normal form equal to: a. The participant's monthly pension amount as determined as of December 31, 1982, plus b. One and six-tenths percent of the participant's average monthly compensation multiplied by the participant's service. c. For purposes of determining a participant's monthly pension amount, no compensation or service shall be taken into account after December 31, 2017. However, service earned after such date shall continue to be counted for purposes of vesting under the plan and for purpose of determining eligibility for early retirement. (2) Vesting on normal retirement. A participant who attains normal retirement age while in active employment with an employer shall become 100 percent vested in his accrued benefit as of such date. (3) Normal form. Retirement income shall be expressed as a monthly amount, payable as an annuity for the participant's life (the "normal form"). (b) Early retirement. (1) Eligibility. Each participant who retires on or after his early retirement age but before his normal retirement age, may elect early retirement. A participant who elects early retirement is entitled to receive a monthly retirement income payable in the form described in section 2-151 beginning on his early retirement date. (2) Amount of early retirement income. The retirement income payable to a participant who elects early retirement shall be determined in the same manner as his normal retirement benefit calculated as described above, but reduced by zero and five-twelfths percent for each month by which the participant's early retirement date precedes his normal retirement date to take into account the participant's younger age and the earlier commencement of retirement income payments. (3) Rule of 80. Notwithstanding section (b)(1) above, effective between September 30, 2016 and March 31, 2017 only, the retirement income payable to a participant who retires before his normal retirement age but on or after the age at which the sum of the participant's age plus his number of years of service equals 80 or more, shall be determined in the same manner as his normal retirement benefit calculated as described above, unreduced. (c) Late retirement date. (1) Eligibility. Any participant who attains his normal retirement age may remain in the active employ of the employer beyond his normal retirement age and may postpone his retirement income payments until a later date; provided however, that a participant may not postpone receipt of his retirement income beyond the required beginning date as set forth in section 2-151(e). Such retirement shall be known as the participant's late retirement date and is payable in the form described in section 2-151. (2) Amount of late retirement income. The retirement income payable to a participant who retires on his late retirement date shall be the sum of a., b. and c. defined below: a. The participant's normal retirement income; and b. An actuarial adjustment for the plan year which includes the participant's normal retirement date and each plan year thereafter as determined in (3) below; and c. The excess, if any of the additional benefit accrual earned after the participant's normal retirement date during the plan year which includes his normal retirement date and during each plan year thereafter, over the actuarial adjustment for each such plan year respectively. (3) Actuarial adjustment. The actuarial adjustment will be determined as of the close of each plan year and will be equal to the increase in the participant's monthly retirement income as of the close of the preceding plan year (or the participant's normal retirement date, if later) which is required in order to provide a monthly benefit as of the determination date that is the actuarial equivalent of the monthly benefit as of the close of the preceding plan year (or the participant's normal retirement date, if later). (d) Vested termination benefit. (1) Ten year cliff vesting provision. A participant who terminates employment for any reason other than retirement but after completing ten years of service shall be entitled to the monthly retirement income equal to the normal retirement income earned by the participant determined in accordance with section 2-149(a) hereof but using the participant's compensation and service as of his termination of employment. Such benefit shall be referred to herein as a vested termination benefit and shall be payable in the form described in section 2-151. A participant who terminates employment with the employer for any reason other than retirement and before completing ten years of service shall not be entitled to receive any retirement income under this plan (other than a return of participant contributions as provided in (3) below). (2) Commencement of retirement income for vested terminated participants. a. Commencement at normal retirement age. A vested terminated participant's retirement income shall commence as of his normal retirement date, unless the participant is eligible for and elects early commencement of his retirement income as provided in b. below. b. Commencement before or after normal retirement age. A terminated participant generally may elect to convert his vested termination benefit into an early retirement income or late retirement income which is payable either before or after his normal retirement date, respectively, in accordance with section 2-149(b) and section 2-149(c), provided he has met any age or service requirement set forth therein. (3) Return of contributions. If a participant has a termination of employment before earning at least ten years of service he shall receive a mandatory distribution of his participant contributions, plus interest. If such participant contributions plus interest are less than $5,000.00, they shall be returned to the participant in a single lump sum payment as of his termination of employment or as soon as practical thereafter. If such participant contributions plus interest are equal to or greater than $5,000.00, they shall be returned to the participant in a single lump sum payment as of the one-year anniversary of the participant's termination of employment or as soon as practical thereafter. If a participant has a termination of employment at least 15 years prior to his normal retirement age, the participant will receive a one-time election to receive an immediate lump sum distribution of his participant contributions, plus interest and forgo any other benefits under the plan, upon such termination of employment. Such distribution shall be made within 90 days of the termination of employment or as soon as practical thereafter. (4) Forfeiture. Benefits under the plan may be reduced or forfeited to the extent permitted under O.C.G.A. §§ 47-1-20 through 47-1-25, if the participant is convicted of a public employment, drug related or other covered crime. (e) Disability. A participant who terminates employment due to a disability, after completing ten years of service, shall receive a monthly retirement income equal to the normal retirement income determined as of his termination of employment beginning as of the first day of the month following his determination of disability. Such disability benefit may be paid in an optional form, as elected by the participant in accordance with section 2-151(c) of the plan. (f) Restoration of service. (1) Reemployment before becoming vested. If a participant has a termination of employment before earning at least ten years of service and is rehired by an employer, his years of service attributable to the previous period of employment shall be ignored unless he repays within one year of rehire all participant contributions plus interest that he received from the plan. (2) Reemployment after becoming vested. If a participant has a termination of employment after earning at least ten years of service and is rehired by an employer, his years of service attributable to the previous period of employment shall be restored unless prior to rehire, the participant received all amounts due under the plan. In such a case, if the participant repays the entire distribution plus interest to the plan within one year of rehire, all his years of service shall be restored. (Ord. No. 2010-90, § 4, 12-7-2010; Ord. No. 2011-105, § 2, 9-20-2011; Ord. No. 2014-142, § 2, 2-4-2014; Ord. No. 2016-177, § 4, 1-5-2016; Ord. No. 2017-183, § 2, 3-7-2017; Ord. No. 2017-190, § 4, 10-17-2017) Sec. 2-150. - Death benefits. (a) Pre-retirement survivor annuity. If a participant's employment terminates on account of his death after he is eligible for a vested termination benefit, an early retirement income, normal retirement income or late retirement income, but before benefits have begun, his eligible spouse or eligible dependents(s) shall be eligible to receive a monthly retirement income known as a pre-retirement survivor annuity. A participant who attains at least age 55 prior to his death may make an election to have the pre-retirement survivor annuity paid to his or her beneficiary in an amount equal to the survivor portion of a 50 percent joint and survivor annuity, or the survivor portion of a 100 percent joint and survivor annuity. If a participant has made no such election prior to his death then the pre-retirement survivor annuity shall equal 50 percent of the monthly retirement income the participant would have received if he terminated employment the date before his death. Pre-retirement death benefits shall be payable as of the first day of each month coincident or next following the participant's date of death and shall be payable to the eligible spouse or to the eligible dependent(s) in equal shares to each eligible dependent. (b) Return of participant contributions. If a participant dies before meeting the requirements of section 2-150(a) above, his designated beneficiary shall be entitled to receive a lump sum payment equal to his participant contributions plus interest. (c) Death after retirement. If a participant's employment terminates on account of his death after his retirement income has commenced in the normal form, the participant's designated beneficiary shall receive a benefit equal to the excess of any of the total participant contributions plus interest over the total payments made to the participant as of his date of death. If a participant's employment terminates on account of his death after his retirement income has commenced in an optional form, his beneficiary shall receive the benefits determined under the option selected. (Ord. No. 2010-90, § 5, 12-7-2010; Ord. No. 2014-142, § 3, 2-4-2014; Ord. No. 2016-177, § 5, 1-5-2016) Sec. 2-151. - Payment of benefits; optional forms of retirement income. (a) Payment of retirement income. (1) Monthly payments. The retirement income payable for normal, early or late retirement shall be payable on the first day of each month and shall begin on the normal, early or late retirement date as applicable; provided however, a participant will not be considered to have retired and will not be eligible to commence receipt of benefits of his early retirement income as long as he continues to be employed by the employer or if he is reemployed by the employer (prior to his normal retirement date) within 90 days of his termination of employment. (2) Benefit commencement date. Normal, early or late retirement income payments shall not commence earlier that the first day of the month following the date on which the participant's complete application for a benefit is filed at the office of the plan administrator; provided however, payment must commence by the required beginning date. (3) Death of participant before payments begin. If a participant dies before his retirement income payments are effective, no benefits shall be payable under the plan except as provided in section 2-150. (b) Normal form of payment. The normal form of payment shall be a life annuity option, which is a monthly retirement income payable to the participant during the participant's lifetime, with payments ceasing upon the participant's death. All benefit formulas in this plan shall give the amount of the participant's retirement income if it is paid in the life annuity option, beginning at the participant's normal retirement date. (c) Optional forms of payment. (1) Optional forms available. A participant may elect to receive any of the optional forms of payment listed below, in lieu of the normal form of payment. The selection of an optional form of benefit shall be final and binding upon the participant and his beneficiary on the date the participant's retirement income commences, except as otherwise provided below. a. One hundred and twenty months certain and life option. This is a reduced monthly retirement income equal to the actuarial equivalent of the life annuity option. The retirement income shall be payable to the participant during his lifetime and, in the event of the participant's death within a period of 120 months after the commencement of benefits, the same monthly amount shall be payable to the participant's beneficiary for the remainder of such 120 month period. b. Joint and survivor annuity option. This is a reduced monthly retirement income equal to the actuarial equivalent of the life annuity option. The retirement income shall be payable to the participant for his life, and upon the participant's death, a designated percentage (100 percent, 66 ⅔ percent, 50 percent as elected by the participant) of the participant's retirement income shall be payable to the participant's beneficiary for the beneficiary's life. Such retirement income shall cease on the later of the death of the participant or the death of the participant's beneficiary. c. Death of beneficiary. If the participant's beneficiary or joint annuitant dies before the participant's retirement income begins, any optional form elected by the participant will be cancelled and the participant will receive retirement income in the normal form unless the participant makes a new election for an optional form with a new beneficiary or joint annuitant. d. Social Security option. This is an increased monthly retirement income equal to the actuarial equivalent of the life annuity option. The retirement income shall be payable to the participant for his life until his social security benefits commence and a reduced retirement income payable thereafter for his life, so that combined social security benefits and retirement income payments are essentially level. e. Death [of] the participant and beneficiary. If both the participant and the beneficiary die after the date the participant's retirement income payment becomes effective but before full payment has been made, any guaranteed payment shall be paid to a contingent beneficiary and if the commuted value of the remaining payments is less than $5,000.00, such payment shall automatically be made in a lump sum. (2) Lump sum option. If the present value of the total amount due to the participant or beneficiary is $10,000.00 or less, the participant or beneficiary may elect to receive payment in a single lump sum payment. (3) Minimum distribution incidental benefit rules. Any optional form of benefit elected by the participant must comply with the minimum distribution incidental benefit requirement of proposed Treasury Regulation § 1.401(a)(9)-2. This rule insures that the retirement benefits payable under the plan are more than incidental. (d) Small lump sum payments. If the monthly amount of the total retirement income (including that of a pre-retirement survivor annuity or disability payment) to be paid is less than $100.00 per month as of the date the retirement income payments are first effective or as of the date of death of the participant, then the single sum actuarial equivalent of such retirement income shall be paid in a lump sum to the participant or beneficiary, as applicable without their consent. (e) Special distribution rules (including age 70½ rules). (1) Commencement of distribution at normal retirement age. Payment of retirement income shall commence no later than the 60th day after the latest of the close of the plan year in which occurs: a. The participant's 65 birthday; b. The tenth anniversary of the date the participant commenced participation in this plan; or c. The participant's termination of employment. (2) Commencement at required beginning date. Notwithstanding (e)(1) above, distribution to a participant shall commence not later than the Required beginning date. The required beginning date shall be April 1 of the calendar year following the later of (i) the calendar year in which the participant attains age 70½ or (ii) the calendar year in which the participant terminates employment. (3) Effective date. The rules set forth in this section 2-151(e) shall apply for purposes of determining the required minimum distribution to participants and designated beneficiaries (as defined below) for calendar years beginning on and after January 1, 2003 even if, in the case of a designated beneficiary, the participant died before 2003. (4) No extension of death benefits or payment forms.
