(a) An alcoholic beverage license may be transferred as to place and as to person only with the consent of mayor and council after application therefore has been forwarded to the planning and community development department on forms furnished by the city, which consent may be given at any meeting of the mayor and council. A transfer fee as currently set or hereafter set by resolution by city council plus the cost of advertising shall accompany each such application for transfer of an alcoholic beverage license. No refund shall be made under any circumstances. (b) An application for a transfer of an alcoholic beverage license shall be handled procedurally the same as an original application in that an advertisement shall be made in the Moultrie Observer once a week for two weeks, signs will be posted at the location, and a public hearing will be held on the application for transfer. The proposed applicant/operator shall be held to the meet the same standards as the predecessor in the operation of the alcoholic beverage license. (Ord. No. 771, § 1(4-56), 12-16-1997; Ord. No. 967-2006, § 1, 1-3-2006) Sec. 6-102. - Restrictions. (a) Licenses hereunder shall not be transferable except as otherwise provided in this division. (b) In case of the death of any person owning a license or any interest therein, the same may, with the approval of the mayor and council and subject to the terms of this article, be transferred to the administrator, executor or personal representative of the deceased person, or to the heirs at law of the deceased person, if such heirs meet all of the other qualifications contained herein. The license of such deceased person shall be held by the administrator, executor, or personal representative of such deceased person only for the time necessary to complete execution of his estate and deposition of the license or his interest therein, but in no event to exceed six months. (c) Nothing in this section, however, shall prohibit one or more of the partners in a partnership holding a license to withdraw from the partnership and to assign his interest in such partnership to one or more of the partners who were partners at the time of the issuance of the license. Such withdrawal shall not, however, serve to bring any new ownership into the partnership, unless all provisions of this article are fully complied with, and then only upon the approval of the mayor and council. (d) Should a transfer of the location be desired, the new location shall meet all requirements of a new license to be issued hereunder, except payment of license fee. The transfer fee as currently set or hereafter set by resolution by city council plus the cost of advertising will accompany the application, and the unearned portion of the license fee shall be transferred to the new location in the event the transfer location is approved by mayor and council. (e) A licensee may take in partners or additional stockholders where it is determined that additional capital furnished is to be used exclusively for additional inventory or expanding the facilities of the business or for building new facilities and where it appears that the licensee himself will directly receive none of the additional capital investment. Under this section an additional partner or new stockholder must be approved by the mayor and council, as provided hereunder. (f) An application for a new license on an existing license location shall meet all requirements of a new license to be issued hereunder, except payment of a license fee. The transfer fee as currently set or hereafter set by resolution by city council plus the cost of advertising will accompany the application, and the unearned portion of the license fee shall be transferred to the new licensee in the event the transfer or issuance of a new license on an existing license location is approved by the mayor and council. (Ord. No. 771, § 1(4-57), 12-16-1997; Ord. No. 968-2006, § 1, 1-3-2006) Secs. 6-103—6-130. - Reserved. DIVISION 4. - RENEWAL
Sec. 6-131. - Annual renewal. (a) The licenses provided for in this article are annual. All annual license fees hereunder shall be paid in advance on or before February 1 of each year. A penalty of ten percent of the license fee shall be assessed for failure to renew the license on or before February 1. Any new license granted hereunder during a license year shall pay a full license fee without proration; provided, however, that if a license is granted after August 1, the license fee shall be one-half of the annual license for such license year. (b) All alcoholic beverage licenses in this chapter may be renewed by payment of the required fees, provided: (1) The license and location are the same; and (2) The licensee is still in compliance with the requirements of state and municipal laws and regulations pertaining to the original issuance of the license and pertaining to the operation of the business under the license at the time of application for renewal; but (3) If a complaint is received as to the licensee's alleged violation of state or municipal law or regulation, or for any other due cause as outlined in subsection 6-162(c), the license shall not be renewed but shall be referred to the mayor and council for decision as to whether renewal shall be granted as follows: a. The mayor and council shall conduct a hearing after giving the licensee reasonable notice of the time and place of such hearing, as well as the purpose thereof. b. The licensee may remain open for business until a decision by the mayor and council is made and shall have a period of three days following that decision in which to pay the required fees if the decision of mayor and council is to permit renewal of the license. (Ord. No. 771, § 1(4-65), 12-16-1997) Secs. 6-132—6-160. - Reserved. DIVISION 5. - REVOCATION
Sec. 6-161. - Revocation for violation of article. Violation of any of the provisions of this article by the holder of a license issued hereunder shall subject the holder of such license to revocation of the license, as provided herein. (Ord. No. 771, § 1(4-70), 12-16-1997) Sec. 6-162. - Grounds for suspension or revocation; notice; hearing; refund. (a) Right to inspect and examine books and records. The city council, any member thereof, the city manager and his designee shall have the right to inspect and examine the books and records of all wholesale and retail dealers in alcoholic beverages any time during the normal hours of business operation by such licensees. (b) Notice; hearing. Any license which has been issued or which may be issued by the city to any licensee may be suspended or revoked by the mayor and council for due cause. Before the city council shall revoke or suspend any existing license, the applicant shall be given notice in writing from the city clerk to show cause before the city council at a time and place specified therein, not less than three days nor more than ten days from the date of service of the notice, why the license should not be revoked or suspended, as the case may be, stating the grounds therefore, and at the appointed time and place the licensee shall have the opportunity to show cause, if any exists, why the application should not be denied or the license revoked or suspended, after which the city council shall take such action as it, in its judgment and discretion, shall deem warranted under the facts, including suspension or revocation, and may impose a fine as currently set or hereafter set by resolution by city council. The hearing herein provided for need not be at a regular meeting of the city council, but may be at such time and place as shall be fixed in the notice. All decisions suspending or revoking any license shall be in writing, with the reason therefore stated, and mailed or delivered to the applicant. In addition, at any hearing as provided herein, the party afforded the hearing shall have the opportunity to present evidence, have an attorney, and have testimony recorded at his expense. (c) Due cause generally. (1) Due cause for the suspension or revocation of any license shall consist of an act of omission found to be by the mayor and council, after a hearing as above provided, a violation of any law or ordinance regulating such business, or violation of regulations made pursuant to authority granted for the purpose of regulating such business, of for the violation of any state or federal law, or for the violation of any city ordinances, other than traffic violations or ordinances, of failure of the licensee or his employee to promptly report to the police department any violation of the law or ordinances, breach of peace, disturbance or altercation resulting in violence occurring inside the building or on the premises. (2) Due cause may also be found should the licensed establishment have become a trouble spot in the judgment of the council by reason of disturbance or acts of disorderly conduct or violence having occurred in the business or on the premises thereof; provided that when the license of any establishment has been revoked or renewal of license denied because the establishment has become a trouble spot, no further license shall be issued under this chapter to any person at the location for a period of at least 12 months from the date of revocation. (3) Due cause shall also consist of the business or the operation or location thereof of the owner or any person connected therewith ceasing to meet any of the qualifications for the issuance of license as stated in this chapter. (4) Due cause may also be found upon the revelation of any false statement or material misrepresentation in any application hereunder. Any material omission from or untrue or misleading information which is contained in an original, renewal or transfer application for license hereunder shall be cause for the denial or refusal of a license, and if any license has previously been granted under such circumstances, the same shall constitute due cause for suspension or revocation of such license. (5) Failure to control operation resulting in public nuisance. If the failure to control the operation either inside the building or outside on the property results in controlled substance abuse, prostitution, gambling, flagrant indecent conduct or obscenity, fighting, excessive noise, loitering or illegal parking, to the number of times and extent that the city council, after proper hearing, should find the establishment to have become a public nuisance, then such failure may be declared to be due cause for suspension or revocation of the alcoholic beverage license for such establishment, or the denial of renewal application for same. (d) Notification. It shall be the duty of a license holder to notify the city if the licensee or any employee is accused of any violation listed in subsection (c)(1) of this section. (e) Emergency due cause; failure or refusal to cooperate with police acting in line of duty. On evidence of failure or refusal of the licensee or any employee hereunder to cooperate with any police officer on any reasonable request or action within such officer's duties, responsibilities or powers, including all police powers, rights and duties to investigate to determine any pertinent fact relating to the establishment, the licensee, any employees or corporate officers or partners, the city manager or his designee shall immediately order all sales of any alcoholic beverages discontinued until after a hearing is set out in the due cause hearing provided for in subsection (b) of this section, such hearing to be concerning such failure or refusal to cooperate. (f) Refund of license fee. When a license is so revoked or suspended, the city shall not be required to refund any portion of the license fee. When a license is revoked, the licensee may not reapply for a license hereunder for a period of ten years from the date of such revocation. (g) Emergency situation. The city manager or his designee is hereby authorized to suspend any license issued hereunder in any emergency situation such as civil disorder or natural disaster or in any situation that the city manager deems such immediate suspension necessary for the protection of the health and welfare of the citizens of the city, and the suspension may be made effective immediately and shall remain in force until the city manager determines the emergency is over or until the next regular meeting of the mayor and council or a meeting called prior to the next regular meeting. (Ord. No. 771, § 1(4-71), 12-16-1997; Ord. No. 969-2006, § 1, 1-3-2006) Sec. 6-163. - Automatic revocation. (a) Whenever the state shall revoke any permit or license to manufacture or sell at wholesale or retail any alcoholic beverages, the city license to manufacture or sell at wholesale or retail any such product within the city shall thereupon be automatically revoked without any further action by the mayor and council or any officer of the city. If the state has suspended the license or placed the same on probation, the city license is automatically suspended or probated, as the case may be. (b) Whenever a license holder fails pay any penalty set forth in subsection 6-199(a) within 30 days of its imposition the license issued by the city shall be automatically revoked without any further action by the mayor and council or any officer of the city. (Ord. No. 771, § 1(4-72), 12-16-1997; Ord. No. 970-2006, § 1, 1-3-2006) Sec. 6-164. - Removal of signs after revocation. When any licensee for the sale of alcoholic beverages is revoked, all signs indicating that such beverages may be sold or purchased shall be immediately removed from the place of business. Upon receipt by the police department of notice of revocation, the police department shall take the necessary steps to see that this section is enforced. (Ord. No. 771, § 1(4-73), 12-16-1997) Secs. 6-165—6-190. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - STANDARDS AND REGULATIONS
Sec. 6-191. - City official, spouse, children prohibited from interest in license. It shall be unlawful for any elected official of any employee of the city or his or her spouse or children under the age of 18 to have any whole, partial, or beneficial interest in any license to sell alcoholic beverages during the tenure of such official or employee with the city, provided that such shall not prevent the ownership of real estate occupied by a license. (Ord. No. 771, § 1(4-81), 12-16-1997) Sec. 6-192. - Display of license. All persons holding an alcoholic beverage license issued under this chapter shall display the license permanently at all times in the business for which the license was issued. (Ord. No. 771, § 1(4-82), 12-16-1997) Sec. 6-193. - Display of name of licensee at spirituous liquor package stores. Each licensee for the sale of alcoholic beverages by the package at retail shall be permitted one wall mounted sign not exceeding five percent of the facade of the building displaying the name of the licensee. In addition, spirituous liquor package stores located within a retail shopping center greater than 80,000 square feet shall be permitted one 50-square foot tenant sign on a freestanding joint tenant sign for the shopping center. Signs shall not be illuminated. There shall be no other signage of any kind on the premises which is visible from the exterior of the premises. (Ord. No. 771, § 1(4-83), 12-16-1997; Ord. No. 923, § 2, 8-3-2004) Sec. 6-194. - Change in ownership reported to planning and community development department. Any change in any of the relationships and/or ownership interest contained on the application must be filed with the planning and community development department within 30 days after such change is made, and the failure to do so shall be grounds for immediate suspension or revocation by the mayor and council of any license issued hereunder or for the immediate dismissal of any application for a license hereunder. (Ord. No. 771, § 1(4-84), 12-16-1997; Ord. No. 971-2006, § 1, 1-3-2006) Sec. 6-195. - Consumption regulated; drinking in public. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person to drink any intoxicating beverage in any street or sidewalk within the city. (b) It shall be unlawful to possess any intoxicating beverage within any public park or on the premises of any publicly owned recreation center within the city. (c) It shall be unlawful for any person to drink any intoxicating beverages on the outside of any commercial establishment on the property thereof. (d) It shall be unlawful for any person to possess an open container of any intoxicating beverage while operating a vehicle on the public streets, rights-of-way or other public property in the city or while a passenger in or on a vehicle being operated on the public streets, rights-of-way or other public properties in the city. (1) As used herein, the term "open container" means any container, the contents of which are immediately capable of being consumed or any container the seal of which has been broken. (2) An open container shall be considered to be in the possession of the operator of a vehicle if the container is not in the possession of a passenger and is not located in a locked glove compartment, locked trunk or otherwise inaccessible. A container is inaccessible within the meaning of this subsection if it is accessible to neither the driver nor any other person in the vehicle, which such driver and other persons are seated in the vehicle. (3) An open container shall be considered to be in the possession of a passenger of a vehicle if the container is in the physical control of the passenger. (4) This subsection shall not apply to the following: a. A passenger of a vehicle in which the driver is operating the vehicle pursuant to a contract to provide transportation for passengers and such driver holds a valid chauffeur's license pursuant to state law or that of any other state. b. A passenger of a bus in which the driver holds a valid chauffeur's license pursuant to state law or that of any other state. (Ord. No. 771, § 1(14-85), 12-16-1997) Sec. 6-196. - Acceptable identification of patrons. It shall be the responsibility of the licensee to examine the identification of patrons to be certain that such patrons are of the legal age of 21 to purchase alcoholic beverages. Acceptable identification as established hereunder shall be a valid driver's license, armed services identification card, or state identification card, all of which must carry a picture of the holder and appear to be valid upon its face. (Ord. No. 771, § 1(4-86), 12-16-1997) Sec. 6-197. - Underage persons; faked credentials. It shall be unlawful for any person under the minimum age set by state law from time to time for the purchase or possession of alcoholic beverages to exhibit faked, forged or borrowed credentials or to falsely misrepresent their age in any manner whatsoever in an effort to obtain alcoholic beverages to which he is not entitled. (Ord. No. 771, § 1(4-87), 12-16-1997) Sec. 6-198. - Purchase, consumption or possession by minors. No alcoholic beverages of any kind shall be sold or furnished to any person under the minimum age set by state law as the same exists from time to time. Furthermore it shall be unlawful for: (1) Any minor to purchase, attempt to purchase, drink, or possess any alcoholic beverage. (2) Any person to keep or maintain a place wherein minors are allowed and permitted to come and purchase, drink, or possess any alcoholic beverages. (3) Any parent or other person to purchase any alcoholic beverages and furnish same to a minor for consumption, except for as allowed by O.C.G.A. § 3-3-23. (Ord. No. 771, § 1(4-88), 12-16-1997) Sec. 6-199. - Penalties. (a) Upon determination by the city council that a sale of alcoholic beverages to an underage person has taken place by a license holder, including the license holder's agent or employee, or that an underage person as an employee of license holder made a sale of alcoholic beverages, such determination having been made after a show cause hearing held for the license holder or the license holder's employee, if applicable, the following schedule of penalties shall be applicable to the holder of the license: ADMINISTRATIVE PENALTIES
(b) Upon determination by the city council that a sale of an alcoholic beverage has taken place by a license holder's agent or employee without a proper beer card or not otherwise authorized to sale an alcoholic beverage, such determination having been made after a show cause hearing held, the following schedule of penalties shall be applicable to the holder of the license:
(c) It shall be unlawful for any license holder, a license holder's agent or employee to sell to any underage person(s). Upon determination of guilt or entry of a plea of guilty or no contest (nolo contendere) in the municipal court the following schedule of penalties shall be applicable: FINE SCHEDULE FOR MUNICIPAL COURT
(d) It shall be unlawful for any license holder's agent or employee to sell alcoholic beverages without a proper beer card or not otherwise authorized to sale an alcoholic beverage. Upon determination of guilt or entry of a plea of guilty or no contest (nolo contendere) in the municipal court the following schedule of penalties shall be applicable:
(e) Other than as hereinbefore set forth in subsections (a)—(d) upon determination by the city council that due cause exists as set forth in subsection 6-162(c) of this Code and/or that there has occurred a violation of this chapter or a violation of any criminal ordinance, statute, rule or regulation, for which a penalty is not otherwise established, the city council may impose a penalty upon the license holder of $2,000.00 for the 1st offense and $5,000.00 for the 2nd and subsequent offenses, irrespective of location. This penalty may be imposed in lieu of or in addition to any suspension, revocation, or other sanction authorized by law. (f) In every case in which an alcoholic beverages license is suspended pursuant to this subsection, the licensee shall be required to post a public notice in a prominent and conspicuous location on the front door or adjacent window of the licensed premises throughout the period of suspension which shall meet the following requirements: (1) The dimensions of the notice shall be at least 8.5 inches by 11 inches with a font size of at least 18 point Times New Roman; (2) The notice shall contain the licensee name, license number, address of the licensed location, and a statement that the licensee's license is suspended pursuant to a finding of the city council that a violation of law has been committed. (3) Failure to comply with the notice provisions of this subsection shall subject the licensee to additional administrative action including, but not limited to, suspension, revocation or cancellation of the license. (Ord. No. 771, § 1(4-89), 12-16-1997; Ord. of 10-16-2000, § 1; Ord. No. 972-2006, § 1, 1-3-2006; Ord. No. 2011-96, § 5, 6-7-2011; Ord. No. 2014-164, § 2, 12-16-2014) Sec. 6-200. - Selling or furnishing to intoxicated persons. No intoxicating beverages of any kind shall be sold or furnished to any visibly intoxicated person or to any person known by the licensee or the licensee's employees to be a habitual drunkard, or to any person known to such licensee to be of unsound mind. (Ord. No. 771, § 1(4-90), 12-16-1997) Sec. 6-201. - Allowing minors on licensed premises prohibited at spirituous liquor package stores. No person who holds a license to sell spirituous liquors by the package shall allow any minor to be in, frequent, or loiter about the premises of the licensee. (Ord. No. 771, § 1(4-91), 12-16-1997) Sec. 6-202. - Handling of alcoholic beverages by minors; exception. It shall be unlawful for any person under the minimum age set by state law from time to time for the purchase or possession of alcoholic beverages to have alcoholic beverages in his possession in the city, except that the handling or possession of alcoholic beverages by a person under the minimum age set by state law in connection with his employment shall not be considered a violation of this section. However, such underage person shall not sell alcoholic beverages. (Ord. No. 771, § 1(4-92), 12-16-1997) Sec. 6-203. - Employees of licensees; procedure; fees; background check; qualifications. (a) No person may be employed by an establishment holding a license hereunder until such person has been issued an identification card indicating the person to be employed is eligible for such employment pursuant to this section. Every employee working in a licensed establishment shall publicly display the identification card inside the business establishment at all times that the employee is working or handling alcoholic beverages. (b) The police department shall make a complete and exhaustive search relative to the criminal record of any person applying for an identification card. (c) No person shall be issued an identification card for shall be issued to a person seeking employment by an establishment holding a license hereunder if they: (1) Shall have been convicted of any felony under the laws of this state or of the United States within a period of ten years immediately preceding the date of receipt of the application. The term "conviction" shall include an adjudication of guilt or a plea of guilty or a plea of nolo contendere or the forfeiture of a bond by a person charged with a crime; or (2) Shall have been convicted of a misdemeanor, or ordinance violation, or traffic offense involving moral turpitude, alcoholic beverages, or controlled substances, within two years immediately preceding the date of their request for an identification card pursuant to this subsection. (d) Identification cards issued pursuant to this section will remain the property of the city and may be confiscated by the chief of police or his designee whenever reasonable cause exists to believe that the cardholder has ceased to meet the qualifications for employment in a licensed establishment. The failure of any cardholder to surrender such identification card on demand by the chief of police or his designee will constitute a violation of this section. (e) Identification cards issued pursuant to this section shall specifically identify the employee and the employing establishment(s). Identification cards shall be renewed prior to their expiration pursuant to subsection (f) of this section otherwise, a new application for an identification card is required. Identification cards shall be valid only during the cardholder's employment at the licensed establishment named on the identification card, unless the card is cancelled or revoked under the provisions of subsection (d) of this section. (f) Every person, except license holders, shall be required to have an identification card in order to sell alcoholic beverages. Said card shall be obtained from the police department. Identification cards will be valid for a period of two years at which time they must be renewed at the police department. Permits are not transferable to other employment within the city. Those applicants not meeting all of the applicable guidelines with respect to issuance or qualifications shall not receive a permit nor renewal. Applicants shall pay a fee at the time of application or renewal as currently or hereafter set by resolution by city council. (Ord. No. 771, § 1(4-93), 12-16-1997; Ord. No. 973-2006, § 1, 1-3-2006; Ord. No. 2014-164, § 3, 12-16-2014) Sec. 6-204. - Licensed establishments to have telephone. Any establishment having an alcoholic beverage license must have a telephone. Failure of an establishment to maintain an operating telephone shall be grounds for revocation of the license by the city council. (Ord. No. 771, § 1(4-94), 12-16-1997) Sec. 6-205. - Hours of sale; hours of operation. (a) Generally. No licensee shall permit the sale of alcoholic beverages on any day or during any time of day when such sales are prohibited by state law. (1) Except as hereinafter provided, no alcoholic beverages shall be sold, either at wholesale or retail, within the city limits on Christmas Day or Sundays or between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 8:00 a.m.; provided, however, that the earliest hour for the sale of beer, ale or malt beverages shall be 6:00 a.m. (2) The sale of alcoholic beverages in restaurants and private clubs for on-premises consumption shall be permitted only during hours when food service is offered between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 12:00 midnight Monday through Saturday and must be removed from the tables one hour after the sale of food ceases, or by 1:00 a.m. if food is served beyond 12:00 midnight, and all patrons will be out of such establishments and the establishment shall be closed by 2:00 a.m. (b) Package spirituous liquors. The exterior entrances of package stores must be locked not later than 11:45 p.m. The licensee shall not engage in the sale of such liquors except between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 12:00 midnight Monday through Saturday. (c) Wholesalers. The business hours of any wholesaler licensed hereunder shall be from sunup to sundown, exclusive of Sundays and Christmas Day. (d) Sundays. (1) Retail package licensees shall be permitted to sell package alcoholic beverages on Sundays only between the hours of 12:30 p.m. and 11:30 p.m. (2) Licensees for the sale of alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises shall be permitted to sell alcoholic beverages for on premises consumption on Sundays only from 12:30 P.M. until 12:00 Midnight provided the establishment at which said beverages are sold must derive at least 50 percent of its total annual gross sales from the sale of prepared meals or food in all of the combined retail outlets of the individual establishment where food is served and in any licensed establishment which derives at least 50 percent of its total annual gross income from the rental of rooms for overnight lodging. (e) Election days. Any licensee for the sale of alcoholic beverages may sell alcoholic beverages in the city on any election days. (Ord. No. 771, § 1(4-95), 12-16-1997; Ord. No. 2013-133, § 1, 7-2-2013) Sec. 6-206. - Premises regulations for on-premises consumption. (a) Lighting. All licensees for the sale of alcoholic beverages for on-premises consumption who do not hold a food service permit issued by the county health department are required to establish and maintain exterior lighting in their parking areas and walkways at a minimum maintained level of two footcandles. Upon determination by the city council that a violation ofthis subsection has taken place, such determination having been made after a show cause hearing held, the following schedule of penalties shall be applicable to the person having sold said alcoholic beverage and the holder of the license and the owner(s) of the premises: An administrative penalty of $500.00 for the first offense and $1,000.00 for the 2nd and each subsequent offense by a license holder for a violation of subsection (b) at the same store or location shall be imposed. The administrative penalty set forth herein shall be in addition to any other penalties imposed in this chapter. (b) Notification of barred individuals. All licensees for the sale of alcoholic beverages for on-premises consumption who do not hold a food service permit issued by the county health department are required to notify the police department in writing of the names of all individuals permanently barred from the licensees' premises at the time such exclusion becomes effective. (c) Brown bagging. "Brown bagging" shall mean the bringing, taking or carrying of any alcoholic beverage for consumption on the premises into any business licensed to operate in the City of Moultrie, or into any leased, rented, or borrowed facility, room, patio, garden, or similar locale by individuals, groups, or organizations who are not license holders for the sale of alcoholic beverages. The bringing, taking, or carrying of alcoholic beverages into a house, apartment, room, or other unit designed for and/or used for private residential occupancy, or into the environs of such locations, shall not be considered "brown bagging". (d) Permitted uses. Except as provided for in paragraph (g) below, no license holder (including agents or employees) of any business establishment in the City of Moultrie shall permit any person to enter upon the premises of the establishment carrying any opened or unopened package, can, bottle, flask, keg, or container of alcoholic beverage for the purpose of consumption therein (commonly referred to as "brown bagging") unless the license holder is licensed by the City of Moultrie to sell alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises. Furthermore, with the exception of bona fide private clubs and post chapters of nationally-chartered veterans and fraternal organizations as defined herein, only the "brown bagging" of alcohol of the classification of the license held by the license holder shall be permitted in the business establishment. By way of example, if the license holder's license is only for the sale of malt beverages for consumptions on the business establishment premises, then only the "brown bagging" of malt beverages shall be allowed. If the license holder is licensed for the sale of malt beverages and wine for consumption on the business establishment premises, the "brown bagging" of both malt beverages and wine shall be allowed. In all cases, the license holder of the establishment, not the patron, customer, guest, or clientele shall determine whether or not to permit "brown bagging" in the business establishment. (e) Licensing. If the license holder of a business establishment does not intend to sell alcoholic beverages, but only wishes to permit customers to enter upon the premises of the establishment carrying alcoholic beverages for the purpose of consumption therein, an alcoholic beverage license shall be required. (f) Hours of operation. Unless exempted in paragraph (g) below, license holders for the sale of alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises who permit the practice of "brown bagging" as defined herein shall only permit "brown bagging" during the same times and days of the week as specified in section 6-205 for the sale of such beverages. Furthermore, unless exempted in paragraph (g) below, the mandatory closing times and hours of operation specified in section 6-205 shall apply to all licensed business establishments who permit the practice of "brown bagging", if "brown bagging" is taking place. (g) Exceptions. The requirements of this section shall not pertain to the private rental, lease, loan or use of a facility, room, patio, garden, or similar locale by individuals, groups, or organizations who, on a not-for-profit basis, may, from time to time, sponsor events, hold parties, conduct banquets, or host receptions at which alcoholic beverages are served free of charge to attendees for personal consumption on the premises, with the consent of the individual, group or organization. Examples would be a civic club's New Year's party held in a rented banquet room at a hotel; an art exhibition held at a conference facility; a wine-tasting party hosted by a garden club; or a wedding reception held on the grounds of a residence or other property. In no case shall exceptions to the licensing requirements enumerated herein be construed to permit lounges, dance halls, game rooms, music venues, or any other type of for-profit business, function, or event open to the general public where alcoholic beverages are "brown bagged", or where alcoholic beverages are made available at no cost, but where a "cover charge" is collected. (h) Restrictions. Except as provided for in paragraph (g), the license holder agent, or employee of any business establishment in the City of Moultrie where alcoholic beverages are "brown bagged" for on premises consumption, shall not permit any person under 21 years of age to be present on the premises, including patios, outside decks, anterooms, and similar areas in close proximity to where alcoholic beverages are consumed unless the establishments is (1) a bona fide restaurant, café, or similar food service establishments in which at least 35 percent of the gross annual income is produced from the sale on the premises of food and has a minimum of 35 seats for the service of food or (2) a bona fide over-night lodging facility with an associated bar or lounge that is secondary to the primary function of lodging from which at least 75 percent of the establishment's gross annual income produced on the premises must be derived, or (3) bona fide bowling alley or similar gaming establishments in which at least 35 percent of the establishment's gross annual income produced on the premises is derived from fees or proceeds associated with bowling, gaming, food service, equipment rental, or other concessions. In the above cases, within 120 days after having been issued a license for the consumption of alcohol on the premises, the license holder shall submit to the city a statement from a certified public accountant or a registered public accountant that the income requirements set forth in this paragraph have been met for the first 90 days of operations. Thereafter, the license holder shall provide such statements to the city on an annual basis on or before the 1st day of January each year for the cumulative 12-month period of January through December of the prior year. (i) The age restrictions enumerated in paragraph (h) above do not apply to private residences or rented, leased, or loaned facilities, rooms, patios, gardens, or similar locales where individuals, groups, or organizations may, on a not-for-profit basis, from time to time, sponsor events, hold parties, conduct banquets, or host receptions at which alcoholic beverages are served free of charge to attendees of 21 years of age or older, or brought by attendees of 21 years of age old or older for personal consumption on the premises, with the consent of the individual, group or organization. Examples would be wedding reception held in a rented ballroom of a hotel; an art exhibition held in a conference center; or a class reunion held in the back yard of a private residence. (Ord. No. 771, § 1(4-96), 12-16-1997; Ord. No. 2009-54, § 1, 4-21-2009; Ord. No. 2011-96, §§ 6, 7, 6-7-2011) Sec. 6-207. - Exterior advertisement. (a) Spirituous liquor package stores. No signs of any kind, painted or electric, advertising spirituous liquors, beer or wine for sale or advertising any brand or price of spirituous liquors shall be permitted on the exterior of any licensed premises except only the name of the licensee referred to in section 6-193. Two lighted point of purchase (POP) signs not exceeding four square feet shall be permitted on the interior in the window. No placard or sign which is visible from the exterior of the licensed premises shall make reference to the price of any liquors sold therein, except tags showing the prices of individual bottles or containers may be affixed to such bottle or container, or to the edge of the shelf whereon such bottles or containers are located, as specified in section 6-210. (b) Liquor by the drink. No outside sign of any kind shall indicate that liquor by the drink is served within the licensed business except as may be inferred from the names or restaurant businesses. (Ord. No. 771, § 1(4-97), 12-16-1997; Ord. No. 923, § 3, 8-3-2004) Sec. 6-208. - Coin-operated devices, similar machines prohibited on licensed premises of spirituous liquor package stores. No retail dealer in spirituous liquors by the package shall permit in his business any slot machines, mechanical music boxes, pinball machines, machines operated for amusement purposes, or coin-operated machines of any kind and character, except only coin-operated machines for dispensing tobacco products. (Ord. No. 771, § 1(4-98), 12-16-1997) Sec. 6-209. - Products for sale, display or offer other than alcoholic beverages at spirituous liquor package stores. (a) No licensee of a retail establishment under this article shall sell or offer for sale or display or keep in stock at his place of business where distilled spirits are offered for sale any other product of commodity except the following: (1) Wines, but only if the licensee holds a valid and current license to sell wine at the place of business; (2) Malt beverages or beer, but only if the licensee holds a valid and current license to sell malt beverages or beer at the place of business; (3) Tobacco products; (4) Beverages containing no alcohol and commonly used to dilute distilled spirits; (5) Ice to be sold in sealed containers only; and (6) Paper, styrofoam, glass or plastic cups or glasses in unbroken packages containing at least ten items each. (b) Should such licensee elect to sell malt beverages or beer as provided in subsection (a)(2) of this section, such retail dealer shall be subject to all laws and regulations pertaining to the sale of distilled spirits, including but not limited to hours of sale and days of sale. (c) Beverages containing no alcohol and commonly used to dilute distilled spirits as provided in subsection (a)(4) of this section may be dispensed through the use of vending machines, but no alcoholic beverage shall be dispensed through such vending machine. (Ord. No. 771, § 1(4-99), 12-16-1997) Sec. 6-210. - Conspicuous display of prices at spirituous liquor package stores. Each retail licensee hereunder shall have conspicuously displayed within the interior of the licensed premises not less that four copies of a printed price list of the liquors offered for sale; provided, however, that a licensee, in lieu of having four copies of a printed list, may have the price placed on the bottle or on the shelf where liquors are exhibited for sale. (Ord. No. 771, § 1(4-100), 12-16-1997) Sec. 6-211. - Drive-in window or curb service prohibited at spirituous liquor package stores. (a) It shall be unlawful to sell or dispense spirituous liquors from drive-in or service windows. (b) Curb service or other sales of spirituous liquors outside the building licensed to sell is hereby expressly prohibited. (Ord. No. 771, § 1(4-101), 12-16-1997) Sec. 6-212. - Dispensing of ice or cups prohibited at spirituous liquor package stores. It shall be unlawful to dispense ice, cups or other containers for use in the consumption of alcoholic beverages from any premises licensed hereunder. (Ord. No. 771, § 1(4-102), 12-16-1997) Sec. 6-213. - Sale or delivery to unlicensed premises from spirituous liquor package stores. It shall be unlawful for any licensee hereunder to make deliveries of any alcoholic beverages by the package beyond the boundaries covered by the license. (Ord. No. 771, § 1(4-103), 12-16-1997) Sec. 6-214. - Regulations governing retail storage for spirituous liquor package stores and liquor by the drink. All licensed retailers shall store all spirituous liquors on the premises for which the license was issued and at no other place. All spirituous liquor stock shall be available at all times for inspection by the mayor and council or their duly authorized representatives. Any spirituous liquors found in any retailer's stock that is sold or distributed by a wholesaler who is not licensed in accordance with state laws to make sales and deliveries in the city shall be subject to immediate confiscation. (Ord. No. 771, § 1(4-104), 12-16-1997) Sec. 6-215. - Liquor pouring. (a) Coin-operated devices. Coin-operated equipment is permitted on the premises for the following purposes: vending machines, such as cigarettes; vending a service such as music or television; and for amusement, excluding any equipment designed or used for gambling purposes or refunds given in such manner as tickets, money, prizes or free games to entice play. (b) Package, broken package, carryout sales prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person on the premises of a licensee for on-premises consumption of distilled spirits to sell or offer to sell or give or lend to any person, for any purpose, including carryout, any alcoholic beverages by the package or bottle or by the broken container or remainder in a package or bottle. (c) Serving drinks to be by employees or employers. Drinks hereunder shall be served only by alcohol beverage license holders, employees or holders of an identification card indicating eligibility to serve alcoholic beverages, and neither the license holder nor the eligible employee shall consume any alcoholic beverages nor shall any employee be seated with any customer. (d) Service in back rooms prohibited. The sale of alcoholic beverages for consumption by persons in any back room or side room which is not open to general public use is prohibited except that private parties or conventions, which have been scheduled in advance, may be served in public or private dining rooms or meeting rooms, and provided further that this prohibition shall not apply to private clubs hereunder nor to the sale of alcoholic beverages for consumption hereunder to the registered guests of any hotel or motel. (Ord. No. 771, § 1(4-105), 12-16-1997) Sec. 6-216. - Keeping or storing other beverages without appropriate license. It shall be unlawful for any person operating under a license for the sale of beer or wine or both to store or have upon the business premises any whiskey or intoxicating liquors without an appropriate license therefor; provided, however, that it shall not be unlawful for the patrons of such a licensee to have in their personal possession any whiskey or intoxicating liquors. (Ord. No. 771, § 1(4-106), 12-16-1997) Secs. 6-217—6-245. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - TAXES[3]
Footnotes: --- (3) --- Cross reference— Taxation, ch. 102.
Sec. 6-246. - Occupational tax payment required. All alcoholic beverage licensees are required to submit a yearly payment of an occupational tax to be determined by the number of employees that the establishment employs and so referenced in this Code in section 26-47. (Ord. No. 771, § 1(4-120), 12-16-1997) Sec. 6-247. - Payment of taxes and other debts to city. The city clerk shall cause an inquiry to be made into the tax records to determine if any applicant, license holder or other parties interested in an application have any outstanding taxes or special assessments that are delinquent or any other monies owing to the city. No license shall be issued, nor shall a license be renewed until all such debts are paid in full irrespective of the nature of the debt. (Ord. No. 771, § 1(4-121), 12-16-1997; Ord. No. 2014-161, § 13, 11-18-2014) Sec. 6-248. - Excise taxes. (a) Malt beverages excise taxes for wholesale dealers. (1) There is hereby levied and imposed upon all wholesale dealers selling malt beverages within the city a specific excise tax in the amount of $0.05 per 12 ounces or proportionately thereof so as to graduate the tax on bottles, cans and containers of various sizes of all malt beverages sold by each wholesale dealer within the corporate limits. The excise tax on tap or draft beer shall be in the sum of $6.00 per container sold as hereinafter specified, containing not more than 15½ gallons and at a like rate for fractional parts thereof where the beverage is sold in or from a barrel or bulk container, such beverage being commonly known as tap or draft beer. All excise taxes required hereunder shall be paid as follows: a. Each wholesale dealer selling malt beverages within the city shall file a report by the tenth day of the month following the calendar month in which the beverages are sold or disposed of within the corporate limits. This report shall itemize for the preceding calendar month the exact quantities of malt beverages, by size and type of container, sold during the month within the corporate limits. The wholesale dealer shall further remit to the city on the tenth day of the month next succeeding the calendar month in which the sales were made the amount of excise taxes due in accordance with this section. b. No decal, stamp, or other identifying marking shall be required on malt beverages sold within the city. (2) The excise tax provided for hereinabove shall be in addition to any license fee, tax, or charge which may now or in the future be imposed upon the business of selling malt beverages at retail or wholesale within the corporate limits. (b) Malt beverage excise taxes for retail dealers. (1) Each wholesale dealer who has sold malt beverages within the city shall file a report by the tenth day of each month itemizing for the preceding calendar month the exact quantities for all malt beverages, by size and type of container for the month sold within the city. Each such wholesale dealer shall remit to the city on the tenth day of the month next succeeding the calendar month in which such sales were made the amount of excise tax due in accordance with this section. (2) The failure to make a timely report and remittance shall render a wholesale dealer liable for a penalty equal to ten percent of the total amount due during the first 30-day period following the date such report and remittance were due and a further penalty of ten percent of the amount of such remittance for each successive 30-day period or any portion thereof during which such report and remittance are not filed. The filing of a false or fraudulent report shall render the wholesale dealer making such report liable for a penalty equal to ten percent of the amount of the remittance which would be required under an accurate and truthful report. Such failure to make a timely report of remittance or the filing of a false or fraudulent report shall also constitute grounds for the revocation of the business license issued by the city to the wholesale dealer. (c) Wine. (1) There is hereby levied and imposed upon each wholesale dealer selling wine within the city an excise tax in the amount of $0.80 per gallon of wine and a proportionate tax at like rates on all fractional parts of a gallon, or in the case of wine sold in metric containers, an excise tax in the amount of $0.22 per liter and a proportionate tax at like rates on all fractional parts of a liter sold by such wholesale dealer within the corporate limits. (2) Each wholesale dealer who has sold wine within the city shall file a report by the tenth day of each month itemizing for the preceding calendar month the exact quantities of all wine by size and type of container for the month sold within the city. Each such wholesale dealer shall remit to the city on the tenth day of the month next succeeding the calendar month in which such sales were made the amount of excise tax due in accordance with this section. (3) The failure to make a timely report and remittance shall render a wholesale dealer liable for a penalty equal to ten percent of the total amount due during the first 30-day period following the date such report and remittance were due and a further penalty of ten percent of the amount of such remittance for each successive 30-day period or any portion thereof during which such report and remittance are not filed. The filing of a false or fraudulent report shall render the wholesale dealer making such report liable for a penalty equal to ten percent of the amount of the remittance which would be required under an accurate and truthful report. Such failure to make a timely report or remittance or the filing of a false or fraudulent report shall also constitute grounds for the revocation of the business license issued by the city to the wholesale dealer. (4) No decal, stamp, or other identifying marking shall be required on wine sold within the city. (5) The excise taxes provided for hereinabove shall be in addition to any license fee, tax or charge which may now or in the future be imposed upon the business of selling wine at retail or wholesale within the corporate limits. (d) Spirituous liquors. (1) Scope of subsection. In addition to all other taxes or license fees imposed upon retail dealers engaged in the city in the business of selling spirituous liquors, as defined under state laws, there is imposed and levied upon all hereinafter described dealers within the city an excise tax to be computed and collected as hereinafter set forth. (2) Basis for computation of tax. The tax levied hereunder shall be computed on the basis of $0.80 per wine gallon for spirituous liquors sold or delivered as hereinafter set forth. (3) Computation, payment, duties of wholesale dealer and distributor. The tax imposed shall be computed and payable monthly. Each wholesale dealer or distributor selling, shipping, or delivering spirituous liquors to any retail dealer in the city shall, as a condition to the privilege of conducting the business in the city: a. Keep and maintain true and correct records of all sales, shipments or deliveries of spirituous liquors to each retail dealer in the city, such records to be preserved for a period of not less than one year and to be made available on request for the inspection of any duly authorized representative of the city. b. Collect from each retail dealer in the city, at the time of delivery of spirituous liquors, the amount of tax due under the terms of this subsection and hold the same in trust for the city until such tax is remitted to the city as herein provided. c. On or before the tenth day of each calendar month, each wholesaler shall make a verified and comprehensive report to the city which shall correctly show and reflect all sales and deliveries of spirituous liquors to or for retail dealers in the city for the calendar month immediately preceding the date of the report. The report shall show the name and address of each retail dealer, the quantities delivered to each retail dealer, the amount of excise tax collected under the terms of this subsection, and such other reasonable information as may be requested by the city. The report shall be accompanied by remittance payable to the city for all taxes collected or due, as shown on the report. d. The excise tax levied in this subsection is hereby levied upon the retailer licensed to do business in the city, and it is the intent of this article to so levy this tax but require payment of the tax at the time of delivery to the retailer by the wholesaler, who shall have the responsibility of remitting the tax to the city on behalf of the retailer on or before the tenth day of each calendar month, as hereinbefore required. In the event the tax due hereunder is not paid on or before the tenth day of each calendar month, a ten-percent penalty on the gross tax will be levied by the city against each defaulting retailing licensee for whom the tax is not paid on or before the tenth day of the month. e. To ensure payment of the excise tax levied hereby and prior to the issuance of any retail liquor license in the city, an applicant must post and file with the city council, along with his application, a performance bond conditioned upon the faithful observance and performance by the applicant of the rules and regulations contained in this article, and the payment of any taxes due to the city. Upon the violation of this article or any part thereof, such bond will be forfeited as determined by the mayor and council at a hearing held for that purpose upon three days' written notice given to the licensee concerned. Bond shall be payable to the city clerk and shall be in the amount of $1,000.00 and shall be in a form furnished by the city and must be approved by the mayor and council. (4) Noncompliance by wholesale dealer; distributor. If any wholesale dealer or distributor fails or refuses to make the reports required herein, the city shall notify such dealer or distributor in writing, and if the reports are not made and the taxes remitted within five days from the date of such notice, such wholesale dealer or distributor shall be prohibited from making any further deliveries in the city, and the retail licensees served by such wholesale dealer or distributor for whom the taxes have not been paid shall be subject to having their license suspended or revoked as herein provided. (5) Unlawful retail sales. It shall be a violation of this article for any person to sell at retail within the city any spirituous liquors on which the taxes herein have not been paid. (6) Unlawful deliveries. It shall be unlawful and a violation of this article for any wholesale dealer or distributor, person, firm, or corporation to deliver any spirituous liquors to any retail dealer in the city without at the time of such delivery collecting the excise taxes herein provided for. (7) Violations and penalties. Any person violating any of the provisions of this article or who shall assist any retail dealer in spirituous liquors in the city to evade or avoid the payment of the taxes herein provided for shall be guilty of a violation of this subsection and on conviction thereof in the recorder's court shall be fined or sentenced as provided by this Code, and any such person so convicted shall also be subject to having his license suspended or revoked, if he shall be a licensed dealer in spirituous liquors at retail. (8) Additional remittance to city. In addition to all other taxes or license fees, retailers of distilled spirits and wines by the drink shall collect and remit to the city on a monthly basis three percent of the charge to the public for such beverages. (Ord. No. 771, § 1(4-122), 12-16-1997) Sec. 6-249. - Invoices. (a) Upon each and every delivery by a licensed wholesaler to a licensed retailer, an invoice in triplicate shall be prepared, showing the quantities and brands of spirituous liquors delivered, together with the price thereof and the excise tax due and collected thereon. The original of such invoice shall be delivered by the wholesaler to the retailer simultaneously with such delivery. The wholesaler shall retain the second copy of such invoice and shall keep it for a period of 12 months after the date of delivery, and during such 12-month period such invoices shall be made available for inspection by the mayor and council or their duly authorized representatives. A copy of such invoice shall be attached to any reports required by the city. (b) Each retail licensee doing business in the city shall keep and maintain the original invoice of each sale to him or purchased by him from a wholesaler of any spirituous liquors for at least 12 months after the date of such purchase and shall maintain records to show the sales of spirituous liquors and any other records required by the city. The city or its duly authorized representative shall have the right to inspect the records of each licensee and make a complete audit of the records of each licensee at any time. Failure of a licensee to properly maintain records showing receipt of spirituous liquors, payment therefor, and payment of the taxes due thereon to the appropriate wholesaler, and records which clearly show the sales, the amount of sales, and the types of sales of each licensee may, at the discretion of the mayor and council, after a hearing as herein provided, result in the revocation or suspension of such license. (Ord. No. 771, § 1(4-123), 12-16-1997)

Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Businesses, ch. 26.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Secs. 10-1—10-25. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - ADULT ENTERTAINMENT ESTABLISHMENTS
Sec. 10-26. - Findings; public purpose. (a) Based on the experience of other local governmental jurisdictions recognizing that the sale and/or consumption of alcoholic beverages in adult entertainment establishments produces increased criminal activity and deterioration of adjacent neighborhoods, the mayor and council of the city find that it is in the best interest of the health, welfare, safety and morals of the community to enact regulations to reduce the possible adverse impacts of adult entertainment establishments. However, the mayor and council also find that the outright prohibition of such establishments could improperly infringe upon protected forms of expression. Therefore, the purpose of this article is to reasonably regulate adult entertainment establishments in a manner that serves the legitimate governmental interest of reducing criminal activity and protecting property values without unreasonably infringing upon the protected rights of adult entertainment establishments and their patrons. (b) The mayor and council has again reviewed and considered problems that other communities have experienced as a result of adult entertainment establishments operating within those jurisdictions. Included in these materials were various studies conducted by local governments on the adult entertainment issue. Reviewed by the council were studies of Oklahoma City, Oklahoma; Houston, Texas; and a summary of land use studies by various municipalities including but not limited to Garden Grove, California; Tucson, Arizona; Seattle, Washington; and Indianapolis, Indiana. Also reviewed were a copy of a transcript of a hearing before the Peach County Commissioners held on May 7, 1996; the article "Regulation of Adult Entertainment in Georgia: Dancing in a Mine Field" by Susan S. Cole under date of June 14, 1996; a copy of the minutes of a meeting of the city council of the City of Fort Myers, Florida, on November 22, 1993; newspaper stories relating to establishments in or near Marietta, Georgia; and recent review and passage of an ordinance by the City of Thomasville, Georgia. After such review and a public hearing on the subject, each individual member of the council is of the opinion that this article is in the best interest of the citizens of the community in an effort to avoid harmful and secondary effects known to occur in and around these types of businesses. The mayor and council, in reaffirming this article, has no intention to infringe upon the rights of any citizens to freedom of speech or expression. (Code 1967, § 16-151; Ord. No. 644, § 1, 6-1-1993; Ord. No. 754, § 1, 6-17-1997) Sec. 10-27. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Adult entertainment means performances by topless and/or bottomless dancers, strippers or similar entertainers, where such performances are characterized by the display or exposure of specified anatomical areas. Adult entertainment establishment means a nightclub, cabaret, adult novelty store or other establishment which features adult entertainment. Any commercial establishment which has as its primary purpose or business the offer for sale of any book, publication, or film which depicts nudity, or sexual conduct or engages in services such as bathhouses, massage parlors, wrestling parlors or like activity including a nightclub, cabaret, lounge or other establishment which features adult entertainment. Adult novelty store means a type of adult entertainment establishment which has a significant or substantial portion, defined as 20 percent, of its stock-in-trade or derives a significant or substantial portion of its revenues or devotes a significant or substantial portion of its interior business or advertising to the sale, rental for any form of consideration, of any instruments, devices, or paraphernalia which are designed for use of, marketed primarily for stimulation of human genital organs or for sadomasochistic use or abuse of themselves or others. Alcoholic beverages includes all alcohol, distilled spirits, beer, malt beverage, wine or fortified wine as more specifically defined in section 6-1 of this Code. Business establishment means a business within the city where alcoholic beverages are offered for sale for consumption on the premises pursuant to a license issued by the city. Church means a building in which persons regularly assemble for religious worship intended primarily for purposes connected with such worship, or for propagating a particular form of religious belief. Good moral character. A person is of good moral character if that person has not been convicted of a crime involving moral turpitude or drug-related or alcohol-related felony or sex-related crime in the past five years. License means a license for the sale for consumption on the premises of alcoholic beverages issued by the city. Licensed day care center means a day care center licensed by the state and/or city that provides care, training, education, custody, treatment or supervision for children under 14 years of age, where such children are not related by blood, marriage or adoption to an owner or operator of the facility. Licensee means any person to whom a license for sale for consumption on the premises of alcoholic beverages has been issued by the city, including the officers and agents of the licensee. Live means any activity or entertainment which is carried on by actual living persons in the physical presence of the patrons. Live entertainment means entertainment for the benefit of patrons which is carried on in the actual physical presence of such patrons, including but not limited to dancing. Mainstream performance house means a theater, concert hall, auditorium or similar establishment which regularly features live performances such as plays or concerts which are not distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on the depiction, description or display or the featuring of specified anatomical areas or specified sexual activities and where such depiction, if any, is only incidental to the primary purpose of any performance. Minor means any person under 18 years of age. Operator means the manager or other person principally in charge of an adult entertainment establishment. Owner means, if a sole proprietorship, the proprietor; if a partnership, all partners (general and limited); if a corporation, all officers, directors and persons holding at least ten percent of the outstanding shares. Person means a human being. Premises means the definite closed or partitioned establishment, whether room, shop or building, wherein alcoholic beverages are sold or consumed, including the sidewalk serving area or outside, open air or patio type serving area on the private property of an establishment, as defined in this Code. Residential, pertaining to the use of land, means premises such as homes, townhomes, patio homes, mobile homes, duplexes, condominiums or apartment complexes, which contain habitable rooms for nontransient occupancy and which are designed primarily for living, sleeping, cooking and eating therein. School means a facility where persons regularly assemble for the purpose of instruction or education including any playgrounds, stadiums, or other structures and grounds used in conjunction therewith. This shall include but not be limited to public and private schools used for primary, secondary, or post-secondary education. Specified anatomical areas means any of the following: (1) Less than completely and opaquely covered human genitals or pubic region; cleft of the buttocks; or any portion of the female breast encompassed within an area falling below the horizontal line one would have to draw to intercept a point above the top of the areola, or any portion of the areola, or any simulation thereof. This definition shall include the entire lower portion of the human female breast, but shall not include any portion of the cleavage of the human female breast exhibited by a dress, blouse, shirt, leotard, bathing suit, or other wearing apparel, provided the areola is not so exposed. (2) Human male genitalia in a discernibly turgid state, even if completely and opaquely covered. Specified sexual activities means and includes any of the following: (1) The fondling or other erotic touching of human genitals, pubic region, buttocks, anus or female breasts; (2) Sex acts, normal or perverted, actual or simulated, inducing intercourse, oral copulation or sodomy; (3) Masturbation, actual or simulated; (4) The displaying of the male or female pubic hair, anus, vulva or genitals; or (5) Excretory functions as part of or in connection with any of the activities set forth in subsections (1) through (4) of this definition. (Code 1967, § 16-152; Ord. No. 644, § 2, 6-1-1993; Ord. No. 877, §§ 1, 2, 1-8-2002) Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. Sec. 10-28. - Conduct prohibited. (a) The following types of entertainment, attire and conduct are prohibited upon any premises licensed to sell, serve or dispense alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises or any other premises holding a business license from the city which allows consumption of alcoholic beverages on its premises within the city limits: (1) The employment or use of any person live, in any capacity, in the sale or service of alcoholic beverages or food while such person is unclothed or in such attire, costume or clothing as to expose any portion of his or her specified anatomical areas. (2) Live entertainment where any person appears unclothed or in such attire, costume or clothing as to expose any portion of his or her specified anatomical areas or where such person performs acts of specified sexual activities or acts which simulate specified sexual activity, as defined herein. (3) The holding, promoting, sponsoring or allowing of any contest, promotion, special night, event or any other activity where live patrons of the licensed establishment are encouraged or allowed to engage in any of the conduct proscribed in subsections (a)(1) and (2) of this section. (b) Nothing contained in this section shall apply to the premises of any mainstream performance house or museum which derives less than 20 percent of its gross annual income from the sale of alcoholic beverages. (Code 1967, § 16-153; Ord. No. 644, § 3, 6-1-1993) Sec. 10-29. - Penalties. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person to perform any acts prohibited in section 10-28, and any such conduct will be a violation of this Code and shall be punishable in the municipal court of the city as provided under section 1-9 of this Code. (b) It shall be unlawful for a licensee to permit any conduct prohibited in section 10-28 which he knows or has reasonable cause to know is taking place on the premises. Any such conduct by a licensee shall be a violation of this Code and shall be punishable in the municipal court of the city as provided under section 1-9 of this Code. Also, upon conviction, a licensee may have his license revoked or suspended as provided in section 10-42 of this article. (Code 1967, § 16-154; Ord. No. 644, § 4, 6-1-1993) Sec. 10-30. - License required. It shall be unlawful for any person, association, firm, partnership, or corporation to engage in, conduct or carry on, in or upon any premises within the city, an adult entertainment establishment without a valid adult entertainment license to do so. The issuance of such license shall not be deemed to authorize, condone, or make legal any activity or conduct that is illegal or unlawful under the laws of the state or the United States. The annual license fee for an adult entertainment establishment shall be $3,000.00. (Code 1967, § 16-155; Ord. No. 644, § 5, 6-1-1993) Cross reference— Business licensing generally, § 26-36 et seq. Sec. 10-31. - On-premises operator required. An adult entertainment establishment shall have a designated person to serve as an on-premises operator. The operator shall be principally in charge of the establishment and shall be located on the premises during operating hours. (Code 1967, § 16-156; Ord. No. 644, § 6, 6-1-1993) Sec. 10-32. - Employee permit required. It shall be unlawful for any person to be employed by an adult entertainment establishment without a permit issued under the terms of this article. For the purposes of this section, the term "employee" includes an "independent contractor." (Code 1967, § 16-157; Ord. No. 644, § 7, 6-1-1993) Sec. 10-33. - Admission of minors unlawful. (a) It shall be unlawful to allow a person younger than 18 years of age to enter an adult entertainment establishment. (b) It shall be the duty of the operator to ensure that an attendant is stationed at each public entrance to the establishment at all times during the establishment's operating hours. It shall be the duty of the attendants to not allow any person under the age of 18 years to enter the establishment. It shall be presumed that an attendant knew a person was under the age of 18 unless such attendant asked for and was furnished: (1) A valid operator's, commercial operator's or chauffeur's driver's license; or (2) A valid personal identification certificate issued by the state department of public safety reflecting that such person is 18 years of age or older. (Code 1967, § 16-158; Ord. No. 644, § 8, 6-1-1993) Sec. 10-34. - Location; development standards. (a) Premises for which an application is made for the licensing of an adult entertainment establishment at the time of the application and at the time the license is granted, if granted, shall be located only in a C-3 district as the same is now or hereafter delineated and defined by the zoning ordinances of the city. (b) No adult entertainment establishment shall be located within 1,000 feet of any of the following: (1) Any parcel of land which is zoned for residential uses or purposes. (2) Any parcel of land upon which a church, school, licensed day care center, governmental building simultaneously owned and occupied by such government, library, civic center, neighborhood public park or neighborhood playground is located. (3) Any parcel of land upon which another adult entertainment establishment is located. For purposes of this section, measurement of distances shall be from property line to property line along the shortest possible straight line, regardless of any customary or common route or path of travel (i.e., "as the crow flies"). The term "parcel of land" shall mean any quantity of land capable of being described by location and boundary, designated and used or to be used as a unit, and duly recorded in the county. (c) The minimum lot area for an adult entertainment establishment shall be one acre with a minimum 150 feet of road frontage on a public right-of-way. (d) Buildings and structures established in connection with an adult entertainment establishment shall be set back at least 40 feet from any property line. (e) A minimum of one parking space shall be provided for every 100 square feet of gross building area, or for every three customer seats, whichever is greater. (f) Merchandise or activities of the establishment shall not be visible from any point outside the establishment. (g) No signs of any kind, painted or electric, advertising adult entertainment shall be permitted on the exterior or in the window of any licensed premises. Signs on the exterior or in the window of licensed premises may show only the name of the licensee. (Code 1967, § 16-159; Ord. No. 644, § 9, 6-1-1993) Sec. 10-35. - Adult entertainment establishment employees. (a) Employees of an adult entertainment establishment shall not be less than 18 years of age. Every employee must be of good moral character as defined in this article. Any employee who is convicted of a sex-related crime, or drug-related or alcohol-related felony while employed as an adult entertainment establishment employee shall not thereafter be employed by any adult entertainment establishment licensed under this article for a period of five years from the date of such conviction, unless a longer time is ordered by a court of competent jurisdiction. The term "convicted" shall include an adjudication of guilt or a plea of guilty. The term "while employed as an adult entertainment establishment employee" shall include all work done or services performed while in the scope of employment elsewhere than on the licensed premises. (b) Before any person may be employed by an adult entertainment establishment, he or she shall file an application for an adult entertainment establishment employee permit with the city manager and receive approval. An investigation fee of $50.00 shall accompany the application. Each applicant shall provide a signed and notarized consent, on forms prescribed by the state crime information center, authorizing the release of the applicant's criminal records to the police department. The city shall have 15 days to investigate information contained in the application. If the prospective employee is found to be of good moral character, the city manager shall approve the permit and the prospective employee may begin working on the licensed premises. If approval is denied, the prospective employee may, within ten days of such denial, make appeal to the mayor and council of the city. (c) No patron, dancer, or other employee of an adult entertainment establishment shall, while on the premises of an adult entertainment establishment, commit the offense of public indecency as defined in O.C.G.A. § 16-6-8. For purposes of this section, the term "employee" shall include an independent contractor. (d) The employee permit of any employee who violates laws and regulations of the state or any provision of this article or any other ordinance or regulation of the city shall be subject to suspension or revocation. (e) For the purpose of this article, independent contractors shall be considered employees and shall be permitted as such, regardless of the business relationship with the owner or licensee of any adult entertainment establishment. (Code 1967, § 16-160; Ord. No. 644, § 10, 6-1-1993) Sec. 10-36. - Application for license generally. (a) Any person, association, firm, partnership or corporation desiring to obtain a license to operate, engage in, conduct or carry on any adult entertainment establishment shall make application to the city clerk, or designated representative. The application must be made in the name of the adult entertainment establishment and shall include the names of the operator and each owner as defined in this article. The application shall be accompanied by a nonrefundable fee, established from time to time by resolution of the city, to defray, in part, the cost of investigation and report required by this article. (b) The license application does not authorize the engaging in, operation of, conduct of or carrying on of any adult entertainment establishment. (Code 1967, § 16-161; Ord. No. 644, § 11, 6-1-1993) Sec. 10-37. - Contents of license application. Each application for an adult entertainment establishment license shall contain the following information and documentation: (1) The proposed establishment's name, street address and mailing address, if different, and telephone number. (2) The name and street address and mailing address, if different, of the owner. The name, street address and mailing address, if different, and Georgia driver's license number of the intended operator. (3) A general description of services and entertainment to be provided. (4) The legal description of the parcel of land on which the establishment is to be located. (5) The business, occupation and employment history of each owner and operator for five years immediately preceding the date of application. (6) If any owner or operator has had an adult entertainment establishment license or similar type of license denied, revoked or suspended, then the violation that led to the denial, suspension or revocation as well as the date and disposition of such, including any fine or sentence imposed, and whether or not the terms of the disposition have been completed.
