(e) It shall be the duty of the animal control officer, and any person under their employ, to impound the dog if: (1) The owner does not secure a certificate of registration in accordance with this article. (2) The owner does not secure liability insurance or meet the bond requirement of this article. (3) The owner does not keep the dog within a proper enclosure or permits the dog to roam or run free. (f) Any dog impounded under the provisions of this section shall be returned to the owner upon the owner's compliance with the provisions of this article and upon payment of reasonable impoundment cost, as fixed by a schedule approved by the governing authority, as from time to time amended. Notice of impoundment under this section shall be given the owner, in writing, by certified mail, at his last known address. This notice shall state that if the owner has not complied with the provisions of this article within 20 days from receipt of such notice, the dog shall be destroyed in an expeditious and humane manner; provided, however no dog shall have been destroyed under this section unless it has been held a full 20 days, exclusive of the date of giving notice. (g) The owner of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog shall be solely liable for any injury to or death of a person caused by such dog. Under no circumstances shall the city or any employee or official of the city which enforces or fails to enforce the provisions of this article be held liable for any damages to any person who suffers an injury inflicted by a dog that has been identified as being a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog or by a dog which the city has failed to identify as a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog or by a dog which has been identified as being a dangerous dog or a potentially dangerous dog but has not been kept or restrained in the manner described in this section or by a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog whose owner has not maintained insurance coverage or a surety bond as required in this section. (Code 1967, § 5-44.1; Ord. No. 746, § 5, 4-1-1997) Sec. 14-58. - Costs of maintaining dangerous animals in veterinary hospital; delivery of skull of slain animal to state department of health. All costs of maintaining any dangerous animal in a veterinary hospital shall be paid by the owner. In all cases where any animal which has bitten a person or caused an abrasion of the skin is slain by a police officer, or other authorized persons, whether by order of the court or otherwise, and a period of less than 15 days has elapsed since the day on which such animal bit any person or caused an abrasion of the skin of any person, it shall be the duty of the police officer, or other authorized person, slaying such animal to forthwith deliver intact the skull, containing the brain of such animal, to the laboratory of the state department of health. (Code 1967, § 5-45; Ord. No. 147, § 1(10), 4-2-1974; Ord. No. 381, § 14, 9-21-1982) Sec. 14-59. - General restraint requirements. (a) The owner of any animal shall keep such animal in a condition of restraint to prevent such animal from being at large. An animal is under restraint within the meaning of this section if it is: (1) Controlled by a leash; (2) On or within a vehicle being driven or parked on the streets, provided that the animal must be confined within any open vehicle by a leash; or (3) Confined within a suitable enclosure. (b) No animal shall be confined on the owner's premises by a leash of less than ten feet in length, except by a leash which is a free running line. The length of leash shall not be long enough to allow the animal to leave the premises of the owner. A free running line shall be one which is attached or is secured by a swivel or other device which will turn and remain free running when wrapped around some object. (Code 1967, § 5-46; Ord. No. 147, § 1(5), 4-2-1974; Ord. No. 381, § 15, 9-21-1982; Ord. No. 520, § 2, 3-17-1987; Ord. No. 874, § 1, 11-6-2001) Sec. 14-60. - Applicability of section 14-59. The provisions of section 14-59 shall not apply to dogs leading blind persons, or security dogs used in commercial establishments. (Code 1967, § 5-47; Ord. No. 147, § 1(6), 4-2-1974) Sec. 14-61. - Penalties for violations of section 14-59. (a) The owner of any animal which violates any provision of section 14-59 shall be fined a minimum of $50.00 for the first offense, shall be fined a minimum of $75.00 for the second offense and shall be fined $100.00 for the third offense. (b) Upon the fourth offense by any animal, the owner shall be required to permanently remove it from the city. (c) Upon failure of the owner to comply with the requirements of this section, the Humane Society shall take up the animal and destroy it. (d) The properly designated animal control person of the Humane Society is authorized to issue citations for a violation of this section returnable to the municipal court. (Code 1967, § 5-48; Ord. No. 147, § 1(7), 4-2-1974; Ord. No. 381, § 16, 9-21-1982; Ord. No. 520, §§ 3, 4, 3-17-1987; Ord. No. 639, § 1, 3-16-1993; Ord. No. 746, § 6, 4-1-1997; Ord. No. 780, § 1, 4-21-1998; Ord. No. 874, § 2, 11-6-2001) Charter reference— Authority to levy dog tax, § 93. State Law reference— Permitting livestock to run at large or stray, O.C.G.A. § 4-3-3; permitting dogs in heat to roam or run free, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-6; enclosures to confine dangerous dogs, O.C.G.A. §§ 4-8-25, 4-8-26; rabies inoculation, O.C.G.A. § 31-19-5. Sec. 14-62. - Other penalties. Penalties for violations of this article dealing with dangerous dogs and potentially dangerous dogs shall be as provided in O.C.G.A. § 4-8-28, except that violations which fall within the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 4-8-28(c) and (d) and shall be referred to the district attorney's office for handling rather than to the municipal court. (Ord. No. 780, § 2, 4-21-1998) Sec. 14-63. - Cleanup of dog feces. (a) Dog waste is offensive and can spread disease and parasites to other dogs and humans. This section is to promote the public health, safety and welfare by requiring any person owning, keeping, walking, in possession, custody or control of any dog to remove all feces deposited by such dog from public or private property. (b) It shall be unlawful for the owner or custodian of any dog to take it off its owner's property limits without the means to properly remove and dispose of the dog's feces from any public or private property. (c) It is the responsibility of a dog's owner or custodian to clean up the dog's feces from any public or private property outside of the dog's owner's property limits. Such property includes, but is not limited to, parks, rights-of-way, paths, and public access areas. (d) Means to properly remove and dispose of feces shall consist of having on or near one's person a device such as a plastic bag, or other suitable plastic or paper container, that can be used to fully clean up and contain dog waste until it can be disposed of in an appropriate container. Such a device must be shown, upon request, to anyone authorized to enforce this section. (e) This provision shall not apply to handicapped persons assisted by trained guide or assistance dogs. (f) Penalties. Any violation of this section shall constitute an infraction and shall be punishable by a fine of $50.00. (Ord. No. 2009-56, § 1, 5-5-2009)

div.head: Chapter 18 - AVIATION[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Charter reference— Airport zoning, § 110. Cross reference— Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 98.
Sec. 18-1. - Airspace safety zone adopted. It shall be unlawful for any person to erect, repair, or maintain any structure affecting the airspace safety zone and the glide angle as set forth in section 110 of the Charter of the city. Any person violating provisions of this section shall be punished as for a misdemeanor in the appropriate courts of the county. (Ord. of 6-19-1945, § 3; Code 1967, § 3-1)

div.head: Chapter 22 - BUILDINGS AND BUILDING REGULATIONS[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Charter reference— Regulation of building construction, § 26; condemnation, removal of buildings, § 27. Cross reference— Environment, ch. 46; fire prevention and protection, ch. 50; flood damage prevention regulations, ch. 54; health and sanitation, ch. 58; historic preservation, ch. 62; planning, ch. 86; solid waste management, ch. 94; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 98; utilities, ch. 110; vegetation, ch. 114; zoning, ch. 122.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 22-1. - Building code adopted by reference. The Standard Building Code, 1994 edition, with sections 102.2.1, 102.2.2, 102.2.3 and 102.2.4 deleted, a copy of which is on file in the office of the city manager, shall be and the same is hereby adopted as the building code of the city. (Ord. of 10-20-1959, § 1; Code 1967, § 6-1; Ord. No. 8-1968, § 1, 10-1-1968; Ord. No. 6-1970, § 1, 5-5-1970; Ord. No. 16-1972, § 1, 11-7-1972; Ord. No. 3-1973, § 1, 2-20-1973; Ord. No. 223, § 1, 6-15-1976; Ord. No. 265, § 1, 1-3-1978; Ord. No. 293, § 1, 2-20-1979; Ord. No. 362, § 1, 10-20-1981; Ord. No. 384, § 1, 11-2-1982; Ord. No. 478, § 1, 11-19-1985; Ord. No. 487, § 1, 3-18-1986; Ord. No. 556, § 1, 9-5-1988; Ord. No. 570, § 1, 4-18-1989; Ord. No. 600, § 1, 7-17-1990; Ord. No. 618, § 1, 9-17-1991; Ord. No. 741, § 1, 2-4-1997) Sec. 22-2. - Mechanical code adopted by reference. The Standard Mechanical Code, 1991 edition, a copy of which is on file in the office of the city manager, shall be and the same is hereby adopted as the mechanical code of the city. (Code 1967, § 6-2; Ord. No. 130, § 1, 12-4-1973; Ord. No. 219, § 1, 6-15-1976; Ord. No. 267, § 1, 1-7-1978; Ord. No. 293, § 2, 2-20-1979; Ord. No. 362, § 2, 10-20-1981; Ord. No. 384, § 2, 11-2-1982; Ord. No. 478, § 2, 11-19-1985; Ord. No. 487, § 2, 3-18-1986; Ord. No. 556, § 2, 9-5-1988; Ord. No. 570, § 2, 4-18-1989; Ord. No. 600, § 2, 7-17-1990; Ord. No. 618, § 2, 9-17-1991) Sec. 22-3. - Fire limits. The fire limits of the city shall be all that portion of the city embraced in the following boundaries, to wit: Third Avenue on the north, Fifth Avenue on the south, Second Street on the west and Third Street on the east, and the extension of the said streets and avenues or said streets and avenues as if extended. (Code 1935, § 70(a); Code 1967, § 6-3) Charter reference— Authority to lay out fire district, § 26. Cross reference— Fire prevention and protection, ch. 50. Sec. 22-4. - Cleanup bond in the demolition or removal of structures. Any person, firm or corporation desiring to obtain a permit to demolish or remove a structure from property within the city limits shall first post with the building inspector a cash bond in the amount of $100.00 to insure that the property on which such structure is demolished or removed will be cleaned of all debris and trash. In the event the property is cleaned of all debris and trash within a reasonable time to the satisfaction of the building inspector, said bond of $100.00 will be returned to the person posting it. In the event such is not done within a reasonable time after the structure is demolished or removed, the city will clean the lot of trash and debris and shall use such part or all of said bond as may be necessary to clean the property. Now in such event, the remaining potion of said bond, if any, shall be forfeited to the city for failure to carry out this condition for the issuing of the permit. (Code 1967, § 6-4; Ord. No. 133, § 1, 12-7-1973) Sec. 22-5. - Standard excavation and grading code adopted by reference. The Southern Standard Excavation and Grading Code, 1975 edition, a copy of which is on file in the office of the city manager, shall be and the same is hereby adopted as the excavation and grading code of the city. (Code 1967, § 6-5; Ord. No. 235, § 1, 12-7-1976; Ord. No. 478, § 3, 11-19-1985; Ord. No. 622, § 1, 10-21-1991) Sec. 22-6. - Swimming pool code adopted by reference. The Standard Swimming Pool Code, 1991 edition, a copy of which is on file in the office of the city manager, shall be and the same is hereby adopted as the swimming pool code of the city. No. 293, § 6, 2-20-1979; Ord. No. 362, § 9, 10-20-1981; Ord. No. 384, § 10, 11-12-1982; Ord. No. 556, § 7, 9-5-1988; Ord. No. 570, § 7, 4-18-1989; Ord. No. 600, § 6, 7-17-1990; Ord. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Certified gasfitter means a gasfitter who is the holder of an unsuspended and unrevoked certificate of competency for the current license year. Gas appliance means a fixture or apparatus manufactured and designed to use natural, manufactured, or any gas as a fuel medium for developing light, heat, or power, and shall include ranges, gas refrigerators, hot plates, space heaters, water heaters, steam and hot water boilers, ovens, furnaces, together with any accessory designed to be attached to any gas appliance, such as solid tops, pilot lights, governors, regulators, and safety devices; provided, however, that nothing herein contained shall be construed to apply to tubing, appliances, appurtenances, or devices used for strictly experimental or scientific purposes. Gasfitter means a person who represents himself as competent and qualified, and undertakes to construct, alter or make additions or who for himself or for any person or firm or corporation undertakes to and does construct, alter or make any addition to a system of gas piping, venting and installation of all gas equipment, appurtenances and appliances together with safety and other controls of same. (Ord. of 7-5-1955, § 12; Code 1967, § 21-35) Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. Sec. 22-184. - Installations outside city. Any person having property, premises or buildings not within the corporate limits but within the gas service territory of the city who desires or is required by law to use or connect with any gas main serving the city shall conform to this code and the laws and ordinances of the city regulating the installation of gas fittings, the securing of permits for, and the inspection of same, and shall abide by the gas regulations of the city. (Ord. of 7-5-1955, § 2; Code 1967, § 21-36) Sec. 22-185. - Gas inspector's appointment. The city manager shall appoint a competent person as gas inspector. (Ord. of 7-5-1955, § 1(1); Code 1967, § 21-37) Sec. 22-186. - Powers and duties of gas inspector. (a) The gas inspector and his assistants are hereby authorized, empowered and directed to inspect and supervise the installation, construction, reconstruction, and repair of all gas piping, gas appliances, fixtures and apparatus now or hereafter to be placed in or in any manner directly attached to any building or structure within the city and its gas service territory. The gas inspector and his assistants shall be subject to the orders and directions of the city manager, and they are hereby vested with full authority to enter any building or premises at any reasonable time in the discharge of their duties herein imposed. (b) It shall be the duty of the inspector to receive all applications for connection, to pass on and approve or reject plans submitted, to sign and issue all notices and to keep a daily record of all applications received, plans approved and all other matters which may pertain thereto and to make a monthly report of his operations. (c) It shall also be the duty of the inspector to investigate all alleged violations of the provisions of this article and to file complaints when necessary. (d) The gas inspector shall decide all controversies which may arise under this article, and in so doing shall be subject to the control and direction of the city manager. (Ord. of 7-5-1955, §§ 1(2), (3), (7), 11; Code 1967, § 21-38) Sec. 22-187. - Inspections. The gas inspector shall inspect as often as necessary all houses in the course of erection, alteration or repair and to inspect any installation of any character already in use which he may have reason to believe is out of repair or is imperfect. (Ord. of 7-5-1955, § 1(4); Code 1967, § 21-39) Sec. 22-188. - Notice of defects; enforcement of compliance. The inspector shall give the owner or agent in charge of any building written notice of any defects in his installation or fixtures or changes or repairs necessary, and such owner or agent shall immediately after such notice make necessary changes and/or repairs. If the owner or agent fails to comply with this notice, the gas inspector may order the gas service department to turn off the gas and it shall not thereafter turn the gas on again until the gas inspector has certified that such defects have been repaired or removed. (Ord. of 7-5-1955, § 1(5); Code 1967, § 21-40) Sec. 22-189. - Certificate of inspection prerequisite to turning on gas. The gas inspector shall furnish the gas service department with a copy of each certificate of inspection. Said department shall not turn gas into any new, altered or repaired system of gas until certificate has been received. (Ord. of 7-5-1955, § 1(6); Code 1967, § 21-41) Sec. 22-190. - Permit required. No person shall connect or cause to be connected any gas piping or appliance with any gas main or private connection without having first filed a written application as hereinafter set forth and having obtained written permit for such work as set out herein. A separate permit must be obtained for such work on each house and for each separate piece of work of any description, including alterations and general repairs. (Ord. of 7-5-1955, § 6(1); Code 1967, § 21-42) Sec. 22-191. - Permit fees. A permit fee for the installation, construction, reconstruction, or repair for any gas piping shall be charged pursuant to a service fee schedule and in such amount as currently or hereafter set by resolution of the city. (Ord. of 7-5-1955, § 6(2); Code 1967, § 21-43; Ord. No. 2014-154, § 1, 10-7-2014) Sec. 22-192. - Plans and specifications. Before issuing a permit, suitable plans and specifications of work proposed to be done, showing clearly the sizes of pipe, kind of fittings, locations and measurements, will be made out on blanks furnished by the city clerk and properly signed by the owner, his agent, or other authorized representative, and filed at the office of the clerk. All connections and fixtures shall be neatly drawn in the following manner: In case of new work or extension of old work, black ink shall be used. In case of old work, red ink shall be used. (Ord. of 7-5-1955, § 6(3); Code 1967, § 21-44) Sec. 22-193. - Issuance of permit by clerk; subsequent changes; infractions. If the plans are approved by the inspector, the clerk will issue a written permit within two days after the application is filed; no change or modification of approved plans will be permitted unless such change or modification is authorized by the owner or agent, submitted to and approved by the inspector and placed on file as in the case of original work. Further, no variation of rules not specially authorized in writing by the inspector, although it may be shown on plan and has passed inspection, will be permitted. The inspector always reserves the right to compel the fitter to rectify any variation of the rules even though the work has passed inspection and a final inspection certificate issued. The fitter's bond will be held for same. (Ord. of 7-5-1955, § 6(4); Code 1967, § 21-45) Sec. 22-194. - Expiration of permits. All permits are good for a continuous performance of work named therein. Permits shall expire when work ceases for a period of 90 days, without good and reasonable cause for same, but will automatically expire upon completion of work for which it was issued. (Ord. of 7-5-1955, § 6(5); Code 1967, § 21-46) Sec. 22-195. - License; bond. (a) Occupational license. Every person, before entering upon the installation, construction, reconstruction or repair of any piping in the city's system and its gas service territory, shall be required to obtain a gasfitter's license. The city clerk shall refuse to issue a license to any person to engage in the business of gas installation and construction, unless such person holds a valid unrevoked and unsuspended certificate of competency, or has in his regular employ a person who holds such certificate. The clerk shall also refuse to any partnership a license to engage in such business unless said partnership shall have in its regular employ or as a member a person who holds such certificate. The clerk shall also refuse to issue a license to any corporation which has not in its regular employ a person who holds a certificate. Every such license shall stand suspended during any period in which the conditions requisite to issuance of a license do not pertain. Such license shall be conspicuously displayed at the holder's place of business. (b) Bond. Before said license is issued the party applying for same shall deposit with the clerk a bond in the principal sum of $2,500.00 executed by a solvent surety company, with an agent in the city, conditioned that the principal shall faithfully comply with the terms of this article and shall indemnify and hold harmless the city and all persons interested, against all costs, expenses, damage and injury sustained by the negligence of such principal, his agents, servants and employees, or his failure to comply ethically with the terms of this article in doing work made the subject matter hereof, and otherwise to be in the form and executed as required by the mayor and council. Upon approval of any such bond by the mayor and council, the clerk shall forthwith issue to the principal therein a license which shall remain in force only so long as said principal's bond is effective. Such bond shall be renewed annually on February 1 of each year as a prerequisite to the issuance of a license for said year. (c) Application to nonresidents. The requirements of bond and license shall apply to all persons, resident or nonresident, of the city, when doing work in the city. Provided, however, any person doing work outside of the city in its gas service territory shall be issued a permit to do such work in lieu of a license, upon the payment of a fee of $5.00 therefor but in no event shall the requirements of examination and bond be suspended. (Ord. of 7-5-1955, § 4; Code 1967, § 21-47) Sec. 22-196. - Licensed fitter to do work. No permit shall be issued for the installation, construction, reconstruction, or repair of any piping except to a licensed gasfitter or a person licensed to do such work in accordance with the provisions of this article. (Ord. of 7-5-1955, § 6(2); Code 1967, § 21-48) Sec. 22-197. - Connections with gas system to be made by city employees only. No one except the city, its agents or employees shall at any time turn on any valve or cock or in any way tamper or make any connection with any gas main, meter connection or gas service pipe between the main and the meter. User, however, may turn off gas at the main jet in case of an emergency. (Ord. of 7-5-1955, § 1(8); Code 1967, § 21-49) Sec. 22-198. - Property owner's responsibility. No property owner shall cause or permit any installation, construction, reconstruction or repair of any gas piping in the city and its gas service territory, before the persons doing the work shall have first obtained a permit from the clerk, and the mere fact that said work has been done will be considered sufficient to hold and render said property owner amenable to this rule. (Ord. of 7-5-1955, § 5; Code 1967, § 21-50) Sec. 22-199. - Inspection; testing; certificate of inspection. (a) When gas piping has been installed in a building or structure, whether the same be new construction, repairs or extensions, the same must be inspected and tested in the presence of the gas inspector or one of his assistants and a certificate of inspection issued as herein provided and an inspection tag attached to such piping by said inspector. Such tests shall conform to Southern Standard Gas Code, section 210. (b) No fire test or water test shall be permitted on any gas piping, and water tested piping will be condemned as faulty. (c) When the system of piping and all extensions thereto have been completed and all openings firmly closed, the person installing such piping shall make the test above provided, and if the piping is found tight, shall make application for test to the gas inspector. Upon such application, the inspector or one of his assistants will inspect the piping and shall witness the test, and if the piping is found tight and the work done is in accordance with the provisions of this article, then the inspector or assistant shall issue and deliver a certificate in substantially the following form: No. ____________ This is to certify that I have inspected and witnessed the test of the gas piping in ____________ Building No. ____________ , ____________ Street and certify that the same is installed in compliance with the City of Moultrie rules and regulations.
(d) Any additional gas piping or outlets installed, after the above certificate has been issued, must be reported for inspection and tested in the same manner as pipe originally installed. (Ord. of 7-5-1955, § 9; Code 1967, § 21-51) Sec. 22-200. - Meter location. The piping shall be extended to the meter location designated by the distributor of gas and a swing joint provided for connecting piping to the meter outlet. No gas meter shall be installed or maintained under the floor of any building or structure. (Ord. of 7-5-1955, § 10; Code 1967, § 21-52) Secs. 22-201—22-225. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - GASFITTER'S CERTIFICATE OF COMPETENCY[7]
Footnotes: --- (7) --- Cross reference— Businesses, ch. 26.
Sec. 22-226. - Plumbing examiners board designated gasfitters examining board. The board of plumbing examiners, composed of five members provided for by section 22-151, in addition to its duties as a plumbers examining board, is hereby constituted a gasfitter's examining board. The gas inspector shall be an ex official member of this board. (Ord. of 7-5-1955, § 3(1); Code 1967, § 21-63) Editor's note— It should be noted that Ord. No. 441, enacted Sept. 18, 1984 repealed section 22-151, which section provided for the board of plumbing examiners. For current provisions relative to licensing of plumbers, see section 22-151. Cross reference— Boards, commissions and committees, § 2-266 et seq. Sec. 22-227. - Examination; fee; certificate of competency. It shall be the duty of the gasfitter's examining board to examine and pass upon the qualifications of every person who may apply for a gasfitter's certificate of competency, to do work in the city or its gas service territory, upon forms provided by the city, and who shall have paid to the city clerk an examination fee of $5.00. Such applicant shall be examined upon the fundamentals of gasfitting, the laws of the city pertaining to gas installation, the theory and practice of gas installation and construction, and the experience and ability of the applicant in practical gas installation, and if such applicant be found to possess an accurate knowledge of the fundamentals of gasfitting, a practical working knowledge of the theory and correct practice of gas installation and construction, a thorough knowledge of the laws of the city relating to gas installation and construction, and sufficient experience and ability in gas installation and construction to safely and competently apply his knowledge in practice, the board shall issue to him a certificate of competency. (Ord. of 7-5-1955, § 3(2); Code 1967, § 21-64) Sec. 22-228. - Subsequent examination after failure. If an applicant fails to pass the examination, at least six months must elapse before he will be permitted to take it again. (Ord. of 7-5-1955, § 3(10); Code 1967, § 21-65) Sec. 22-229. - Record book to be kept. The gasfitter's examining board shall keep in the office of the city clerk a book in which shall be recorded the names and addresses of each applicant for a certificate, the date of filing of application, the final action of the board upon each application, the date of such action, date and action of the board in revocation or suspension proceedings, and the signature of the members of the board participating in any action. (Ord. of 7-5-1955, § 3(10); Code 1967, § 21-66) Sec. 22-230. - Revocation; suspension. The gasfitter's examining board shall have power to revoke any certificate if, after fair hearing, it is found that actual practice under such certificate has demonstrated to the satisfaction of the board that the holder thereof does not possess the qualifications necessary for issuance of a certificate after examination as provided hereinabove, and no revoked certificate shall be reinstated within 30 days, or without examination. The board shall have the power to suspend any certificate for a definite period not exceeding 60 days if, after fair hearing, it determines that the holder has been guilty of any violation of the laws of the city relating to gas installation and construction, or of any clearly incompetent or neglectful workmanship. (Ord. of 7-5-1955, § 3(8); Code 1967, § 21-67) Sec. 22-231. - Appeals. Any person feeling aggrieved by action of the gasfitter's examining board in refusing to grant certificate of competency, or in revoking or suspending a certificate already issued, may appeal to the city council. Such appeal shall be taken within ten days from the date of the action complained of by filing with the board; said board shall forthwith transmit to the city council, over the signature of the chairman of the board, all of the papers constituting the record upon which the action appealed from was taken. (Ord. of 7-5-1955, § 3(9); Code 1967, § 21-68) Sec. 22-232. - No charge for initial certificate. When any applicant for a gasfitter's certificate of competency passes the examination, his first year's certificate of competency shall be issued to him by the board without charge. (Ord. of 7-5-1955, § 3(4); Code 1967, § 21-69) Sec. 22-233. - Duplicate; fee. Each duplicate certificate issued by the city clerk for one lost, stolen, or otherwise not in the person's possession shall cost $1.00. (Ord. of 7-5-1955, § 3(7); Code 1967, § 21-70) Sec. 22-234. - Expiration date. All certificates of competency, registration certificates, and licenses shall expire on January 31 next succeeding the date of issue, and no reduction shall be made for any part of the year elapsed. (Ord. of 7-5-1955, § 3(6); Code 1967, § 21-71) Sec. 22-235. - Renewal; fee. Each certificate of competency, whether original or renewal, shall be issued for only the license year in which issued and dated, and shall be of no force or effect in any subsequent license year. Any holder of an unrevoked or unsuspended certificate for any particular license year, whether original or renewal, shall be entitled to a renewal certificate without examination for the next succeeding license year upon payment of a renewal fee of $2.00 to the city clerk, provided such holder shall have been actively engaged in the business of gasfitting for not less than three months within a period of one year next preceding application for such renewal certificate. (Ord. of 7-5-1955, § 3(3); Code 1967, § 21-72) Sec. 22-236. - Transferability. No gasfitter's certificate of competency under the provisions of this division shall be transferable or assignable. (Ord. of 7-5-1955, § 3(5); Code 1967, § 21-73) Secs. 22-237—22-265. - Reserved. DIVISION 3. - LIQUEFIED PETROLEUM GAS
Sec. 22-266. - Installation. (a) Permit required. It shall be unlawful to make any installation for service of any liquefied petroleum gas until a permit is secured from the city manager or such inspector as he may appoint for such purpose. (b) Application; fee. The applicant for any installation shall make written request to the city manager for a permit, which request shall state the proposed location of the installation, and shall be accompanied by a sketch of the proposed installation and a fee of $5.00 to cover inspection costs. In the event said permit is not granted the fee shall be returned to the applicant. (c) Conformance with code; approval. Each installation shall conform to the "Standard for Handling and Installation of Liquefied Petroleum Gas" of the National Board of Fire Underwriters, which code is made a part of this division, and no connection of any equipment for the furnishing of any such gas to any consumer in the city shall be made until such installation and equipment is approved in writing by the city inspector. (d) Measuring quantity. Each installation shall be equipped with an accurate and appropriate measuring device (meter or gage, depending upon the type of system) so as to enable the inspector and the consumer to clearly determine the amount of pressure or quantity of material being received. Cylinders may be weighed in lieu of providing such measuring devices, when such weighing will determine the quantity of material being received. (Ord. of 2-21-1939, § 2; Ord. of 5-16-1939, § 2; Code 1967, § 21-79) Sec. 22-267. - Occupational license, bond required. It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, or corporation to carry on the business of installing or selling any liquefied petroleum gases in the city without first having received a license from the city to carry on such business, and without also having filed with the clerk of the city a surety bond executed by a surety company authorized to do business in the state, in the penal sum of $1,000.00, payable to the city for the use and benefit of the city and of all persons whom the principal in the said bond shall serve in the city, conditioned for the faithful performance of all contracts entered into by said principal for the installation of equipment and/or for the furnishing of gas service in said city, and for the compliance with the ordinances of said city. (Ord. of 2-21-1939, § 3; Code 1967, § 21-80) Cross reference— Business licensing generally, § 26-36 et seq. Sec. 22-268. - Containers, tanks. It shall be unlawful for any person to keep, store or use bottled gas including propane, butane, propylene, butylene, or any other liquefied hydrocarbon gas or any mixture of such gases, within the city, unless the same shall be contained in tanks, receptacles, or other equipment bearing thereon the approval of the National Board of Fire Underwriters and/or conforming to the National Board of Fire Underwriters Pamphlet No. 58. (Ord. of 2-21-1939, § 1; Ord. of 5-16-1939, § 1; Code 1967, § 21-81) Secs. 22-269—22-295. - Reserved. ARTICLE VI. - HOUSING CODE
Sec. 22-296. - Adopted by reference. The Standard Housing Code, 1991 edition, a copy of which is on file in the office of the city manager, shall be and the same is hereby adopted as the housing code of the city. (Code 1967, § 14-1; Ord. No. 8-1970, § 1, 5-5-1970; Ord. No. 221, § 1, 6-15-1976; Ord. No. 234, § 1, 12-7-1976; Ord. No. 267, § 3, 1-17-1978; Ord. No. 293, § 4, 2-20-1979; Ord. No. 478, § 7, 11-19-1985; Ord. No. 556, § 5, 9-5-1988; Ord. No. 570, § 4, 4-18-1989; Ord. No. 622, § 4, 10-21-1991) Sec. 22-297. - One- and two-family dwelling code adopted by reference. The CABO One and Two Family Dwelling Code, 1989 edition, with the 1990 revisions, a copy of which is on file in the office of the city manager, shall be and the same is hereby adopted as the one- and two-family dwelling code for the city. (Code 1967, § 14-2; Ord. No. 600, § 3, 7-17-1990) Secs. 22-298—22-325. - Reserved. ARTICLE VII. - SUBDIVISIONS
Sec. 22-326. - Subdivisions. That certain document entitled City of Moultrie Land Subdivision Regulations, August 4, 2009 Edition, a copy of which is on file in the office of the city manager, is designated and same is hereby adopted and shall be known as the Land Subdivision Regulations of the City of Moultrie, regulating and governing the subdivision and re-subdivision of land within the corporate limits and for all other lawful purposes. Same are hereby referred to, adopted and made a part hereof, as if fully set out in this article with such additions, insertions, deletions and changes, as may hereafter be set forth. (Ord. No. 2008-47, § 1, 8-5-2008; Ord. No. 2009-62, § 1, 8-4-2009)

div.head: Chapter 26 - BUSINESSES[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Alcoholic beverages, ch. 6; amusements and entertainments, ch. 10; licensing of plumber, § 22-151 et seq.; gas fitter certificate competency, § 22-226 et seq.; emergency services, ch. 42; peddlers and solicitors, ch. 82; secondhand goods, ch. 90; commercial garbage and recyclables, § 94-66 et seq.; residential and commercial yard trimmings, § 94-96 et seq.; residential and commercial rates for solid waste, § 94-126 et seq.; taxation, ch. 102; wreckers, § 106-181 et seq.; utilities, ch. 110; vehicles for hire, ch. 118.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 26-1. - Engaging in prohibited business declared unlawful. It shall be unlawful for any person, company or corporation to engage in the city in any business or vocation prohibited by this chapter. (Code 1967, § 16-1.1; Ord. No. 1-1969, § 3, 1-7-1969; Ord. No. 104, § 1.1, 1-16-1973) Sec. 26-2. - Exemption for growers of farm products. No fruit or produce trucks are allowed on streets of the city. All dealers or traders must have a fixed place of business on private property. Vendors or peddlers of perishable farm products and of grove and orchard, bona fide engaged in selling such of said products as are actually produced by themselves shall be exempt from payment of license tax; but the duty of establishing the fact for said exemption shall in the first instance be upon the applicant for said exemption, to be complied with by first filing with the city clerk an affidavit setting forth said facts in detail. (Code 1967, § 16-11; Ord. No. 1-1969, § 1, 1-7-1969; Ord. No. 104, § 11, 1-16-1973) State Law reference— Disabled veterans and blind persons engaging in peddling, operating businesses or practicing professions, O.C.G.A. § 43-12-1 et seq. Sec. 26-3. - Use of streets for sale of merchandise prohibited; exceptions. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person to exhibit, display, or offer for sale, on the street or sidewalks within the corporate limits of the city, any goods, wares, or merchandise, or to solicit the purchase of any goods, wares, or merchandise so displayed, or to sell any such goods, wares, or merchandise. (b) The provisions of this section shall not apply within the special district created by section 24.1 of the Charter to business located therein provided as follows: (1) Business may exhibit, display, and offer for sale on the sidewalks immediately adjacent to the business such goods, wares, products, and merchandise normally sold by said business on the first and third weekends of each month, provided such is done in a fashion that will not block the flow of pedestrian traffic and in conformity with policies and procedures as currently or hereafter exist pursuant to resolution of the city. (2) Businesses may exhibit, display, and offer for sale on the sidewalks immediately adjacent to the business such goods, wares, products, and merchandise normally sold by said business on such dates and times and during such special events and holidays designated as such pursuant to resolution of the city provided such is done in a fashion that will not block the flow of pedestrian traffic and in conformity with policies and procedures as currently or hereafter exist pursuant to resolution of the city. (3) When the streets are closed to vehicular traffic businesses may exhibit, display, and offer for sale on the streets and sidewalks immediately adjacent to the business such goods, wares, products, and merchandise normally sold by said business on such dates and times and during such special events and holidays designated as such pursuant to resolution of the city provided such is done in a fashion that will not block the flow of pedestrian traffic and complies with directions from the city police department and complies with policies and procedures as currently or hereafter exist pursuant to resolution of the city. (Ord. of 2-20-1940, §§ 1—5; Code 1967, § 16-24; Ord. No. 118, § 1, 9-18-1973; Ord. No. 193, § 1, 4-15-1975; Ord. No. 251, § 1, 6-21-1977; Ord. No. 808, § 1, 5-18-1999; Ord. No. 2014-157, § 1, 10-21-2014) Annotations— Ordinance with its general application to the sale of all articles without any discrimination, and its limited scope as to territory and time, is not unreasonable, but is a valid regulation under the police power for public safety and convenience. Ferguson, et al. v. City of Moultrie, 71 Ga. App. 15; 29 SE2d 786 (1944); also Jones, et al. v. City of Moultrie, 196 Ga. 526; 27 SE2d 39 (1943); 71 Ga. App. 16; 29 SE2d 788 (1944). However, Jehovah's Witness would not be guilty of violation if evidence showed the distribution of religious literature did not interfere with traffic, safety and convenience of public, Jones v. City of Moultrie, 72 Ga. App. 282; 33 SE2d 561 (1945). Sec. 26-4. - Bond and permit for circus, carnival. (a) Before any license is issued for a circus, carnival, or similar performance, the applicant shall deposit with the city clerk and treasurer of the city cash or a suitable bond in the amount of $500.00 in addition to the regular license fee, for the purpose of protecting the city against any damage to city property. (b) The deposit shall be made upon the condition that the applicant will clean up all litter caused by the applicant so that the premises will be left in approximately the same condition as they were prior to being used by applicant. All markings on poles and trees made by applicant shall be removed. (c) In the event applicant complies with all these conditions, the money will be refunded. In the event applicant fails to comply with the conditions, the city may cause the necessary work and improvements to be made, paying the expenses thereof out of the deposit. The balance, if any, will be refunded to applicant. (d) Before the city shall issue a license for a circus, carnival or similar performance, the applicant shall obtain a permit from the county Humane Society. (Code 1967, § 16-25; Ord. No. 1-1969, § 1, 1-7-1969; Ord. No. 135, § 1, 11-20-1973; Ord. No. 521, § 1, 4-7-1987) Sec. 26-5. - Permit for loudspeaker. No person shall use a loudspeaker for any purpose outside of any building within the city without getting a permit from the city to be granted in the same manner business licenses are granted, and no permit for the use of such loudspeakers outside of any building in the city shall be granted except for public announcements and amusements in the public interest limited to public occasions held in the public interest, the governing authorities of said city are to determine the question of granting such permit. (Ord. of 6-19-1951, § 2; Code 1967, § 16-26) Sec. 26-6. - Penalties for violation of chapter. Any person, firm or corporation violating the terms of this chapter shall be punished in accordance with section 3 of the city Charter and section 1-9 of the Code of Ordinances. (Code 1967, § 16-14; Ord. No. 1-1969, § 9, 1-7-1969; Ord. No. 104, § 14, 1-16-1978) Secs. 26-7—26-35. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - LICENSING[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- Cross reference— Licensing of alcoholic beverages, § 6-31 et seq.; license for adult entertainment establishments, § 10-30; license for pool and billiard parlors, § 10-77; occupational license for plumbers, § 22-151 et seq.; occupational license for liquefied petroleum gas, § 22-267; license for auctions, § 26-76; insurers license, § 26-191 et seq.; taxation, ch. 102.
Sec. 26-36. - Registration, payment of tax prerequisite to engaging in business. It shall be unlawful for any person, company or corporation to engage in any business, calling, vocation, or profession in the city on which a license or occupation tax is required by said city, without first registering with the city manager of the city the name, business or calling, vocation or profession and paying the license or tax prescribed for same. Written applications must be filed with the city manager's office on forms provided for that purpose. (Code 1967, § 16-1; Ord. No. 1-1969, § 4, 1-7-1969; Ord. No. 104, § 1, 1-16-1973) Annotation— License tax on dairies with more than six cows, who deliver milk or cream in city was taxed for revenue purposes and not regulatory. Rossman v. City of Moultrie, 189 Ga. 681; 7 SE2d 270 (1940). State Law reference— Specific, business, and occupation taxes, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-1 et seq. Sec. 26-37. - Separate licenses for each business, location. Each person applying for license shall make an oath that the business to be followed by applicant falls in the class to which the section fixing the tax specially applies. The licenses hereinafter enumerated are imposed upon each separate business and each separate place of business, and apply to that particular business and do not include any other business for which a special license is required. (Code 1967, § 16-2; Ord. No. 1-1969, § 7, 1-7-1969; Ord. No. 104, § 2, 1-16-1973) Sec. 26-38. - Transfer of licenses. Occupational tax certificates and licenses, except those for the sale of alcoholic beverages, may be transferred one time as to person or as to location by returning the license for appropriate transfer and reissue and paying a fee of $40.00. (Code 1967, § 16-3; Ord. No. 1-1969, § 7, 1-7-1969; Ord. No. 13-1970, § 1, 8-4-1970; Ord. No. 104, § 3, 1-16-1973; Ord. No. 686, § 1, 12-20-1994; Ord. No. 710, § 1, 12-5-1995; Ord. No. 2013-138, § 1, 12-17-2013) Sec. 26-39. - Purchase of occupational license; proration. Any person, company, or corporation, except such person or company who is on February 1 of any year engaged in any business or occupation on which a special tax, regulatory fee or license is required by this chapter, or who shall commence a business or occupation after February 1 of any year, but prior to July 1, of that year shall purchase an occupational license for the entire year. On or after July 1 of any year any person, company or corporation making application for an occupation license may secure a one-half-year license, by paying one-half of the fee hereinafter prescribed, which license shall be good for the remainder of the license year in which it is purchased. (Code 1967, § 16-4; Ord. No. 1-1969, § 5, 1-7-1969; Ord. No. 104, § 4, 1-16-1973; Ord. No. 2013-138, § 2, 12-17-2013) Sec. 26-40. - Due date; penalty; interest. (a) All occupational taxes, regulatory fees, contractors' registrations, and licensing accounts are due on or before February 1 of each year. Any and all accounts not paid in full within 45 days of February 1 shall be deemed delinquent and a penalty of ten percent of the total amount due shall be added thereto; and, (b) In addition to the penalty imposed by section 26-40(a) the unpaid tax shall accrue interest at the rate of 1.5 percent interest per month until paid in full. (c) In the event an entity fails or refuses to pay any amounts due for occupational taxes, regulatory fees, contractors' registrations, and licensing accounts, including penalties and interest pursuant to section 26-40 herein, execution shall enter against the delinquent payor returnable in the Moultrie Municipal Court and there shall be imposed a civil fine that shall not exceed $500.00 and may be enforced by the contempt power of said court. (Code 1967, § 16-5; Ord. No. 1-1969, § 6, 1-7-1969; Ord. No. 104, § 5, 1-16-1973; Ord. No. 2013-138, § 3, 12-17-2013; Ord. No. 2017-184, § 1, 4-18-2017) Sec. 26-41. - Execution for collection. For all special and license taxes there shall be included the tax on insurance and bond premiums by the city clerk, and upon said tax becoming delinquent, he shall issue execution to be levied by the marshal, and the property levied on shall be advertised and sold as provided by the ordinances and the Charter of said city and the laws of the state. Said execution shall bear interest at the rate of 12 percent per annum and from date said taxes become delinquent. (Code 1967, § 16-6; Ord. No. 1-1969, § 8, 1-7-1969; Ord. No. 104, § 6, 1-16-1973; Ord. No. 686, § 2, 12-20-1994; Ord. No. 710, § 2, 12-5-1995) Charter reference— Execution of collection of license tax, § 95. Sec. 26-42. - Expiration; revocation. (a) Expiration. Each license issued by the city shall expire on January 31 next after the date the same is issued. Each applicant shall pay, as a prerequisite to the issuance of such license, the annual license fee or occupational tax required by law. (b) Revocation. Any person doing business under license, violating this Code or any ordinance of the city with reference to his business, may have his license revoked by the council, and on conviction of such violation shall be punished as prescribed in section 1-9 of the Code of Ordinances of the city, except in cases where a specific penalty is prescribed. (Code 1935, § 451; Code 1967, § 16-7; Ord. No. 104, § 7, 1-16-1973) Charter reference— Revocation of licenses, § 96. Sec. 26-43. - Registration of veteran's license. Any person doing business in the city using veteran's license must register same with the tax collector of the city. (Code 1967, § 16-8; Ord. No. 1-1969, § 11, 1-7-1969; Ord. No. 104, § 8, 1-16-1973) State Law reference— Veteran exemption, O.C.G.A. § 43-12-1 et seq.; fraudulent claim of exemption, O.C.G.A. § 48-1-7. Sec. 26-44. - Application of tax to servicing of articles. The special or license taxes provided for in this chapter shall also apply in all cases where articles are picked up in said city, serviced outside of the city or outside the state, and delivered in the city after service. Such tax shall also apply where articles are picked up outside the city or outside the state, serviced in the city, and delivered outside the city and state after service. (Code 1967, § 16-9; Ord. No. 1-1969, § 8, 1-7-1969; Ord. No. 104, § 9, 1-16-1973) Sec. 26-45. - Application of tax to intrastate commerce. No special or license tax herein provided for is intended to be levied upon or on account of interstate commerce; and in any case where a person is engaged in both interstate and intrastate commerce, the tax here levied is intended to be levied upon and on account of the intrastate commerce only. (Code 1967, § 16-10; Ord. No. 1-1969, § 1, 1-7-1969; Ord. No. 104, § 10, 1-16-1973) Sec. 26-46. - Vending, pinball, music machines. General licenses do not cover special licenses on soft drinks, malt beverages (beer/ale), or wine; penny arcades; music machines; cigarette, penny scales, or pinball machines. Vending machines and music machines shall be registered in the name of the place of business under same license. It shall be unlawful to install any vending, pinball or music machine in the city, including drink boxes with slots, in any place of business or public institution, unless the owner or operators shall first have filed notice of location with the city manager and paid license fee thereon in advance of installation. (Code 1967, § 16-12; Ord. No. 1-1969, § 7, 1-7-1969; Ord. No. 104, § 12, 1-16-1973) Sec. 26-47. - Schedule of license fees. (a) The following occupation taxes shall be levied and collected in the city for the tax year beginning February 1, 1999, and for each and every year thereafter, until changed by ordinances. (b) The occupation taxes provided for herein shall be due and payable February 1 of each year, and shall be delinquent if not paid by March 1 of each year, and each February 1 and March 1 thereafter, or on or before date of beginning of any business, calling, vocation, or profession in the city for which an occupation tax is required. (1) General businesses.
**Occupational tax is calculated by multiplying the number of employees in the firm times the tax per class. Example: Occupational tax for a firm with 50 employees is 50 employees times $70.00 = $3,500.00. Occupational tax for a firm with 200 employees is 200 employees times $65.00 = $13,000.00. (2) Professionals. Professionals as listed below may pay an occupation tax of $250.00 or may pay according to the number of employees as set out in subsection (c)(1) of this section: a. Lawyers. b. Physicians. c. Osteopaths. d. Chiropractors. e. Podiatrists. f. Dentists. g. Optometrists. h. Psychologists. i. Veterinarians. j. Landscape architects. k. Land surveyors. l. Public accountants. m. Embalmers. n. Funeral directors. o. Engineers. p. Architects. q. Professional counselors and therapists. (d) Schedule of regulatory fees. REGULATORY FEES
(1) Businesses located outside of the city providing services within the city shall pay a $80.00 regulatory fee unless they have paid a regulatory fee as listed in subsection (d)(2) of this section. (2) Any business paying a regulatory fee shall be required to register with the city and provide any basic information concerning their business and the nature of that business as requested. (3) If a regulatory fee is required for a business operation within the incorporated limits of the city, then the occupational tax will be waived. (e) Exemptions. An occupation tax shall not apply to any business or profession where such levy is prohibited or exempted by the laws of Georgia or of the United States. (Code 1967, § 16-13; Ord. No. 104, § 13, 1-16-1973; Ord. No. 182, §§ 1, 2, 1-21-1975; Ord. No. 183, §§ 1—3, 2-4-1975; Ord. No. 209, §§ 1, 2, 2-3-1976; Ord. No. 268, §§ 1, 2, 1-17-1978; Ord. No. 291, §§ 1, 2, 1-16-1979; Ord. No. 323, § 1, 5-6-1980; Ord. No. 331, §§ 1—7, 10-21-1980; Ord. No. 353, § 1, 7-21-1981; Ord. No. 386, §§ 1—4, 12-7-1982; Ord. No. 390, §§ 1, 4, 1-18-1983; Ord. No. 394, §§ 2, 5, 3-1-1983; Ord. No. 421, §§ 1—7, 1-17-1984; Ord. No. 426, § 1, 3-6-1984; Ord. No. 510, §§ 1—4, 12-16-1986; Ord. No. 541, § 1, 1-19-1988; Ord. No. 606, § 3, 12-4-1990; Ord. No. 686, § 3, 12-20-1994; Ord. No. 693, § 1, 3-21-1995; Ord. No. 710, § 3, 12-5-1995; Ord. No. 810, § 1, 5-18-1999; Ord. No. 956, § 1, 9-22-2005; Ord. No. 2008-43, § 1, 6-17-2008; Ord. No. 2013-138, §§ 4, 5, 12-17-2013) Secs. 26-48—26-75. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - AUCTIONS[3]
Footnotes: --- (3) --- State Law reference— Auctioneers, O.C.G.A. § 43-6-1 et seq.; jeweler's liens, auctions, O.C.G.A. § 44-14-430 et seq.
Sec. 26-76. - License required. (a) A license is required for any person, firm or corporation crying their goods, wares or merchandise on the streets or in their place of business aloud, or any person, firm or corporation advertising any sale of their goods, wares or merchandise by crying or spieling such sale aloud from any vehicle, auto or otherwise, for the purpose of attracting the public to such sale on the streets or in their places of business, excepting such sales of cattle or farm products. (b) Any person desiring to sell, dispose of, or offer for sale, at public auction, or cause or permit to be sold, disposed of, or offer for sale at public auction any goods, wares or merchandise shall first apply to the license inspector of the city for a license to carry on such auction and pay the fee therefor, and the person employed to auction said goods, wares or merchandise shall obtain a license and pay the fee therefor, all as may be required by the city. (Code 1967, § 16-34; Ord. No. 1-1969, § 1, 1-7-1969) Cross reference— Business licensing generally, § 26-36 et seq. Sec. 26-77. - Statement, affidavit as to inventory, persons conducting auction to be filed; issuance of license. (a) Before commencing such auction sale such person, firm or corporation conducting the same shall file with the license inspector of the city a statement setting forth when and where and for how long such auction sale will be conducted, together with a full and true inventory of all the articles to be sold at such auction sale, and shall attach to such statement an affidavit made by the person, firm or corporation conducting such sale that said statement is true and that said inventory contains a true statement of all the articles to be sold and that such goods are property of and owned by the person, firm or corporation conducting such sale, and such affidavit shall contain a statement of the name and address of the person employed to act as auctioneer in auctioning off such goods. (b) No auction sale shall be held except as set forth in said statement and affidavit, and no other articles shall be sold except those included in such sworn inventory unless a new affidavit shall be filed listing the additional goods to be sold, nor shall any other person be allowed to conduct said auction except the person listed in said affidavit until a new affidavit shall be filed setting forth such other person who may be employed to conduct such auction and cry off said goods. (c) The license inspector shall then issue a license permitting the sale. (Code 1967, § 16-35; Ord. No. 1-1969, § 1, 1-7-1969) Sec. 26-78. - Bond required. Upon securing the licenses hereinbefore mentioned and before commencing the auction sale set forth in said statement and affidavit as provided in section 26-77, the person, firm or corporation holding or conducting such sale of their goods, wares or merchandise shall make and file with the clerk of the city a bond in the sum of $5,000.00 in some good and solvent surety company doing business in this state, or other good and sufficient bond subject to the approval of the clerk of the city, payable to the city and conditioned to pay the city, or anyone else suing in its name for their use, for injuries or damages received on account of dishonest or fraudulent conduct in the administration of said business so licensed. Said bond shall provide that any person injured by the dishonest, fraudulent or improper conduct of said business may sue on said bond for their own use, and the recovery, if any, shall be payable to such person. (Code 1967, § 16-37; Ord. No. 1-1969, § 1, 1-7-1969) Sec. 26-79. - By-bidders prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person to act or to employ another in such auction sale as a by-bidder, or what is commonly known as a capper or booster or to make or accept any false or misleading bid, or to pretend to buy or sell any aforesaid article sold or offered for sale at such auction. (Code 1967, § 16-38; Ord. No. 1-1969, § 1, 1-7-1969) Sec. 26-80. - Exemption of certain sales. The provisions of this article shall not extend to judicial sales or to executors' or administrators' sales, nor to the sale by the holder of personal security under a contract allowing public sale in default of a debt. (Code 1967, § 16-39; Ord. No. 1-1969, § 1, 1-7-1969) Sec. 26-81. - Hours of sale. No person, firm or corporation shall carry on or conduct an auction for the sale of goods, wares or merchandise between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 8:00 a.m. local time, or on Sunday. (Code 1967, § 16-40; Ord. No. 1-1969, § 1, 1-7-1969; Ord. No. 197, § 2, 8-5-1975) Secs. 26-82—26-110. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - CLOSING OUT SALES
Sec. 26-111. - Inventory required. Whenever any person desires to advertise, represent or hold or conduct any sale of goods, wares or merchandise that is to be advertised or represented as a "closing out sale," a "going out of business sale," a "quitting business sale," or a sale designated in any manner by which it is represented that the business of such person is being terminated or closed out, such person shall file with the license inspector of the city an inventory of the goods, wares or merchandise to be sold. The inventory required shall contain a complete and accurate list of the stocks of goods, wares, or merchandise to be sold, together with their wholesale price. (Code 1967, § 16-46; Ord. No. 1-1969, § 1, 1-7-1969) Sec. 26-112. - Permit fee; payment of taxes and debts. The license inspector shall then issue a permit for $10.00 permitting the sale, providing all taxes and debts due the city have been paid including taxes due for current year. Taxes due for current year shall be figured at millage rate of previous year if new rate has not been set. (Code 1967, § 16-47; Ord. No. 1-1969, § 1, 1-7-1969) Sec. 26-113. - Sale of goods not listed on inventory prohibited. It shall be unlawful to sell, offer or expose for sale or to include in such inventory herein provided for any goods, wares or merchandise which are not an actual part of the original stock of goods of the applicant, and it shall be unlawful to make any replenishments or additions to such stock for the purpose of such sale, and it shall be unlawful for any person at any such sale to sell any goods, wares or merchandise not specifically described in such inventory. (Code 1967, § 16-48; Ord. No. 1-1969, § 1, 1-7-1969) Sec. 26-114. - Time limits; extension. It shall be unlawful to hold or conduct a closing out sale, a going out of business sale, a quitting business sale or a sale designated in any manner by which it is represented that the business of such person is being terminated or closed out, for a longer period than 60 days; provided, however, that in the event a longer time is necessary or required, the city council may grant an additional 30 days upon sufficient showing of said necessity. Upon expiration of the permit period, the business shall be closed, and no person who owned or had an interest therein shall reopen a similar business in any form (i.e., individual, partnership or corporation) in the same location in the same or another name within 60 days of the closing of such business at the end of the permit period. (Code 1967, § 16-49; Ord. No. 1-1969, § 1, 1-7-1969; Ord. No. 351, § 1, 6-17-1981) Sec. 26-115. - Exemption of certain sales. (a) The provisions of this article shall not apply to commercial travelers, or selling agents selling goods, wares and merchandise to dealers at wholesale. (b) No provision of this article shall be applicable to trustees in bankruptcy, executors, administrators, receivers, or public officials acting under judicial process. (Code 1967, § 16-50; Ord. No. 1-1969, § 1, 1-7-1969) Sec. 26-116. - Prohibited sales. Fire sales, wreck sales, and/or other sales where stock or livestock are shipped into the city and advertised at a special sale, are expressly prohibited. (Code 1967, § 16-51) Secs. 26-117—26-145. - Reserved. ARTICLE V. - BUYERS OF PRECIOUS METALS
Sec. 26-146. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Fixed place of business means an office or other fixed facility, that is, a place, site, structure, or other similar facility, used exclusively for business, including, but not limited to administrative or management activities, on a regular and continuing basis through which an individual or business entity engages in a trade or business for which an occupational license is currently issued. Gold or silver buyer means any person engaged in the business of purchasing or otherwise dealing in gold or silver or other precious metals of any kind or description, from members of the general public within the corporate limits of the city. Included in this definition are buyers of secondhand jewelry and gems. Isolated transactions between persons not engaged in the business are not covered by the terms of this article. (Code 1967, § 16-90; Ord. No. 332, § 1, 10-21-1980; Ord. No. 2010-79, § 1, 3-16-2010) Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. Sec. 26-147. - Legislative findings. Engaging in the business of buying gold, silver, other precious metals; precious gems; or jewelry within the corporate limits of the city is hereby declared to be affected with the public interest because of the opportunity it affords for the disposal of stolen property. (Code 1967, § 16-91; Ord. No. 332, § 2, 10-21-1980) Sec. 26-148. - Compliance with article required. It is hereby declared to be unlawful, and an offense punishable as provided in section 1-9 of this Code, to engage in the business of buying precious metals, precious gems or jewelry from members of the general public within the corporate limits of the city without first complying with the registration and other provisions of this article and obtaining a license as herein provided. Each day such offense occurs or continues shall constitute a separate offense. (Code 1967, § 16-92; Ord. No. 332, § 3, 10-21-1980) Sec. 26-149. - Advertising. No person, partnership, corporation or other entity covered by this article shall advertise, either in the news media, or portable signs, or in any other manner, the buying, selling or trading of, or otherwise dealing in, precious metals, precious gems or jewelry until they have complied with the provisions of this article. The violation of this section shall be unlawful and an offense punishable as provided in section 1-9 of this Code, and each day such violation occurs or continues shall constitute a separate offense. (Code 1967, § 16-93; Ord. No. 332, § 4, 10-21-1980) Sec. 26-150. - Registration. (a) Required. All persons, partnerships, corporations or other entities engaging in the business of buying precious metals, precious gems or jewelry shall register with the chief of police on a form to be provided by the chief of police. (b) Information. All applicants for registration under the provisions of this article shall furnish, in addition to such other information as the chief of police shall require, the following information: (1) Name of the applicant. (2) Permanent address and local address of the applicant. (3) If the applicant is a partnership, the name and address of each member of the partnership. (4) If the applicant is a corporation, the name and address of each stockholder, each officer and each director of the corporation. (5) The name and address of each employee of the applicant who is actively engaged in the performance of such services. (6) If a resident, the length of time the applicant has been a resident of the state and the city. (Code 1967, § 16-94; Ord. No. 332, § 6, 10-21-1980) Sec. 26-151. - Effect of criminal conviction. No person shall engage in the business or activity for which the license is required under this article, or shall be a member of a partnership, or an officer, stockholder or director in a corporation engaged in such business who shall have been convicted of a felony or a misdemeanor involving moral turpitude. (Code 1967, § 16-96; Ord. No. 332, § 7, 10-21-1980) Sec. 26-152. - Bond required. Every person, partnership, corporation or other entity engaging in the business of buying precious metals, precious gems or jewelry shall file with the chief of police for the city a surety bond executed by such applicant secured by a corporate surety company, authorized to do business in the state, in an amount not less than $5,000.00 conditioned upon compliance with the provisions of this article, and upon the prompt report of all suspicious persons dealing with the obligor, and of stolen property or property suspected of being stolen, and for the returning to the chief of police or to the true and lawful owner of any such property or making payment therefor. The bond shall be taken in the name of the city, and the city or any person injured by the breach of said bond may bring an action on said bond in its or his own name to recover damages therefor. (Code 1967, § 16-97; Ord. No. 332, § 8, 10-21-1980; Ord. No. 2010-79, § 2, 3-16-2010) Sec. 26-153. - Investigation of applicant. Within five days after receipt of an application as provided for herein, the chief of police shall cause an investigation to be made of the applicant and his proposed operation. If upon investigation the chief of police shall find that the applicant is of good moral character and has never been convicted of a felony or a misdemeanor involving moral turpitude, and has met all of the requirements of this article, he shall approve the issuance of a license to the applicant. The license shall be issued by the license division, and the license tax provided by the license and tax ordinance shall be paid. (Code 1967, § 16-98; Ord. No. 332, § 9, 10-21-1980) Sec. 26-154. - Notice to law enforcement officials. If the license required by the provisions of this article is approved, the applicant shall file a notice with all law enforcement agencies of the county and city within 15 days after approval. (Code 1967, § 16-99; Ord. No. 332, § 10, 10-21-1980) Sec. 26-155. - Register. Every licensee under this article shall keep a register upon which the licensee shall record the name, address, social security number or driver's license number, a brief description of the person, and other identification, of every person from whom the licensee purchases any precious metals, precious gems or jewelry, together with the date and time of day of said purchase; a description of each article purchased, including the name, make and serial or other identifying number or mark; and the amount paid therefor. Such entry shall be made at the time the transaction occurs. Before buying any precious metals, precious gems or jewelry, the licensee shall require positive identification from the seller, either from a driver's license or other document. (Code 1967, § 16-100; Ord. No. 332, § 11, 10-21-1980) Sec. 26-156. - Reports to police. Each licensee under this article shall file daily written reports at 10:00 a.m. with the chief of police, showing the name and description of the persons from whom precious metals, precious gems or jewelry were purchased by the licensee during the preceding 24 hours, and a description in detail of the nature, type and quantity of the precious metals, precious gems or jewelry. It is hereby made the duty of the chief of police to obtain such reports promptly each day. It shall be unlawful and an offense punishable as provided in section 1-9 of the Code of the city for any licensee to fail or refuse to make such daily report in the manner described by this section, and such failure shall be a ground for the revocation of the license. (Code 1967, § 16-101; Ord. No. 332, § 12, 10-21-1980) Sec. 26-157. - Elapsed time before disposal. No articles of personal property made of gold, silver or other precious metals or precious gems or jewelry shall be sold, melted, altered or otherwise disposed of by any secondhand dealer until ten days have elapsed from the time the chief of police has been given a copy or transcript of the register in which such articles of personal property made of gold, silver, platinum or other precious metals or gems or jewelry are entered, and said articles shall not be transferred from within the city limits during said ten-day period of time. (Code 1967, § 16-102; Ord. No. 332, § 13, 10-21-1980) Sec. 26-158. - Licenses nontransferable. Licenses issued under this article shall not be transferred. (Code 1967, § 16-103; Ord. No. 332, § 14, 10-21-1980) Sec. 26-159. - Disposition of stolen items. In the event it is determined that any item covered by this article is the subject of any theft, embezzlement or other crime, the licensee shall surrender same upon demand to the owner or the chief of police. (Code 1967, § 16-104; Ord. No. 332, § 15, 10-21-1980) Sec. 26-160. - Purchasing from minors prohibited. It shall be unlawful and punishable as provided in section 1-9 of this Code for any person, partnership, corporation or other entity engaged in the business of buying precious metals, precious gems or jewelry to purchase any of said items from a person less than 18 years of age. (Code 1967, § 16-105; Ord. No. 332, § 16, 10-21-1980) Sec. 26-161. - Revocation of license. Licenses issued pursuant to this article shall be subject to revocation or suspension by the city manager upon recommendation of the chief of police for the violation of or the failure to comply with any provision of this article or for the violation of any provision of law, after reasonable notice and an opportunity to be heard has been given the licensee. The city manager shall immediately notify any licensee of such suspension or revocation. (Code 1967, § 16-106; Ord. No. 332, § 17, 10-21-1980) Sec. 26-162. - Location restrictions. Every gold or silver buyer shall have at least one fixed place of business within the corporate limits of the city and all items stored pursuant to section 26-157 shall be stored at said fixed place of business. A gold or silver buyer may temporarily operate at a location other than their fixed place of business so long as the temporary location is properly zoned and the owner, occupier, or other person or entity entitled to the use of the location and the gold or silver buyer are licensed pursuant to this article. (Ord. No. 2010-79, § 3, 3-16-2010) Secs. 26-163—26-190. - Reserved. ARTICLE VI. - INSURERS[4]
Footnotes: --- (4) --- Cross reference— Business licensing generally, § 26-36 et seq.
Sec. 26-191. - Insurers' license fee. There is hereby levied for the year 1995 and for each year thereafter an annual license fee upon each insurer doing business within the city, in the amount of $75.00. For each separate business location in excess of one not covered by section 26-192, which is operating on behalf of such insurers within the city, there is hereby levied a license fee in the amount of $75.00. For the purposes of this article, the term "insurer" means a company which is authorized to transact business in any of the classes of insurance designated in O.C.G.A. § 33-3-5. (Code 1967, § 16-117; Ord. No. 405, § 1, 8-2-1983; Ord. No. 413, § 1, 11-1-1983; Ord. No. 435, § 1, 7-17-1984; Ord. No. 685, § 1, 12-6-1994) Sec. 26-192. - License fee for insurers insuring certain risks at additional business locations. For each separate business location, not otherwise subject to a license fee hereunder, operated and maintained by a business organization which is engaged in the business of lending money or transacting sales involving term financing and in connection with such loans or sales, offers, solicits or takes application for insurance through a licensed agent of an insurer for insurance, said insurer shall pay an additional license fee of $26.25 per location for the year 1995 and for each year thereafter. (Code 1967, § 16-118; Ord. No. 405, § 2, 8-2-1983; Ord. No. 413, § 2, 11-1-1983; Ord. No. 685, § 2, 12-6-1994) Sec. 26-193. - Insurers' agency license fees; independent insurance agencies, brokers, etc., not otherwise licensed. There is hereby levied for the year 1995 and for each year thereafter an annual license fee upon independent agencies and brokers for each separate business location from which an insurance business is conducted and which is not subject to the company license fee imposed by section 26-191 hereof, in the amount of $75.00 for each such location within the city. (Code 1967, § 16-119; Ord. No. 405, § 3, 8-2-1983; Ord. No. 413, § 3, 11-1-1983; Ord. No. 685, § 3, 12-6-1994) Sec. 26-194. - Gross premiums tax imposed on life insurers. There is hereby levied for the year 1995 and for each year thereafter an annual tax based solely upon gross direct premiums upon each insurer writing life, accident and sickness insurance within the state in an amount equal to one percent of the gross direct premiums received during the preceding calendar year in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8.1. Gross direct premiums as used in this section shall mean gross direct premiums as used in O.C.G.A. § 33-8-4. The premium tax levied by this section is in addition to the license fees imposed by section 26-191 of this article. (Code 1967, § 16-120; Ord. No. 405, § 4, 8-2-1983; Ord. No. 413, § 4, 11-1-1983; Ord. No. 685, § 4, 12-6-1994) Sec. 26-195. - Gross premiums tax imposed on all other insurers. There is hereby levied for the year 1995 and for each year thereafter an annual tax based solely upon gross direct premiums upon each insurer, other than an insurer transacting business in the class of insurance designated in O.C.G.A. § 33-3-5(1), doing business within the state in an amount equal to 2½ percent of the gross direct premiums received during the preceding calendar year in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8.2. Gross direct premiums as used in this section shall mean gross direct premiums as used in O.C.G.A. § 33-8-4. The premium tax levied by this section is in addition to the license fees imposed by section 26-191 of this article. (Code 1967, § 16-121; Ord. No. 405, § 5, 8-2-1983; Ord. No. 413, § 5, 11-1-1983; Ord. No. 685, § 5, 12-6-1994)

div.head: Chapter 30 - CEMETERIES[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 98. State Law reference— Dead bodies, O.C.G.A. § 31-21-1 et seq.; cemeteries, O.C.G.A. § 44-3-130 et seq.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 30-1. - Interment by unauthorized personnel. It shall be unlawful for any person other than those properly authorized by city officials to inter any body in any part of the cemetery. (Code 1935, § 198(h); Code 1967, § 7-1) Sec. 30-2. - Burial outside city cemeteries prohibited. It shall be unlawful to inter any dead body in any other place within the corporate limits of the city than in city-designated cemeteries, and any person who shall so inter or cause to be interred any dead body within the corporate limits, save in city-designated cemeteries, shall, on conviction, be punished as prescribed in section 1-9 of this Code. (Code 1935, § 198(g); Code 1967, § 7-2) Sec. 30-3. - Burial of paupers. No person shall be buried in any public cemetery as a pauper, nor shall a coffin be furnished for any such person, except upon the written approval of the mayor, or, in his absence, the chairman of the police committee. (Code 1935, § 198(k); Code 1967, § 7-3) Sec. 30-4. - Depth of grave or vault specified. It shall be unlawful to bury any person in any public cemetery in a dirt grave or vault less than five feet from the top of the ground to the bottom of the grave or vault, and in a cement vault no person shall be buried less than three feet from the top of the ground to the bottom of the vault. (Code 1935, § 198(j); Code 1967, § 7-4) Sec. 30-5. - Defacing of monuments, enclosures, trees or plants prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person to remove, deface, or in any manner injure any monument, railing, enclosure, ornament, tree or plant within the city cemetery. Such person, on conviction thereof, shall be punished as prescribed in section 1-9 of this Code. (Code 1935, § 198(a); Code 1967, § 7-5) Sec. 30-6. - Discharge of firearms. It shall be unlawful for any person to shoot any gun, pistol or other firearm within the city cemetery, unless it be by military firing salutes at a funeral in honor of the dead. (Code 1935, § 198(c); Code 1967, § 7-7) Sec. 30-7. - Depositing offensive matter in cemeteries. It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit on any part of said cemetery or any land adjoining it any carcass or any putrid or offensive matter whatsoever. (Code 1935, § 198(c); Code 1967, § 7-8) Sec. 30-8. - Animals and fowl prohibited; liability of owner. Animals and fowl are prohibited in the public cemetery, and the owners thereof shall be liable for damages occasioned thereby and for prosecution as herein provided for when it shall have been established that such animals and fowl are at large through the negligence of such owners. The presence of any animal or fowl in any public cemetery shall be prima facie evidence of negligence by such owner, sufficient to establish either a civil or criminal prosecution hereunder. (Code 1935, § 198(i); Code 1967, § 7-9) Cross reference— Animals, ch. 14. Sec. 30-9. - Trespassing.
