It shall be unlawful for any person so summoned to refuse to assist in such arrest. (Code 1935, §§ 176, 180; Code 1967, § 18-1) Sec. 74-2. - Blocking sidewalks and streets. It shall be unlawful for any person or group of persons to obstruct, in any way, the free passage of other persons or vehicles upon or across any sidewalk, crossway, alley, street, or other public thoroughfare within the city, except that restaurants may use a portion of sidewalks for tables and chairs and other services for their patrons, pursuant to regulation by the council. (Code 1967, § 18-2; Ord. No. 760, § 1, 9-2-1997) Sec. 74-3. - Camping on public, private, property. It shall be unlawful for any person to camp on any street or alley or any public place of the city, or upon private property without the consent of the owner. (Code 1935, § 189; Code 1967, § 18-3) Sec. 74-4. - Conspiracy. It shall be unlawful for any two or more persons in this city to conspire to do any act contrary to this Code, or to the laws and ordinances of the city. They may be jointly or severally prosecuted. (Code 1935, § 187; Code 1967, § 18-4) Sec. 74-5. - Defacing property. It shall be unlawful for any person to write, draw, paint, cut or carve any letters, word, or device on, or in any manner mutilate, disfigure, injure, deface, or damage any sign or building or other improvement in this city. (Code 1935, §§ 193, 196; Code 1967, § 18-6) Sec. 74-6. - Disorder at athletic contests or other games. It shall be unlawful for any person attending or at any athletic contest or other games, at any park or other place in the city, to do any act or thing which interferes or is liable to interfere with the progress of the game; to stand or sit in the aisles or passages of the grandstand, bleachers or other seating places provided; to go into any seat different from that for which he has paid and is entitled to; to go beyond any line, fence or rope or other contrivance established by the authorities at such games as a division line between players and the public and beyond which the public is prohibited; to place or throw any object in any place or position within said park or other public place, while said game is in progress, where or when said object being so placed or thrown causes injury or is likely to cause injury to any person; to assemble with others or another, at any place in said park or other public places while the said game is in progress, for the purpose of betting; to enter any such park, or other public place, where the same is enclosed, or peep in or over such enclosure, for the purpose of witnessing any of said game, without paying such fee to the proper person, as is charged or fixed by the authorities at said game for an admission in said park or other public place or to enter such enclosure at any place other than that designated by the authorities in charge of said park or other public place; or to aid, abet, encourage or participate in any fight, turmoil, or other disorderly demonstration at or in said park or place. It shall likewise be unlawful for any player or participant in any game herein specified to refuse to go without the enclosure of said park or other public place when ordered so to do by the proper official of said game. (Code 1935, § 182; Code 1967, § 18-7) Sec. 74-7. - Disturbance of public meetings. It shall be unlawful for any person to disturb any meeting lawfully assembled. (Code 1935, § 169; Code 1967, § 18-8) Sec. 74-8. - Disorderly conduct. (a) A person commits the crime of disorderly conduct, if, with intent to cause physical inconvenience, annoyance or alarm by or to a member or members of the public, or recklessly creating a risk thereof, such person: (1) Acts in a violent or tumultuous manner toward another whereby any person is placed in fear of safety of his life, limb or health; or, (2) Acts in a violent or tumultuous manner toward another whereby the property of any person is placed in danger of being destroyed or damaged; or, (3) Endangers the lawful pursuits of another by acts of violence, angry threats and abusive conduct or creates a hazardous or physically offensive condition by any act which is not performed under any authorized license or permit; or, (4) Causes, provokes or engages in any fight, quarrel, brawl or riotous conduct so as to endanger the life, limb, health or property of another; or, (5) Fights or quarrels in such manner and in such place as to annoy or disturb the peace, quiet, comfort, or repose of persons in any office, or any dwelling, hotel, or other type residence, or of any persons in the vicinity; or, (6) Assembles or congregates with another or others for the purpose of causing, provoking or engaging in any fight or brawl; or, (7) Jostles or roughly crowds or pushes any person in any public place; or, (8) Collects in bodies or crowds for unlawful purposes as defined by the ordinances of the city; or, (9) Assembles or congregates with another or others for the purpose or with the intent to engage in unlawful gaming; or, (10) Frequents any public place with intent to take money from other persons by illegal and fraudulent schemes, tricks, artifices or devices; or, (11) Assembles for the purpose of engaging in any fraudulent scheme, devise or trick to obtain any valuable thing in any place from any person in the city or who shall aid or abet therein; or, (12) Accosts or attempts to force his company upon any person, male or female, or attempt to pickup any person, male or female; or, (13) Utters or uses in the presence of another any bawdy, lewd, abusive, indecent, vulgar, threatening or obscene language or make an obscene gesture in or near a public place which has a direct tendency to cause acts of violence by, to, or provokes a violent response by, the person to whom or of whom the remarks are addressed or heard; or, (14) Frequents any place where gaming or the illegal sale or possession of alcoholic beverages or narcotics or dangerous drugs is practiced, allowed or tolerated; or, (15) Uses "fighting words" or such other words which are likely to provoke a violent response directed towards any person or becomes outraged and thus creates a turmoil; or, (16) Assembles or congregates for the purpose of trouncing on or accosting another; or, (17) By act of violence interferes with the pursuit of the lawful occupation of another; or, (18) Congregates with another or others on any public way so as to halt the flow of vehicular or pedestrian traffic and/or refuses to clear the public way when ordered by a lawful authority; or, (19) Congregates with another or other persons in a public place and refuse to comply with the lawful order of the police to disburse; or, (20) Operates a motor vehicle upon a parking area, public or private, vehicle access, or pedestrian walkway of any parking area and by sudden starting, stopping, or turning so as to endanger the person or property of another; or, (21) Operates a motor vehicle upon any parking area, public or private, vehicle access way, or pedestrian walkway of any parking facility at a speed great enough to endanger the person or property of another; or, (22) Operates a motor vehicle upon any pedestrian walkway or sidewalk, public or private in any manner; or, (23) Consumes alcoholic beverages or possesses or has under his control an open container of any alcoholic beverage in any public area including property of the city, state, or county unless otherwise permitted by ordinance; or, (24) Operates a motor vehicle and have therein under his possession and/or control or the possession and/or control of any person within the automobile an open container of any type containing an alcoholic beverage; or, (25) Appears in an intoxicated condition in any public place or within the curtilage of any private residence not his own other than by invitation of the owner or lawful occupant or within a place of business patronized by the public, such condition made manifest by boisterousness, indecent condition or act or by vulgar, profane, loud or unbecoming language; or, (26) Aids, abets or encourages a minor to do any act which constitutes disorderly conduct or a breach of the peace; or, (27) Yells, shouts, sings, chants or makes any other loud or unreasonable noise by any means whatsoever, whether by voice, handclapping, stomping or by mechanical means, on the public streets or on other public property or in proximity thereto in such manner and to such extent as to annoy or disturb the peace, quiet, comfort or repose of persons in any office, or in any dwelling, hotel, or other type residence, or of any person in the vicinity; or, (28) Does any act tending to debauch the safety, morality or decency of the general public; or, (29) Does any act which does, or which tends to, disturb the peace and quiet of the city or any portion thereof. (b) Noise is unreasonable, within the meaning of subsection (a)(27), if considering the nature and purpose of the person's conduct and the circumstances known to the person, including the nature of the location and the time of the day or night, the person's conduct involves a gross deviation from the standard of conduct that a law-abiding citizen would follow in the same situation; or the failure to heed the admonition of a police officer that the noise is unreasonable and should be stopped or reduced. (c) A renter, resident, or owner-occupant of the premises who knowingly or negligently consents to unreasonable noise on the premises shall be guilty of a noise violation. (d) Unless another penalty is provided by law, every person convicted of a violation of any provision of this section shall be punished by a fine of not more than $1,000.00 or by imprisonment for not more than six months or by both such fine and imprisonment. (Code 1935, § 165; Code 1967, § 18-9; Ord. No. 2013-128, § 1, 6-18-2013; Ord. No. 2014-145, § 1, 3-18-2014) Annotation— Disorderly conduct by use of "indecent, vulgar, obscene and abusive language in and near a public place in the city" does charge violation of municipal ordinance (section 165, Code 1935). Since publicity is the gist, said ordinance is valid and does not infringe on state statute prohibiting "opprobrious words or abusive language" used without provocation to or of another, tending to cause a breach of the peace. Sloan v. City of Moultrie, 61 Ga. App. 886; 7 SE2d 760 (1940). Sec. 74-9. - Reserved. Editor's note— Ord. No. 2013-129, § 1, adopted June 18, 2013, amended the Code by repealing former § 74-9 in its entirety. Former § 74-9 pertained to drunkenness, and derived from the Code of 1935, §§ 170, 171; and the Code of 1967, § 18-10. Sec. 74-10. - Escape. (a) It shall be unlawful to escape from the city work gang or jail, or from any arresting officer before or after trial and conviction. (b) It shall be unlawful to aid or abet any prisoner, before or after his trial, to escape from any officer, or any jail or work gang of the city. (Code 1935, §§ 178, 179; Code 1967, § 18-11) Sec. 74-11. - False alarm. It shall be unlawful for any person to make, give, send or turn in or cause to be made, sent, given or turned in, in any manner or way whatever, a false fire alarm or riot alarm, knowing the same to be false. (Code 1935, § 210; Code 1967, § 18-12) Cross reference— Alarm systems, § 42-26 et seq. Sec. 74-12. - Gambling; possession of gaming equipment. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person to assemble with another or others for the purpose of playing or betting for money or other thing of value, at any game played with cards, dice, or balls, or to play and bet for money or other thing of value, at any table of whatever name, kind or description, for gaming, or to bet at any game of ninepins, or any other number of pins, or at any billiard or pool table. (b) It shall be unlawful for any person to keep or maintain gaming devices in his or another's place of business for use or operation of any kind, at any time or under any circumstances. (c) It shall be unlawful for any person to maintain or operate or own or possess for the purpose of maintaining or operating any pinball or similar machine or any machine operated by depositing a coin therein for the playing of a game or engaging in any contest of chance or skill, including vending machines where the amount of merchandise to which the customer or person playing the machine is entitled is uncertain, or in some instances may be a larger amount than in other instances. (d) It shall be unlawful for any person to have in his custody or possession any cards, dice, balls or other gaming implements with the intention to use the same in playing and betting for money or other things of value. (Code 1935, §§ 173, 174; Ord. of 11-20-1956, § 1; Code 1967, § 18-14) Sec. 74-13. - Houses of ill fame. (a) Entering or occupying. It shall be unlawful for any person to occupy or to enter, for other than legitimate purposes, any lewd or bawdy or disreputable house within the city. (b) Permitting occupancy. It shall be unlawful for any person who is the owner or the agent of the owner to rent or cause to be rented any house or portion of a house, to be used as a house of ill fame in the city, or for any owner or agent of such owner of any house in this city to suffer or permit any woman of ill fame to occupy such house in this city for the purpose of adultery or fornication, for the space of two days after the same has been adjudged a house of ill fame by the municipal court. (c) Ejection of occupant. Whenever it develops upon the trial of any case made under the provisions of this section that any house is a house of ill fame, and so adjudged by the municipal court, it shall be the duty of the chief of police or his subordinate officers to eject the tenant therefrom. Circumstances from which it may be reasonably inferred that any house is inhabited by disorderly persons of immoral character and notoriously bad fame shall be sufficient to establish the fact that such house is a house of ill fame. (Code 1935, §§ 159, 160; Code 1967, § 18-15; Ord. No. 2014-150, § 1, 8-5-2014) Sec. 74-14. - Littering. (a) Prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person to litter the public streets, sidewalks, alleys, parking lots, drains and drainage ditches of the city. (b) Distribution of handbills, etc. It shall be unlawful for any person to place in or on any unoccupied or unattended automobile or other vehicle in the city or to otherwise distribute anywhere in the city any handbill, circular, pamphlet, poster, postcard or literature of any kind; however, such distribution may be permitted directly to the occupants of businesses or private residences or to the occupants of occupied vehicles in such manner as not to create a litter problem. (c) Cleanliness of garbage storage required. Every owner or occupant or lessee of a house or building used for residence, business or commercial purpose is required to maintain garbage storage areas in a clean condition and ensure that all garbage is properly containerized. (Code 1967, § 18-15.5; Ord. No. 376, §§ 1—3, 8-17-1982) Cross reference— Solid waste management, ch. 94. Sec. 74-15. - Loitering, loafing. (a) On streets. It shall be unlawful for any person to be found idling, loitering, or loafing upon the streets of the city. (b) Around jail. It shall be unlawful for any person to enter or loiter around the guardhouse or any other prison of said city, without permission of the city marshal or his deputies. (c) At bus depot, railroad station. It shall be unlawful for any person to loiter or idle at any bus depot or railroad station in this city, unless upon business with such bus line or railroad, or when waiting for the arrival or departure of a bus or train. (Code 1935, §§ 181, 185; Ord. of 10-19-1943, § 1; Code 1967, § 18-16) Sec. 74-16. - Malicious mischief. No person in the city shall commit any act of mischief which in anyway tends to injure the person or property of another. (Code 1935, § 172; Code 1967, § 18-17) Sec. 74-17. - Nuisances; abatement. (a) Creation, maintenance. It shall be unlawful for any person to create or maintain any nuisance. (b) Definition. Any building, business, thing, machine or machinery erected, repaired, conducted, maintained, operated or used within the city contrary to any of the fire, health and safety regulations of this Code shall be and is hereby declared to be a nuisance, or any matter or thing which endangers or impairs the peace, health, or welfare of any citizen is hereby declared a nuisance. (c) Removal by marshal. All nuisances, except those hereinafter specifically provided for, in, about or on the street and alleys of the city, shall be removed at once by the marshal without any preliminary proceeding for that purpose. (d) Abatement. (1) Nuisances may be removed and abated, as herein provided, upon the written complaint of any inhabitant of the city, which complaint shall set forth particularly the nature and location of the nuisance complained of and the person, if known, complained against and shall be verified. Said complaint shall be filed with the city clerk, who shall have a copy served upon the person complained against, together with a summons, requiring him to show cause before the municipal court at the place and at the time therein specified, not less than two and not more than five days from the date thereof, why the alleged nuisance should not be abated. (2) The copy and summons shall be served by the marshal or any police officer by handing the person complained against a copy thereof or by leaving same at his most notorious place of abode. (3) The municipal court shall hear evidence as to the facts and render judgment therein according to said facts and the laws of the case. If the thing complained of be a nuisance, the judgment of the municipal court shall so specify and they shall thereon fix the time when said nuisance shall be abated or removed by the defendant. (4) If such nuisance is not abated within the time specified within said judgment, the clerk shall issue a writ of removal to the marshal directing and requiring him to abate and remove such nuisance immediately, and the costs of such removal shall be assessed against the defendant or his property. (e) Untenantable building. (1) The city shall have the power to condemn and remove as a nuisance any burned or untenantable building in the city and to assess the entire costs of such proceeding against the property on which the building is located and against the owner thereof. (2) Whenever the city shall seek to condemn a burned, damaged, or untenantable building, the city shall notify the owner(s) of said property, in writing, of the date of a hearing to be had thereon, giving such owner(s) notice thereof in person or by leaving same at their most notorious place of abode, if they reside in the city. If the owner(s) are a nonresident of said city, service shall be made upon them by mailing a copy of said notice to them at their last known address. The city may provide in said notice that said hearing will be held not less than ten days in the future, but the city shall have the right, in the event any such building shall be dangerous to health, life, and public safety, to condemn and remove the same without notice. When notified, however, the owner(s) of the property shall be entitled to appear before the municipal court at the time and place stated in the notice, either by themselves or through their agent(s) or attorney(s) and at said hearing testimony shall be taken according to law and a full hearing given; and in the event any such building is condemned and the property owner(s) shall fail to abate said nuisance within the time fixed by the judgment of the municipal court, the city shall have the right to remove the same at the expense of the property owner(s). (Code 1935, §§ 293, 294, 296; Code 1967, § 18-18; Ord. No. 375, § 1, 7-21-1982; Ord. No. 2014-150, §§ 2—4, 8-5-2014) Sec. 74-18. - Obscene literature, pictures. (a) It shall be unlawful to possess, exhibit or sell, or offer to sell, bargain or transfer, any obscene writing of any kind, including songs. (b) It shall be unlawful to possess, exhibit, sell, or offer to sell, bargain or transfer, any obscene or vulgar picture, drawing or painting in the city. (Code 1935, §§ 156, 157; Code 1967, § 18-19) Sec. 74-19. - Parades; permit required. It shall be unlawful for any person to organize, hold or in any manner participate in a parade, march or organized demonstration for any purpose without having first obtained a permit to do so from the city manager at least 48 hours in advance of the time and date of the parade, march or demonstration. The application seeking such permit shall include the point and place of its beginning, the route it will follow in its course, the place of termination, the exact starting time, the ending time, and the number of police officers needed to assist with the handling of the traffic during the time of such parade, march or demonstration. (Code 1967, § 18-19.5; Ord. No. 324, § 1, 5-20-1980) Cross reference— Traffic and vehicles, ch. 106. Sec. 74-20. - Parading in masks; permit required. Except for Halloween celebrations by children, it shall be unlawful for any person or group of persons to parade or appear on or in the streets of the city or any other public place within the city while dressed in, or wearing, any mask or hood or other device which conceals or substantially conceals the identity or personality of any such person, unless such parade, appearance or demonstration shall be first approved by the city council in regular session or called session for that particular purpose, upon application in writing filed with the city clerk. The city council must act not later than ten days after application has been filed for such appearance, parade or demonstration. (Ord. of 7-8-1949, § 1; Code 1967, § 18-20) Sec. 74-21. - Peeping toms. Peeping toms, as defined by O.C.G.A. § 16-11-61, are hereby prohibited. (Code 1967, § 18-21) Sec. 74-22. - Prostitutes. It shall be unlawful for any woman commonly known as a street walker or prostitute to be found standing or loitering about the streets, alleys, or stores or other public places. (Code 1935, § 153; Code 1967, § 18-22) Sec. 74-23. - Public indecency. (a) Definitions. The term indecency as used in this section shall mean any display of any portion of the body which is normally covered by undergarments or clothing designed and intended to be worn as undergarments which convey an image that is lewd, indecent or sexually titillating to a person of ordinary and reasonable sensibilities or is intended to convey membership in identifiable gangs which have been previously associated with unlawful acts. The term hips as used in this section shall be defined as the crest of the ilium of the wearer. The term pants as used in this section shall mean a usually loose-fitting outer garment for the lower part of the body that reaches typically to the ankle but sometimes to any of various other points from the upper leg down and includes shorts and skirts. The term public place as used in this section shall mean any street, alley, park, public building, any place of business or assembly open to or frequented by the public, and any other place which is open to the public view, or to which the public has access. The term undergarment as used in this section shall mean any article of clothing worn under outer garments and next to the skin, including clothing worn at or below the waist, that are designed, intended or worn under the clothes to cover a person's intimate parts or which resembles clothing worn under outer garments even if attached by any means to pants. (b) It shall be unlawful for any person or persons to perform any of the following acts in a place where a person is in public: (1) An actual or simulated act of sexual intercourse or masturbation; (2) A lewd exposure of the sexual organs; (3) A lewd appearance in a state of partial or complete nudity; (4) A lewd caress or indecent fondling of the body of another person; (5) Urination or defecation; (6) The wearing of pants more than three inches below the top of the hips (crest of the ilium) exposing the skin or undergarments; or (7) Exposure of undergarments by the lifting, lowering, or removing of outer garments. (c) Penalties. (1) A citation shall be issued to the offender and the person shall be subject to a penalty of not less than $25.00 on the first offense and not more than $200.00 for each subsequent offense. In addition to or in lieu of a fine, the court may order such person to participate in up to 40 hours of court approved community service activities. (2) Any violation of this section shall be cited by the law enforcement officer by issuance of a citation and summons to appear before the municipal court of the city, or in the case of a juvenile, the juvenile court of the county. (3) This section shall not, in and of itself, be grounds for an arrest or for search of the person cited. However, the municipal court or juvenile court shall have the same authority as the superior court to enforce obedience to its orders, judgments and sentences. (Code 1967, § 18-23; Ord. No. 2013-130, § 1, 6-18-2013) Sec. 74-24. - Signs. It shall be unlawful for any person to post or cause to be posted any bills on any buildings in the city unless by the consent of the owners or occupants of said building. Where such signs are permitted they shall conform with the requirements of applicable zoning regulations. (Code 1935, § 197; Code 1967, § 18-24) Sec. 74-25. - Trespass. It shall be unlawful for any person to go upon the property or premises of another after having been notified by the owner or person in charge of such property or premises not to go upon said property. (Code 1967, § 18-25) Sec. 74-26. - Creation of loud and unnecessary noise prohibited. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person to make, continue, or cause to be made or continued any loud, unnecessary or unusual noise which either disturbs, injures or endangers the comfort, repose, health, peace or safety of other persons within the city. This prohibition shall include, but not be limited to, the playing of portable radios or recording devices in automobiles, trucks, and other motor vehicles as set out more particularly in subsection (b) of this section. (b) It shall be unlawful for any person to use, operate, or permit to be played, used or operated any radio or television receiving set, musical instrument, phonograph or other recording playback machine or device for the producing or reproducing of sound in such a manner as to disturb the quiet, comfort, repose, health, or peace of the neighboring inhabitants or at any time with louder volume than is necessary for the convenient hearing of the persons who are in the room, vehicle or immediate vicinity in which such machine or device is operated and who are voluntary listeners thereto. (c) The mayor and council delegates to the city manager the authority to permit outdoor functions and activities which are nontraditional, such as street dances, parking lot dances, and promotions, and similar activities and which might tend to produce high noise levels by way of amplified music or other sources. The intent of this subsection is to allow such activities under controlled conditions and where appropriate steps have been taken to reduce the likelihood of annoying or disturbing the peace and comfort of persons in the immediate vicinity of the proposed activity. This subsection is not intended to address or control traditional outdoor activities such as ball games, picnics, church-related and civic gatherings. The decision of whether to permit an activity covered by this section shall be that of the city manager under such terms and conditions as he deems necessary to meet the intent of this section. (Code 1935, § 164; Code 1967, § 18-26; Ord. No. 601, § 1, 8-7-1990) Sec. 74-27. - Vagrancy. Vagrants or persons of suspicious character shall not loiter or loaf or lounge in and upon the streets or other public places in the city, nor upon the premises of another. (Code 1935, § 175; Code 1967, § 18-27) Sec. 74-28. - Weapons. (a) Drawing concealed weapons. It shall be unlawful for any person in this city to draw from a place of concealment about his person any pistol, dirk, or knife. (b) Drawing weapon on another. It shall be unlawful for any person to draw on another any weapon; provided, that any person may in good faith draw in self-defense any weapon not a concealed weapon. (c) Discharging. It shall be unlawful for any person other than law enforcement officers in actual discharge of their duties as such or persons in actual defense of life, limb, or property of themselves or others under their lawful protection to discharge any sort of gun, pistol, rifle, or other firearm, or BB gun or airgun or spring gun, within the corporate limits of the city, whether the same is loaded with bullet, shot, shell, missile, or a mere explosive blank cartridge, shell, or other explosive device. It shall be unlawful for any person to discharge any firearm, including air powered firearms, in the corporate limits of the city and upon any lands now owned by said city, as aforesaid, if any such person shall first obtain permission to do so from the governing officials of said city. (Code 1967, § 18-28) Sec. 74-29. - Digging borrow pits. (a) It shall be unlawful to dig a borrow pit in the city without obtaining the prior written approval therefor from the city manager, which approval shall set forth the approximate depth and dimensions of the pit to be allowed. (b) Anyone dissatisfied with the action of the city manager on any request to dig a borrow pit may appeal such action to the mayor and council by filing notice thereof with the clerk of the city within ten days of the action of the city manager with which the person appealing is dissatisfied. (Code 1967, § 18-29; Ord. No. 2-1972, §§ 1, 2, 2-8-1972) Sec. 74-30. - Junk. (a) For the purpose of this section, the term "junk" shall mean any motor vehicle, machinery, appliance, product or merchandise with part missing, or scrap metal or other scrap materials that are damaged, deteriorated or that are in condition which prevents their use for the purpose for which they were intended. This definition specifically includes motor vehicles not movable under their own power and that cannot be made so movable by minor repairs such as inflating a tire or installing fuel or battery. (b) It shall be unlawful and a violation of this section for any person, firm or corporation to keep or store junk as defined in subsection (a) of this section in the city, unless such junk is located in a zone allowing the storage of such junk and only then if such junk is stored in such a manner as not to be visible from adjacent property, including public streets. In no event shall it be lawful for any person, firm or corporation to allow junk as defined in subsection (a) of this section to accumulate on any property not properly zoned for the storage of junk. (c) Nothing contained in this section shall be construed to prevent persons, firms or corporations which repair motor vehicles, appliances, etc., from accumulating unserviceable articles left with them in the normal course of their business; provided, however, such unserviceable articles shall not be visible from adjoining property. (Code 1967, § 18-30; Ord. No. 8-1972, §§ 1, 2, 5-16-1972) Sec. 74-31. - Panhandling, asking or begging prohibited; locations restrictions. No person shall impede or obstruct, for the purpose of begging, as defined in section 82-26, or panhandling, asking, solicitation, or intimidation, any person in a public place or in any place open to the public or in any of the following ways: (1) Within 20 feet of any entrance or exit of any bank, savings and loan association, credit union, or check cashing business during its business hours or within 20 feet of any automated teller machine during the time it is available for customers' use. Provided, however, that when an automated teller machine is located within an automated teller machine facility, such distance shall be measured from the entrance or exit of the automated teller machine facility. Provided further that no person shall panhandle, ask, beg or solicit within an automated teller machine facility where a reasonable person would or should know that he or she does not have the permission to do so from the owner or other person lawfully in possession of such facility. Nothing in this subsection shall be construed to prohibit: a. The lawful vending of goods and services within such areas; or b. Panhandling, asking, soliciting, or begging within the restricted area after obtaining the written permission of the owner or tenant. (2) Within 15 feet of any entrance into or exit from any building open to the public, subject to the provisions of subsection (a) of this section. (This prohibition shall not apply if the owner or tenant of the building grants permission to beg, panhandle, ask, or solicit within the restricted area.) (3) By approaching an operator or occupant of a motor vehicle while such vehicle is located in any public place, whether stopped or moving, or parked on any street, parking lot, or alley. (This prohibition shall not apply if the person or persons are employed by or affiliated with a bona fide not-for-profit organization or governmental entity provided said person or persons first register with the city clerk by providing the name, address, contact information, and tax identification number of said entity. In addition, the location where said activities will occur shall be provided to the city clerk and such activities shall be limited to the area designation and said person or persons shall at all times wear or display the name or other identifying information of said entity while asking or soliciting funds to be remitted and utilized by said entity); (4) Within or immediately adjacent to any public parking lot or structure any time after dark. After dark means any time from one-half hour after sunset to one-half hour before sunrise; (5) Within any public transportation vehicle or within 20 feet of any designated or posted public transportation facility or vehicle stop; (6) By remaining in any indoor or outdoor dining area of any restaurant or other establishment serving food for immediate consumption after being asked to leave by the owner, manager, or supervisor of the facility or any agent or security force thereof, or by a peace officer acting at the request of any of the persons specified in this subsection; (7) By repeating a begging, panhandling, asking, solicitation request when the person solicited is stationary and has refused an immediately prior request made at that location. Examples include, but are not limited to: a. By at any time immediately before, during, or after the request, touching the solicited person without that person's consent; b. While blocking the path of the person solicited or the entrance to any building or vehicle; c. By following behind, alongside, or ahead of the person solicited during or after the request; d. By directing profane or abusive language at the person solicited at any time immediately before, during, or after request; e. By immediately before, during, or after request, making any statement other than the request or acting in any other manner which, in light of the circumstances taken as a whole that would cause a reasonable person to feel harassed, intimidated, or compelled to contribute. (8) This section 74-31 shall not apply to any of the following: a. To panhandling related to business which is being conducted on the subject premises by the owner or lawful tenants; b. To panhandling related to the lawful towing of a vehicle; or, c. To panhandling related to emergency repairs requested by the operator or other occupant of a vehicle. (9) Unless another penalty is provided by law, every person convicted of a violation of any provision of this section shall be punished by a fine of not more than $1,000.00 or by imprisonment for not more than 6 months or by both such fine and imprisonment. (Ord. No. 2014-144, § 1, 3-18-2014) Secs. 74-32—74-55. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - CURFEW FOR JUVENILES
Sec. 74-56. - Findings; public purpose. (a) The council hereby finds and determines as a matter of fact that the city is facing a mounting crisis caused by crimes committed by juvenile offenders and crimes committed against juvenile victims. (b) The council further finds that persons under the age of 17 are particularly susceptible by their lack of maturity and experience to participate in unlawful activities and/or to place themselves in situations which would increase their potential for victimization. (c) The council further finds that a need exists for increased parental responsibility and parental control over the activities of juveniles. (d) The council further finds that this criminal activity, both individually and collectively, presents a clear and present danger to the citizenry and to public order and safety and that an ordinance establishing a curfew for persons under the age of 17 and parental responsibility for violations of said curfew is an appropriate method of addressing the foregoing issues. (e) Therefore, the purpose of this article is to: (1) Protect juveniles themselves and other citizens from the dangers of crimes which occur on sidewalks, streets, and in public and semipublic places during late night and early morning hours; (2) Decrease the amount of criminal activity committed by juveniles; and (3) Promote and enhance parental control over juveniles. (Code 1967, § 18-51; Ord. No. 667, § 1, 4-5-1994) Sec. 74-57. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Curfew hours means the hours of 11:00 p.m. until 6:00 a.m. the following day from Sunday to Thursday, and the hours of 12:00 midnight to 6:00 a.m. on Saturday and Sunday mornings. Emergency means an unforeseen circumstance or combination of circumstances or the resulting state or any situation requiring immediate action to care for or prevent serious bodily injury or loss of life. This term includes, but is not limited to, a fire, natural disaster, or automobile accident. Juvenile means any person under 17 years of age. Law enforcement officer means a certified law enforcement officer of any rank who is a duly sworn officer of the police department. Legal guardian means a person or agency appointed by a court to act in the role of a parent. Operator means any individual, firm, association, partnership or corporation operating, managing or conducting any licensed business establishment. The term includes the members or partners of an association or partnership and the officers of a corporation. Parent means the natural parent, adoptive parent, stepparent or custodial grandparent of a juvenile. Public place means any property owned or controlled by the city or other governmental entity to which the general public has access and a right to resort for business, recreation, entertainment, or other lawful purpose, including sidewalks, streets and highways. Semipublic place means any privately owned or privately operated real property, including any structure thereon, to which the general public is invited or has the legal right of access and a right to resort for business, recreation, or entertainment, or other lawful purpose, such as, but not limited to, any store, shop, restaurant, lounge, theater, parking lot, alley, road, shopping center, bowling alley, pool hall, any vacant lot, or any vacant or abandoned building. (Code 1967, § 18-52; Ord. No. 667, § 2, 4-5-1994) Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. Sec. 74-58. - Curfew established. It shall be unlawful and a violation of this article for any juvenile to linger or stay or to congregate, loiter, wander, or stroll in any public place or semipublic place within the city, either on foot or in or upon any conveyance being driven, ridden, or parked thereon, during curfew hours. (Code 1967, § 18-53; Ord. No. 667, § 3, 4-5-1994) Sec. 74-59. - Exceptions. The provisions of this article shall not apply if the juvenile is: (1) Accompanied by a parent or legal guardian. (2) Engaged in lawful employment or travelling between such employment and his current residence without any detour. (3) Engaged in interstate travel. (4) Attending an official school, religious, or other recreational activity supervised by adults and sponsored by the city, the county, the Colquitt County School Board, a civic organization, or other similar entity that takes responsibility for the juvenile, or going to or returning home from, without any detour, any activity previously described in this subsection. (5) On the curtilage of his residence or on the sidewalk abutting his residence. (6) Attending or returning to his current residence from a specific activity at a public place or semipublic place which is open to the general public and supervised by adults; provided further that such activity begins no later than 10:00 p.m.; provided further that the juvenile has in his immediate possession written permission from his parent or legal guardian authorizing the child to attend or engage in that specific activity. (Code 1967, § 18-54; Ord. No. 667, § 4, 4-5-1994) Sec. 74-60. - Responsibility of parents. It shall be unlawful for the parent, legal guardian, or other adult person having the care, control or custody of a juvenile to permit or by insufficient control to allow such juvenile to violate and/or to remain in violation of the provisions of section 74-58 of this article. (Code 1967, § 18-55; Ord. No. 667, § 5, 4-5-1994) Sec. 74-61. - Responsibility of operators. It shall be unlawful for any operator, owner or any employee managing or conducting any establishment to knowingly allow a juvenile to remain or stay or to congregate, loiter, wander, stroll or play upon the premises of the establishment during curfew hours in violation of the provisions of section 74-58 of this article. (Code 1967, § 18-56; Ord. No. 667, § 6, 4-5-1994) Sec. 74-62. - Notice. Operators are encouraged but not required to conspicuously display in or about the premises of an establishment a legibly printed notice in substantially the following form: "IT IS UNLAWFUL FOR A PERSON UNDER THE AGE OF 17 TO REMAIN ON THESE PREMISES BETWEEN THE HOURS OF 11:00 P.M. TO 6:00 A.M. FROM SUNDAY TO THURSDAY AND THE HOURS OF 12:00 MIDNIGHT TO 6:00 A.M. ON SATURDAY AND SUNDAY MORNINGS UNLESS SPECIFICALLY ALLOWED BY LAW." (Code 1967, § 18-57; Ord. No. 667, § 7, 4-5-1994) Sec. 74-63. - Defenses. (a) It shall be a defense to any prosecution under the provisions of section 74-58 of this article that: (1) The juvenile was married or had been married or had the disabilities of minority removed by a court of law. (2) The juvenile was exercising rights protected by the First Amendment to the United States Constitution and/or Ga. Const. art. I. (b) It shall be a defense to any prosecution under the provisions of section 18-55 of this article that: (1) The parent, legal guardian or other adult person having the care, control or custody of a juvenile found to be in violation of this article had reported to the police department that said juvenile was missing from such person's control or custody. (2) The parent, legal guardian or other adult person having the care, control or custody of a juvenile could not have known, in the exercise of reasonable care and diligence, of the unlawful acts of such juvenile. (3) The juvenile on whose conduct the charge against the parent, legal guardian or other adult person responsible for exercising care, control or custody was exercising rights protected by the First Amendment to the United States Constitution and/or Ga. Const. art. I. (c) It shall be a defense to any prosecution under the provisions of section 18-56 of this article that the owner, operator or employee notified the police department that a juvenile was present on the premises of the establishment during curfew hours and refused to leave after being asked to leave the premises. (Code 1967, § 18-58; Ord. No. 667, § 8, 4-5-1994) Sec. 74-64. - Penalties for violations. (a) A juvenile charged for violating section 74-58 of this article shall be referred to the juvenile court of the county for disposition in accordance with the laws of the state. (b) Any person found guilty of violating section 74-60 or section 74-61 of this article shall be fined not less than $50.00 nor more than $200.00 for a first conviction and not less than $200.00 nor more than $1,000.00 for any subsequent conviction and/or may be sentenced to complete community service work at the discretion of the municipal court. (Code 1967, § 18-59; Ord. No. 667, § 9, 4-5-1994)

div.head: Chapter 78 - PARKS AND RECREATION[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Environment, ch. 46; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 98.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 78-1. - City parks and recreational areas, hours of public use. All parks and recreational areas of the city shall be open for public use from sunrise to sunset local time unless a previously scheduled, organized activity is in progress or scheduled to begin. In such event, the area will be cleared of all persons immediately upon completion of the previously scheduled activity. (Ord. No. 2008-36, § 1, 5-20-2008) Editor's note— Ord. No. 2008-36, § 1, adopted May 20, 2008, deleted the former § 78-1, and enacted a new § 78-1 as set out herein. The former § 78-1 pertained to similar subject matter. See the Code Comparative Table for complete derivation. Secs. 78-2—78-30. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - RECREATION ADVISORY COMMISSION[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- Cross reference— Boards, commissions and committees, § 2-266 et seq.
Sec. 78-31. - Created. There is hereby created the Moultrie-Colquitt County Recreation Advisory Commission. (Code 1967, § 19½-2(a); Ord. No. 699, § 1, 6-6-1995; Ord. No. 742, § 1, 2-4-1997) Sec. 78-32. - Membership. (a) The Moultrie-Colquitt County Recreation Advisory Commission shall consist of seven members, six of whom shall be elected officials of the county and the city. The seventh shall represent cities located in the county. The city manager, the county administrator and the recreation director of the city shall serve as ex officio members of the commission with all the rights and privileges of membership with the exception of the right to vote. The mayor of the city and the chairman of the county board of commissioners shall appoint three members each to the commission. There shall always be three members of the city council and three members of the county board of commissioners. There shall always be one at-large member on the commission representing the cities of Doerun, Norman Park, Ellenton, Funston, Berlin and Riverside. Said at-large member shall be a joint appointment by the mayors of Doerun, Norman Park, Ellenton, Funston, Berlin and Riverside. (b) The mayor of the city shall appoint three members from the city council for a term of one year. The mayor may appoint himself. The chairman of the county board of commissioners shall appoint three members from the county board of commissioners for a term of one year. The chairman may appoint himself. The joint appointment of the cities of Doerun, Norman Park, Ellenton, Funston, Berlin and Riverside shall be for a period of one year. (c) Any member appointed by the mayor or chairman can be removed by the mayor or chairman. The at-large member appointed by the cities of Doerun, Norman Park, Ellenton, Funston, Berlin and Riverside can be removed by a two-thirds vote of the mayors representing those cities. (d) All of the members of the commission shall serve without compensation. (Code 1967, § 19½-2(b); Ord. No. 699, § 1, 6-6-1995; Ord. No. 742, § 1, 2-4-1997) Sec. 78-33. - Officers. The recreation commission shall elect a chairman, vice-chairman, and a secretary from its membership, with each committee officer serving a one-year term. The chairman and vice-chairman shall rotate annually on a rotating basis between the city and the county. (Code 1967, § 19½-2(c); Ord. No. 699, § 1, 6-6-1995; Ord. No. 742, § 1, 2-4-1997) Sec. 78-34. - Meeting times. The recreation advisory commission shall meet at such times as may be necessary to transact the business coming before it but not less than quarterly. At its first meeting in January and every year thereafter, the commission shall elect its officers. Meetings of the commission shall be open to the public. (Code 1967, § 19½-2(d); Ord. No. 699, § 1, 6-6-1995; Ord. No. 742, § 1, 2-4-1997) Sec. 78-35. - Duties and powers. (a) The duties and powers of the commission shall be as follows: (1) Annually review the proposed recreation budget as prepared by the city. (2) Study, investigate, develop, and recommend to the city, other county municipalities, and the county board of commissioners plans for improving the recreation facilities and programs of Moultrie, Doerun, Norman Park, Ellenton, Funston, Berlin, Riverside, and the unincorporated areas of the county. (3) Advise with and recommend plans to other agencies of the Cities of Moultrie, Doerun, Norman Park, Ellenton, Funston, Berlin, Riverside, and the unincorporated areas of the county. (4) Otherwise promote public interest in the general development of creation in the cities of Moultrie, Doerun, Norman Park, Ellenton, Funston, Berlin, and Riverside, and the unincorporated areas of the county. (b) Nothing herein shall be construed to abridge or change the powers and duties of other committees, commissions, departments, boards and other like agencies of the cities and the county board of commissioners. (Code 1967, § 19½-2(e); Ord. No. 699, § 1, 6-6-1995; Ord. No. 742, § 1, 2-4-1997) Sec. 78-36. - Annual report. It shall be the duty of the Moultrie-Colquitt County Recreation Advisory Commission in January of each year to file with the city clerks of each of the county municipalities and with the clerk of the county board of commissioners a comprehensive report on the recreational needs and proposals for the coming year, to include estimates thereof. (Code 1967, § 19½-2(f); Ord. No. 699, § 1, 6-6-1995; Ord. No. 742, § 1, 2-4-1997)

div.head: Chapter 82 - PEDDLERS AND SOLICITORS[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Businesses, ch. 26; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 98. State Law reference— Peddlers and itinerant traders, O.C.G.A. § 43-32-1 et seq.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 82-1. - Purpose. The purpose of the article is to promote the health, safety and welfare of residents of the City of Moultrie; to protect the privacy of residents of the City of Moultrie; and to prevent fraud and crime against residents of the City of Moultrie. (Ord. No. 2008-50, § 1, 10-21-2008) Secs. 82-2—82-25. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - PEDDLERS
Sec. 82-26. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Aggressive begging shall mean begging with the intent to intimidate another person into giving money or goods. Applicant means any person who or which applies for a certificate of registration under this article. Begging shall mean asking for money or goods as a gift, whether by words, bodily gestures, signs or other means. Canvass or canvassing means such activities as are directed at dissemination of religious, political or public interest information, taking polls, seeking opinions and determining attitudes of individuals or groups of individuals including uninvited contact at any residence by any institution, organization or cause having a charitable purpose as defined in this section for purposes of making the message, aim or purpose of such institution, organization or cause known to the occupant of such residence, but shall not include the solicitation of funds as defined in this section. Charitable purpose means philanthropic, benevolent, religious, public interest or other nonprofit objectives, including the benefit of poor, needy, sick, refugee or handicapped persons; the benefit of any church or religious society, sect, group, order or cause; the benefit of a patriotic or veterans' association or organization; the benefit of any fraternal, social or civic organization; or the benefit of any educational, environmental, civic or public interest institution, organization, or cause. The term "charitable purpose" shall not be construed to include the direct benefit of the individual making the solicitation. City means the City of Moultrie, Georgia. Code means the Code of the City of Moultrie, Georgia. Gold or silver buyer means any person engaged in the business of purchasing or otherwise dealing in gold or silver or other precious metals of any kind or description, from members of the general public within the corporate limits of the city. Included in this definition are buyers and sellers of secondhand jewelry and gems. Isolated transactions between persons not engaged in the business are not covered by the terms of this article. Individual means only a natural person. Intimidation shall mean the coercion, threat, or frightening into submission or obedience of one person unto another whether by words, bodily gestures, or other means. Local nonprofit organization shall mean any bona fide charitable or nonprofit organization having an office, place of business, chapter or the like located in the corporate limits of the City or in Colquitt County. Panhandling shall mean to detain or distract a person or persons in a public place for the purpose of soliciting money or goods. Peddler means any means a person without a fixed place of business or one who sells at other than his fixed place of business and who goes to any residence or place of business, without prior invitation of the resident or occupier thereof, for the purpose of selling, offering for sale or exposing for sale any goods, merchandise, wares or services; or for the purpose of taking orders for the purchase of goods, merchandise, wares or services, whether by samples, catalogs or the like; or for the purpose of selling subscriptions to periodicals or magazines. The term peddler does not include the sale or offering for sale of goods or services by representatives of local nonprofit organizations, or gold or silver buyers. Peddling means any of the activities described in the definition of peddler, immediately above. Person means any natural person, corporation, partnership, or other entity which has legal existence under Georgia law, their employees, agents, officers and the like. Public place shall mean any road, alley, lane, parking area, sidewalk, building, or any place, private or otherwise, adopted or fitted for vehicular or pedestrian travel, that is in common use by the public with the consent, expressed or implied, of the owner or owners, and further, any public playground, school grounds, recreational facility, parks, parkways, park drives, park paths, and rights-of-way open to the use of the public. Residence means and includes every separate living unit occupied for residential purposes by one or more persons contained within any type of building or structure. Resident means any individual residing, temporarily or permanently, within the corporate limits of the city. Solicit funds, solicitation of funds or soliciting funds means any request for the donation of money, property, or anything of value, or the pledge of a future donation of money, property, or anything of value; or the selling or offering for sale of any property, real or personal, tangible or intangible, services, whether of value or not, including, but not limited to, goods, books, pamphlets, publications or subscriptions to publications, brochures, or services upon the representation, express or implied, that the proceeds of such sale will be used for a charitable purpose as such term is defined in this section. A solicitation of funds is complete when the solicitation is communicated to any individual when located within the corporate limits of the city. Solicitor means any person who engages in solicitation of funds or the buying of goods. (Ord. No. 2008-50, § 2, 10-21-2008; Ord. No. 2010-78, §§ 1—3, 3-16-2010) Editor's note— Ord. No. 2008-50, § 2, adopted Oct. 21, 2008, deleted the former § 82-26, and enacted a new § 82-26 as set out herein. The former § 82-26 pertained to similar subject matter. See the Code Comparative Table for complete derivation. Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. Sec. 82-27. - Manner of operation. (a) Peddlers operating within the city may operate in flea markets and while operating therein shall not require an additional license but may operate under the license of the owner of the flea market, which owner is responsible for the conduct of all peddlers operating within his or its establishment. Peddlers operating door to door shall do so only during daylight hours except by prior appointment with the occupant to be called upon. (b) (1) Peddlers may operate in association with festivals, fairs or expositions, but the organization or entity organizing the festival, fair or exposition will be responsible for obtaining all necessary permits that may be required. (2) Peddlers may operate within the state farmer's market. (3) Peddlers may sell agricultural products that have been grown locally. (4) Peddlers may provide products free of charge as part of an ancillary promotional event. (5) Peddlers may operate in association with a registered nonprofit organization selling products for fund-raising purposes. (6) Peddlers may operate "ice cream trucks". (c) (1) No display, sales or parking is permitted in any street or any street right of way. In addition, no display, sales or parking shall obstruct pedestrian or vehicular traffic, except as permitted in the following subsection (2). Any temporary structures shall be sited in such a manner as not to obstruct the view of any pedestrian or vehicle traffic. (2) No more than ten percent of the required parking area for the existing commercial use may be used for the temporary miscellaneous sales. (3) Within one day after the expiration of the use, the site must be cleared of all debris and temporary structures. (4) No open fires for the disposal of scrap wood, tree trimmings or other material shall be permitted. (5) No permanent structure shall be erected for use by peddlers. (Ord. of 9-1-1964, § 3; Code 1967, § 16-81; Ord. No. 390, § 2, 1-18-1983; Ord. No. 394, § 1, 3-1-1983; Ord. No. 540, § 1, 1-19-1988; Ord. No. 856, § 2, 12-19-2000) Sec. 82-28. - Permit required. A permit is required for a peddler or solicitor operating other than in a flea market, and such person shall file an application on a form provided by the city manager or his duly authorized representative. (Ord. No. 2008-50, § 3, 10-21-2008) Editor's note— Ord. No. 2008-50, § 3, adopted Oct. 21, 2008, deleted the former § 82-28, and enacted a new § 82-28 as set out herein. The former § 82-28 pertained to similar subject matter. See the Code Comparative Table for complete derivation. Sec. 82-29. - Permit application; fee; duration. Any person desiring to engage in peddling within the corporate limits of the city shall pay a nonrefundable administration fee of $150.00 and shall provide, on an application form to be supplied by the city clerk, the following information: (1) The name of the applicant registering and desiring to engage in peddling or solicitation; (2) Whether the applicant is a natural person, partnership, corporation or other legal entity; and: a. If a natural person, the person's business or residence address and telephone number; b. If a partnership, the names of all partners and the principal business address and telephone number of each partner; c. If a corporation, information shall be given as to whether the corporation is organized under the laws of the state or is a foreign corporation and the mailing address, telephone number and business location of any local or regional office making the application and mailing address of home office of the corporation and telephone number of the home office shall be given; d. If an association or other legal entity, the registration statement shall show the names and principal business or residence addresses and telephone numbers of the officers and directors or trustees; if the association is part of a multistate organization or association, the mailing address and business location of its home office shall be given, in addition to the mailing address and business location of any local office the association may operate; (3) The time period within which the peddling or solicitation effort is to be made, giving the date of beginning of the effort and the projected date of conclusion; (4) A description of the methods and means by which the peddling or solicitation is to be accomplished; (5) The names of any other cities in which the person registering has engaged in peddling or solicitation within the past two years, but if the person has engaged in peddling or solicitation in more than ten other cities, the person registering may list the five cities in which the most peddling or solicitation activities occurred, along with the dates of peddling and solicitation and a list of the licenses/permits obtained during such peddling and solicitation. (6) Whether the person registering or any officer, director, trustee, partner, or any current agent or employee thereof who has been convicted of a felony or misdemeanor involving moral turpitude within the past five years, and, if so, the nature of the offense, the city and state where the conviction occurred, and the year of such conviction; (7) A list of the persons, including their home addresses and telephone numbers, and dates of birth, who will actually be participating in the peddling effort; (8) If the person registering is unable to provide any of the foregoing information, an explanation of the reasons why such information is not available; (9) A statement to the effect that when a certificate of registration is granted, such certificate will not be used as or represented to be an endorsement by the city or any of its elected officials or employees; (10) The registration statement must be signed by the person registering if that person is an individual; if the person registering is a partnership, by a partner thereof; if the person registering is a corporation or an association, by an officer thereof; the individual making the registration statement shall sign the statement and swear or affirm before an officer authorized to administer oaths that he or she has carefully read the registration statement and that all the information contained therein is true and correct. If an individual has been authorized to apply for the permit on behalf of a corporation or association a letter of authorization from an officer of the company or association must be presented at the time of the initial application. (11) The city clerk shall maintain on file in the clerk's office the registration statement provided for in this section for the period of time the certificate of registration is in effect and the city clerk shall make such registration statement available for review by any member of the public, upon request. (Ord. No. 2008-50, § 4, 10-21-2008) Editor's note— Ord. No. 2008-50, § 4, adopted Oct. 21, 2008, deleted the former § 82-29, and enacted a new § 82-29 as set out herein. The former § 82-29 pertained to similar subject matter. See the Code Comparative Table for complete derivation. Sec. 82-30. - Issuance of certificate of registration. After a review of the registration statement to determine its compliance with section 82-29 and within ten working days of the receipt of the registration statement, the city clerk shall either issue a certificate of registration or notify the person registering that the registration statement does not comply with the requirements of section 82-29 and shall specifically designate what information or explanation has not been furnished that is required before a certificate of registration can be issued. If the required information has not been furnished within five business days of the applicant being notified by the city clerk that the application does not supply complete information as outlined, the permit shall not be granted. (Ord. No. 2008-50, § 5, 10-21-2008) Sec. 82-31. - Form of certificate of registration. (a) The city clerk shall prescribe the form of and issue a certificate of registration to each applicant who complies with the provisions of section 82-29 upon payment of the nonrefundable administrative fee. However, each such certificate of registration shall contain the following language: "The issuance of this certificate of registration is not an endorsement by the City of Moultrie or any of its elected officials or employees." (b) Each certificate of registration shall bear a registration number which is the same as the file containing the registration statement filed by the applicant. (c) No more than three certificates of registration shall be issued to any one applicant in any calendar year. (Ord. No. 2008-50, § 6, 10-21-2008) Sec. 82-32. - Identification cards. (a) The city clerk shall prescribe the form of identification cards and shall be responsible their issuance. However, each such identification card shall bear the name of the person registering, the registration number, the name of the peddling organization or entity, as may be applicable, and the expiration date of the certificate of registration. Each identification card shall have printed prominently thereon and shall read: "This identification card is not an endorsement by the City of Moultrie or any of its elected officials or employees of any product or service sold by the bearer hereof." (b) The city clerk shall issue each person who has complied with the provisions of section 82-29 a number of identification cards which corresponds with the number of individuals listed as peddlers on the registration statement up to a maximum of five cards per permit. (Ord. No. 2008-50, § 7, 10-21-2008) Sec. 82-33. - Expiration of certificate of registration. Every certificate of registration and identification card issued by the city clerk shall expire 45 days from the date of issuance. (Ord. No. 2008-50, § 7, 10-21-2008) Sec. 82-34. - Unlawful peddling, canvassing or soliciting. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person, directly or through an agent or employee, to engage in peddling within the corporate limits of the city unless such person shall have first obtained a certificate of registration from the city clerk, as provided in this article. (b) It shall be unlawful for any individual, as the agent or employee of another, to engage in peddling within the corporate limits of the city unless the individual's principal or employer has received a certificate of registration as provided in this article. (c) It shall be unlawful for any individual to engage in peddling without visibly displaying an identification card issued that individual by the city clerk as provided in this article. (d) It shall be unlawful for any individual to alter an identification card issued by the city clerk. Any card issued by the city clerk which is in error may be exchanged for a corrected card. (e) It shall be unlawful for an individual to engage in peddling while displaying an identification card issued by the city clerk in the name of another individual. (f) It shall be unlawful to peddle, canvass or to solicit between the hours of 8:00 p.m. and 9:00 a.m.. (g) It shall be unlawful for any person, directly or through an agent or employee, to engage in peddling or solicitation within the corporate limits of the city after the expiration of any certificate of registration issued as provided in this article. (h) It shall be unlawful for the person registering or the agents or employees thereof to engage in any peddling activity other than that set out in the registration statement from which the certificate of registration was issued. (i) Any peddler, canvasser, solicitor, or person selling goods or services on behalf of a local nonprofit organization who enters on private property under a certificate of registration issued pursuant to section 82-30 and section 82-31 shall immediately and peacefully depart such private premises, when requested by the resident of such private premises, and the failure of such peddler, canvasser, solicitor of funds or person selling goods or services on behalf of a local nonprofit organization to depart the private premises after being so requested shall be unlawful. (j) It shall be unlawful for any person who engages in peddling or solicitation within the corporate limits of the city to represent in connection with such peddling that the issuance of a certificate of registration or an identification card by the city constitutes an endorsement or approval of the purposes of such peddling effort by the city or any elected official or employee thereof. (k) The penalty of a violation under this section shall be by a fine not exceeding $1,000.00 or by imprisonment for any time not exceeding six months. Any one or more of these punishments may be imposed for the same offense. In all cases where penalties or forfeitures are provided for any act or omission, they shall be held to apply to each and every such act or omission, and when such act or omission is of a continuing character, they shall apply to each and every days continuance thereof. (Ord. No. 2008-50, § 8, 10-21-2008; Ord. No. 2010-78, § 3, 3-16-2010) Editor's note— Ord. No. 2010-78, § 3, adopted March 16, 2010, amended § 82-34 title to read as herein set out. former § 82-34 title pertained to unlawful peddling, canvassing or soliciting. Sec. 82-35. - Notice posted that peddlers, canvassers, or solicitors are not invited. (a) Any occupant of a residence or business who does not wish to receive peddlers, canvassers, solicitors or persons selling goods or services on behalf of a local nonprofit organization at that residence or place of business shall give notice of that determination in the following manner: A weatherproof card at least three inches by four inches in size, shall be posted or exhibited at or near the main entrance door to the residence indicating that determination by the occupant in substantially the same language as follows: "No solicitors, peddlers, or canvassers invited." The letters on such notice shall be at least one-third-inch in height. Such card so exhibited shall constitute notice to any peddler, canvasser, solicitor, or person selling goods or services on behalf of a local nonprofit organization of the determination by the occupant of the residence or place of business that such persons are not invited at that residence or place of business. (b) It shall be unlawful for any person to go upon any residential or business premises and ring the door bell upon or near any door or create any sound in any manner calculated to attract the attention of the occupant of such residence or place of business for the purpose of securing an audience with the owner or occupant thereof and engage in peddling, canvassing, soliciting or selling goods or services on behalf of a local nonprofit organization as in this article and defined in defiance of the notice posted or exhibited at the residence in accordance with the provisions of this article. (c) The penalty for violations under this section shall be assessed under the provisions of subsection 82-34(11) of this Code. (Ord. No. 2008-50, § 9, 10-21-2008; Ord. No. 2010-78, §§ 5—7, 3-16-2010) Editor's note— Ord. No. 2010-78, § 5, adopted March 16, 2010, amended § 82-35 title to read as herein set out. former § 82-35 title pertained to notice posted that peddlers, canvassers or solicitors of funds are not invited. Sec. 82-36. - "No-call" list. The city clerk is hereby authorized to maintain a "no-call" list which comprises the names and addresses of all residents of the city, to include the owners or occupiers of business premises, who do not wish to have their places of residence or business visited by peddlers, canvassers, solicitors or persons selling goods or services on behalf of a local nonprofit organization. No peddler, canvasser, solicitor or person selling goods or services on behalf of a local nonprofit organization shall call on any resident or owner or occupier of a business premises whose name and address appear on the "no-call" list maintained by the city clerk. Every peddler who or which obtains a certificate of registration pursuant to this article, and every canvasser, solicitor or person selling goods or services on behalf of a local nonprofit organization is charged with the responsibility of obtaining from the city clerk a copy of the "no-call" list if established pursuant to this section before beginning any peddling effort, canvassing effort or solicitation of funds. Any person engaged in any peddling effort, canvassing effort, solicitation of funds, sale of goods or services on behalf of a local nonprofit organization who or which calls on a residence or place of business which appears on the "no-call" list established pursuant to this section shall be subject to penalty under the provisions of subsection 82-34(11) of this Code. (Ord. No. 2008-50, § 10, 10-21-2008; Ord. No. 2010-78, § 8, 3-16-2010) Sec. 82-37. - Prohibited acts. It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in aggressive begging in a public place or in any place open to the public. The penalty for violation under this section shall be assessed under the provisions of subsection 82-34(k) of this Code. (Ord. No. 2008-50, § 11, 10-21-2008, Ord. No. 2014-143, § 1, 3-18-2014) Sec. 82-38. - Exemptions for certain persons. Any person peddling or soliciting under the terms of this article who holds a valid current license from a state agency authorizing such peddling and solicitation, and which state agency regulates any person so licensed by it, is hereby excepted from the provisions of this article. Churches, schools and other nonprofit organizations shall likewise be excepted from the provisions of this article. (Ord. of 9-1-1964, § 4; Code 1967, § 16-84; Ord. No. 163, § 1, 9-3-1974; Ord. No. 2008-50, § 12, 10-21-2008)

div.head: Chapter 86 - PLANNING[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Charter reference— City planning commission, § 100 et seq. Cross reference— Administration, ch. 2; buildings and building regulations, ch. 22; environment, ch. 46; flood damage prevention, ch. 54; historic preservation, ch. 62; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 98; utilities, ch. 110; vegetation, ch. 114; zoning, ch. 122. State Law reference— Zoning, development and planning, O.C.G.A. §§ 36-66-1 et seq., 36-70-1 et seq.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Secs. 86-1—86-25. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - SOUTHWEST GEORGIA AREA PLANNING AND DEVELOPMENT COMMISSION[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- Cross reference— Boards, commissions and committees, § 2-266 et seq.
Sec. 86-26. - Established. In cooperation with the governing authorities of other area municipalities and counties, in order to guide and accomplish a coordinated and harmonious development of the city and the Southwest Georgia area which will, in accordance with existing and future needs, best promote public health, safety, morals, order, convenience, prosperity, and the general welfare, as well as efficiency and economy in the process of development, the Southwest Georgia Area Planning and Development Commission, hereinafter referred to as "the area planning commission" is hereby created and established as authorized by O.C.G.A. § 50-8-30 et seq., as amended, and said planning commission shall be organized and empowered as provided in this article. (Ord. of 12-21-1965, § 1; Code 1967, § 20-1) Sec. 86-27. - Membership. The Southwest Georgia Area Planning and Development Commission shall consist of three members from the counties participating in the area commission. Of the said three members from each county, one shall be appointed by the governing authority of the municipality wherein the county seat is located, the second member shall be appointed by the governing authority of said county, and the third member shall be appointed by all the participating governments of said county, the third member to be from among the minority group of the said county, selected in consultation with and on recommendation of representatives from organizations which represent the minority population of said county. (Ord. of 12-21-1965, § 2; Code 1967, § 20-2; Ord. No. 14-1972, 9-19-1972) Sec. 86-28. - Term of office; removal; compensation. The term of office for all members shall be five years, except that the initial appointment by the city council of the city shall be for a term of four years. The third member from the county representing the minority population shall be appointed for an initial term of two years. Any vacancy in the membership shall be filled for the unexpired term by the governing authority making the appointment which has become vacant. The appointing authority shall also have the power to remove any member it may appoint for cause on written charges, after public hearing. All members shall serve without compensation. (Ord. of 12-21-1965, § 3; Code 1967, § 20-3; Ord. No. 14-1972, 9-19-1972) Sec. 86-29. - Organization; rules; staff; finances. The commission shall elect a chairman and vice-chairman from among its appointive members. The term of office of the chairman and vice-chairman shall be for one year or until reelected or their successors are elected. The commission shall appoint a secretary who may be an employee of the commission. The commission shall meet at least once each month at the call of the chairman and at such other times as the chairman or board may determine; shall adopt rules for the transaction of business; and shall keep a record of its resolutions, transactions, findings, and determinations, which record shall be a public record. The commission may appoint such employees and staff as it may deem necessary for its work. In the performance of its duties, the planning commission may cooperate with, contract with, or accept funds from federal, state, or local public or semipublic agencies or private individuals or corporations; may spend such funds; and may carry out such cooperative undertakings and contracts. It may make expenditures for the purpose by the participating governing authorities. (Ord. of 12-21-1965, § 4; Code 1967, § 20-4) Sec. 86-30. - Powers and duties. It shall be the function and duty of the commission to make such careful and comprehensive surveys and studies of existing conditions and probable future developments and to prepare such plans for physical, social, and economic growth as will best promote the public health, safety, morals, convenience, prosperity, or the general welfare as well as efficiency and economy in the development of the entire Southwest Georgia area and each political subdivision herein. In general, the commission shall have powers and duties and responsibilities as set forth in O.C.G.A. § 50-8-30 et seq., as amended. (Ord. of 12-21-1965, § 5; Code 1967, § 20-5) Secs. 86-31—86-55. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - MOULTRIE-COLQUITT COUNTY PLANNING COMMISSION[3]
Footnotes: --- (3) --- Cross reference— Boards, commissions and committees, § 2-266 et seq. State Law reference— Zoning, development and planning, O.C.G.A. §§ 36-66-1 et seq., 36-70-1 et seq.
