Sec. 86-56. - Created, purpose. (a) In order to guide and accomplish a coordinated and harmonious development of the city and county which will, in accordance with existing and future needs, best promote public health, safety, morals, convenience, order, prosperity and the general welfare, as well as efficiency and economy in the process of development, the Moultrie-Colquitt County Planning Commission, hereinafter referred to as "the planning commission," shall be and the same is hereby created and established as authorized by the former General Planning and Zoning Enabling Act of 1957 (1957 Ga. Laws, page 420 et seq.), as amended, and O.C.G.A. § 36-70-1 et seq. (b) Such planning commission shall be organized and empowered as provided in this article. (Code 1967, § 20-11; Ord. No. 14-1968, 11-5-1968) Sec. 86-57. - Membership; appointments; terms; compensation. The Moultrie-Colquitt County Planning Commission shall consist of 12 members. Six of the members shall be residents of the city appointed by the mayor and council of the city, and six of the members shall be residents of the county living outside the corporate limits of the city appointed by the board of commissioners of the county. The terms of the members shall be for three years, except that in the appointment of the first Moultrie-Colquitt County Planning Commission under the terms of this article, two of the members appointed by both governing bodies shall initially serve for three years, two for two years, and two for one year, all thereafter serving three-year terms. Any vacancy in membership shall be filled for the unexpired term by the body originally filling the position in which the vacancy occurs. The appointing body shall also have the authority to remove any member appointed by it for cause, on written charges, after a public hearing. All members shall serve without compensation but may be reimbursed for actual expenses incurred in connection with their official duties. (Code 1967, § 20-12; Ord. No. 14-1968, § 1, 11-5-1968; Ord. No. 338, § 1, 2-17-1981) Sec. 86-58. - Organization, rules, staff and finances. The Moultrie-Colquitt County Planning Commission shall elect its chairman from among its members. The term of the chairman shall be for one year with eligibility for reelection. The commission shall in like manner elect a vice-chairman; except that if the chairman be elected from members appointed by one governing body, the vice-chairman shall be elected from members appointed by the other governing body. The term of the vice-chairman shall be for one year with eligibility for reelection. The commission shall appoint a secretary who may be an officer or an employee of the city or the county. The planning commission shall make its own rules of procedure and determine its time of meeting. All meetings of the planning commission at which official action is taken shall be open to the public, and all records of the planning commission shall be a public record. The planning commission may appoint such employees and staff as it may deem necessary for its work and may contract with the state planning agency and with city planners and other consultants for such services as it may require. The expenditures of the planning commission, exclusive of gifts, shall be within the amounts appropriated for the purpose by the governing authorities of the city and the county. (Code 1967, § 20-13; Ord. No. 14-1968, § 2, 11-5-1968; Ord. No. 338, § 2, 2-17-1981) Sec. 86-59. - Powers and duties. From and after the time when the planning commission shall have organized and selected its officers, and shall have adopted its rules of procedure, then said planning commission shall have the powers, duties and responsibilities set forth in the former General Planning and Zoning Enabling Act of 1957 (1957 Ga. Laws, page 420 et seq.), as amended, and O.C.G.A. § 36-70-1 et seq. (Code 1967, § 20-14; Ord. No. 14-1968, § 3, 11-5-1968)

div.head: Chapter 90 - SECONDHAND GOODS[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Businesses, ch. 26.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Secs. 90-1—90-25. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - JUNK AND SECONDHAND DEALERS, PAWNBROKERS[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- State Law reference— Junk dealers, O.C.G.A. § 43-22-1 et seq.; pawnbrokers, O.C.G.A. § 44-12-130 et seq.; supervision of pawnbrokers by municipalities, O.C.G.A. § 44-12-136; liens of pawnbrokers, O.C.G.A. § 44-14-400.
Sec. 90-26. - Registration of purchases. Each person or dealer in junk, pawn or secondhand shop shall register on a form to be furnished by the police department of the city at the time of the purchase or pawn the name of all persons from whom purchases or pawns are made, a description of the article and the amount involved, which information shall be furnished daily to the police department of the city. (Ord. of 1-18-1966, § 1; Code 1967, § 16-73; Ord. No. 12-1967, §§ 2, 4, 12-7-1967) Sec. 90-27. - Pawnshops dealing in pistols to have license. All pawnshops dealing in pistols must have a license therefor. (Code 1967, § 16-75; Ord. No. 12-1967, § 4, 12-7-1967) Secs. 90-28—90-55. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - GARAGE SALES
Sec. 90-56. - Permit; time limits; location. Garage sales held by individuals for the purpose of disposing of personal items no longer needed or wanted may be held in any zone of the city; provided, however, no such sale may be conducted without first receiving a permit from the city. Said permit shall be issued by the license inspector of the city without charge. The permit shall state the date of the sale, the name of the person conducting the sale, and the location of the sale. It shall be a violation of this section to conduct a garage sale without first obtaining a permit. Only one sale may be held by an individual in any year, and shall last no more than two consecutive days. Under no circumstances shall such a sale be conducted off the premises of the owner of the property to be disposed of at the sale, except that it shall be permissible for neighbors to conduct a joint sale on the property of one of the neighbors who is a participant in the sale. (Code 1967, § 16-52; Ord. No. 174, § 1, 11-19-1974; Ord. No. 555, § 1, 7-5-1988)

div.head: Chapter 94 - SOLID WASTE MANAGEMENT[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Buildings and building regulations, ch. 22; environment, ch. 46; health and sanitation, ch. 58; littering, § 74-14; utilities, ch. 110.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 94-1. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases and their derivations when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Ashes means the residue from the burning of wood, coal, coke, or other combustible materials. Building material means any material defined as but not limited to lumber, brick, block, stone, carpet, plumbing materials, plaster, concrete, roofing, floor tile, gutters or other substances accumulated as a result of the construction of, repairs, or additions to structures or accessory structures or the demolition of such. City means the City of Moultrie. City council means the legally designated governing body of the city composed of the council and mayor. City manager means the city manager of the city. Commercial recyclables includes cardboard and noncoated corrugated boxes. Complex means an apartment complex, mobile home park, or similar type of residential complex. Complex management means the official person or entity charged with overseeing and managing a complex. Composting means the controlled biological decomposition of organic matter into a stable, odorfree humus. Garbage means the byproduct resulting from the growing, harvesting, processing, handling, preparation, cooking, or consumption of animal or vegetable food or other matter which is subject to decomposition, decay, and putrefaction, for the generation of noxious or offensive gases or odors, or which during or after decay may serve as breeding areas or feeding material for flies, insects, or animals. Ashes and dead animals weighing 100 pounds or less shall be classed as garbage. Hazardous waste means materials which constitute a hazard to health or safety, such as poison, acids, caustic matter or solutions, chemicals, infected materials, offal, fecal matter, explosives, radioactive materials, and highly flammable substances. Household debris means large discardable items, other than industrial, hazardous, or sanitary waste, which cannot be inserted into a garbage container. Household debris includes, but is not limited to, large household furniture, such as sofas and chairs, and large household appliances, such as stoves and refrigerators. Industrial waste means waste materials, including solids, semisolids, sludges, and liquids, created by or resulting from the operation of factories, processing plants, or other manufacturing enterprises. Litter means all discarded manmade materials, including but not limited to garbage, household debris, refuse, rubbish, building materials, sand, gravel, slag, dead animals, industrial waste, hazardous waste, other discarded, used or unconsumed substance or other waste material which, if thrown or deposited, tends to create a danger to public health, safety and welfare or which is not handled in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. Old cars means any car which is inoperable, which does not have displayed a current Georgia state or other state motor vehicle inspection sticker, if required, or which does not have displayed a current license tag, including historical tags. Public works department means the public works department of the city. Refuse means all decomposing and decaying solid wastes (except body wastes), accumulations including garbage, rubbish, ashes, street cleanings, dead animals, industrial wastes, building material, household debris, litter, yard trimmings, and other discarded materials. Residential recyclables includes newspapers, glass bottles, metal cans, aluminum cans, plastic bottles, cardboard, and noncoated corrugated boxes. Rubbish means combustible and noncombustible solid waste, other than garbage, household debris, yard trimmings, hazardous waste, industrial waste, and sanitary waste, not subject to rapid decomposition derived from residential, commercial, and institutional areas and shall include paper, rags, plastics, cartons, boxes, metals, minerals, crockery, packaging materials, discarded clothing, and similar materials. Sanitary waste means sewage waste materials, including solids, semisolids, sludges, liquids, or any other form of sewage created by or resulting from septic tanks, wastewater treatment plants, or other facilities. Scrap tire means a tire that is no longer suitable for its original intended purpose because of wear, damage, or defect. Solid waste means any solid waste derived from households including single-family and multifamily residences, hotels and motels, bunkhouses, campgrounds, picnic grounds, and day use recreation areas as well as commercial establishments including stores, offices, restaurants, warehouses, and other nonmanufacturing activities. Solid waste shall include garbage, household debris, rubbish, litter, tree trimmings, and yard trimmings, but does not include hazardous waste, industrial waste, sanitary waste, or solid waste from mining, agricultural, or silvicultural operations. Tree trimmings means tree leaves or needles, branches, limbs, and parts of trees. Weeds includes jimson, cudsu, thistle, ragweed, burdock or other weeds of like kind found growing in any lot or tract of land within the city, and any weeds, grasses or plants other than trees, brushes, flowers or other ornamental plants, growing to a height of ten inches. Garden flowers, vegetables, cultivated agricultural crops, ornamental shrubbery and trees shall not be considered weeds, grasses or other vegetation. Yard trimmings means leaves, brush, grass clippings, shrub prunings, tree trimmings, discarded Christmas trees, nursery and greenhouse vegetative residuals, and vegetative matter resulting from landscaping development and maintenance, other than mining, agricultural, and silvicultural operations. (Ord. No. 792, § 1(12-1), 8-18-1998; Ord. No. 834, §§ 1—4, 4-4-2000) Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. Sec. 94-2. - Administration. (a) Authority of city manager. The city manager, through the public works department, and by implementing and enforcing the provisions of these regulations, is authorized and directed to control the storage, collection, transportation, and disposal of all refuse within the city. The regulations contained in this chapter shall apply to the storage, collection, transportation, and disposal of refuse in the city by private haulers, as well as by the public works department. However, nothing in this section or chapter shall be construed as a surrender by the city of its legal authority to permit and franchise private haulers of refuse, including industrial and hazardous waste, or to become the sole and exclusive hauler of all refuse, including industrial and hazardous waste in the city. (b) Collection authority. All refuse generated or accumulated in the city, when in compliance with this chapter, shall be collected, transported, and disposed of by the public works department or an approved private hauler. No other person shall collect, transport, or dispose of any refuse generated or accumulated in the city. (c) Approved private haulers. Any private hauler seeking to collect refuse within the city, including industrial and hazardous wastes, must be a state-certified hauler, obtain a permit and enter into a franchise agreement with the city council, and furnish the city a list of all its customers within the city and the type of customer they are. Any private hauler of commercial garbage who was operating within the city as of April 1, 1998, can maintain the customer base it had as of April 1, 1998, provided it follows the guidelines for attaining and receiving approved private hauler status; however, it can accept no new commercial customers, and should the private hauler cease to exist as a company, the hauler's customer base shall fall under normal collection practices of this chapter. (Ord. No. 792, § 1(12-2), 8-18-1998) Sec. 94-3. - Cleanliness of property required; property owner's responsibility; abatement by city; costs constitute lien. (a) Persons to maintain premises in a cleanly manner. (1) Every person, whether the owner, occupant, person in control or any agent thereof, of any private property, whether a vacant lot or otherwise, shall at all times maintain the premises in a clean, sanitary, healthy and nonhazardous condition. All property shall be free of litter, garbage, household debris, rubbish, scrap tires, old cars or parts, household appliances, and weeds, undergrowth, brush or other matter which by reason of height, proximity to neighboring structures, physical condition, filth or habitat for reptiles, animals, and insects, shall be deemed by the city to be unsanitary, unhealthy or hazardous. Provided however, that this section shall not prohibit the storage of litter in authorized private receptacles for collection. (2) Outdoor furniture. The use of any furniture not manufactured for outdoor use, upholstered or un-upholstered furniture manufactured primarily for indoor use, including mattresses, chairs and seats, or any motor vehicle parts or equipment of any sort, shall be prohibited on any unenclosed porch, carport, garage, balcony or any front, side or rear yard visible from any public place, sidewalk, roadway, street or highway and it shall be prohibited to use any unenclosed front or side porch area for the storage of manufactured furniture primarily for indoor use, including mattresses. (b) Clearing of private property by city. (1) The city through its officers, is authorized and empowered to notify the owner, occupant, person in control or any agent thereof, of any private property within the city, to properly abate any condition on their property deemed unsanitary, unhealthy or hazardous. Such notice may be given by personal service, certified mail or posting the property in a conspicuous manner. (2) Upon the failure, neglect, or refusal of any owner, occupant, person in control or any agent thereof, so notified, to properly abate said condition within the ten days receipt of the notice or such notices return due to inability to make certified delivery or the posting of the property, unless a hearing is requested in writing addressed to the clerk of municipal court by the person receiving the notice, the city is hereby authorized and empowered to clean said property and abate any conditions deemed unsanitary, unhealthy or hazardous. (3) If an affected party requests a hearing as set forth in (2) above, the clerk of municipal court shall summon all affected parties to show cause before the judge of Moultrie Municipal Court at the time specified therein, not less than four nor more than 20 days from the date thereof, why the alleged condition should not be abated. The court shall hear evidence as to the facts and render judgment therein according to said facts and the law of the case. If the thing complained of be dangerous to the public health, safety or welfare, the judgment of the court shall so specify and shall thereon fix the time not more than ten days from the date of said judgment when said condition shall be abated by the affected parties. (4) When the city has effected the cleaning of such property or has paid for such cleaning to be accomplished, the actual cost thereof, plus an administrative fee of $100.00 plus accrued interest at the rate of 12 percent per annum from the date of the completion of the work, if not paid by the owner, occupant, person in control or any agent thereof, shall be charged against the person and property of any owner, occupant, person in control or any agent thereof. (5) When the full amount due the city is not paid within thirty (30) days, there shall be recorded in the property records of the county courthouse, a sworn statement showing the cost and expense incurred for the work, the date the work was done, and the legal description of the property. The recordation of such sworn statement shall constitute a lien on the property, and shall remain in full force and effect for the amount due in principal and interest, plus cost of court, reasonable attorney fees, for collection, until final payment has been made. Sworn statements recorded shall be prima facie evidence that all legal requirements have been complied with and that the work has been done properly and shall be in full notice to every person concerned that the amount of the statement, plus interests and costs, constitutes a charge against the property designated or described in the statement and that the same is due and collectible as provided by law. A fi. fa. shall be issued, executed, prosecuted, levied, and sales conducted thereunder as in the case of fi. fas. for the collection of ad valorem taxes of the city. (c) In addition, every violation of this article shall be punishable as follows by the issuance of citation: Upon the first notice on any given lot or tract of land within any calendar year, a penalty in the amount of $100.00; Upon the second notice on any given lot or tract of land within any calendar year, a penalty of $150.00; Upon the third and subsequent notice on any given lot or tract of land within any calendar year, a penalty of $250.00. (Ord. No. 834, § 5, 4-4-2000; Ord. No. 2009-57, § 1, 5-5-2009) Editor's note— Ord. No. 834, adopted April, 4, 2000, repealed in its entirety section 94-3, cleanliness of property required, and enacted a new section 94-3 as set out herein. Said former section pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 792, adopted August 18, 1998. Sec. 94-4. - Ownership of refuse. All refuse, including refuse deposited in approved refuse containers, shall remain the property of the owner, occupant, or agent owning, holding, or occupying the property on which the refuse was generated or accumulated until the same has been placed in a public works department or approved private hauler vehicle. (Ord. No. 792, § 1(12-4), 8-18-1998) Sec. 94-5. - Noncollectible refuse. Certain types of refuse shall not be collected by the public works department, but shall be removed by the applicable resident, commercial customer, contractor, or approved private hauler. These types of refuse include the following: (1) Tree trimmings shall not be collected where trees are trimmed or cut for compensation, whether the compensation be in cash or in the wood from the trees trimmed or cut, except in the case of a natural disaster. (2) Yard trimmings and debris from the original development of a lot shall not be collected. However, where the city requires the cleaning of a vacant lot by a person, whether the owner, occupant, or agent owning, holding, or occupying said property, the debris therefrom, excluding stumps, shall be collected for the applicable fee. (3) Building material waste generated whereby the construction was done for compensation shall not be collected. However, building material waste generated whereby the construction was done by the owner on the residence in which he resides shall be collected for the applicable fee. (4) Hazardous waste shall not be collected. (5) Industrial waste shall not be collected. (6) Sanitary waste shall not be collected. (Ord. No. 792, § 1(12-5), 8-18-1998) Sec. 94-6. - Prohibited activities. The following activities are declared to be unlawful and in violation of this chapter: (1) No person shall deposit on or bury in or cause to be deposited on or buried in any public land, park, street, alley, vacant or unoccupied lot or any drainage ditch any garbage, household debris, building materials, rubbish, litter, scrap tires, filth, carrion, weeds, undergrowth, brush, yard trimmings, or any other refuse. No person shall deposit or bury any such materials on or in the property of another without the prior consent of the owner and then not in violation of other sections of this chapter or any other state or federal laws. (2) No materials other than yard trimmings and non-petroleum-based combustible building materials shall be burned in the city and then only after a proper permit has been secured from the fire department. (3) No person, other than the owner, occupant, or agent owning, holding, or occupying said property whereon refuse is generated, city employee, or an approved private hauler shall disturb any refuse container or remove its covers or any of the contents thereof, or cause such refuse container or its contents to be strewn or scattered on the lawns, sidewalks, or streets. (4) No smoldering ashes or other smoldering combustible materials residue, building materials, household debris, yard trimmings, or scrap tires shall be placed inside any refuse container or be mixed with any other refuse. (Ord. No. 792, § 1(12-6), 8-18-1998) Sec. 94-7. - Enforcement. (a) Solid waste management plan. A solid waste management plan must be submitted with every application for a commercial building permit. Approval of the plan must be made by the director of the public works department. (b) Penalty for violation. Any person who violates any of the provisions in this chapter shall, upon notification, have three calendar days to correct the violation unless a specific violation has a different time for correction specified elsewhere in this chapter. Any person who then remains in violation and is convicted therefor shall be liable for up to a fine of $1,000.00 and up to 100 days confinement for each offense. Each violation hereof shall be deemed a separate offense. (Ord. No. 792, § 1(12-7), 8-18-1998) Secs. 94-8—94-35. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - RESIDENTIAL GARBAGE, HOUSEHOLD DEBRIS AND RECYCLABLES
Sec. 94-36. - Precollection. (a) Residential garbage. (1) Customer responsibility. A residential customer has the following responsibilities: a. Containerization of garbage. Residential garbage shall be drained of all excess liquid and be enclosed in plastic bags, and shall then be placed and maintained in containers satisfying the requirements of this article. Containers shall be maintained at all times with tightfitting lids or covers, and secured in such a manner as to prevent the overturning by the elements or by dogs or other animals. Residents/tenants shall ensure that all refuse is maintained in the proper container and that the container area is kept clean and free of litter. b. Weight of containers. No 32-gallon container shall be loaded with a total weight exceeding 50 pounds. No 64-gallon container shall be loaded with a total weight exceeding 100 pounds. No 96-gallon container shall be loaded with a total weight exceeding 150 pounds. c. Cleanliness of containers. All residential garbage containers shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition between scheduled collection days. In the case of a 32-gallon in-ground container, customers shall not allow garbage or water to collect inside the liner or between the liner and the garbage can. Following notice from the public works department, a resident/tenant shall have three calendar days to remove the garbage or water. If the garbage or water has not been removed by that time, the public works department shall remove the water or garbage and bill the resident/tenant a service fee, pursuant to the service scheduled maintained by the city. (2) Container specifications and initial cost. Residential garbage containers shall consist of the following types of containers and, unless expressly determined in this article, the public works department shall have final determination of the type container to be used at each individual property: a. Thirty-two gallon in-ground container. This permanent in-ground container consists of a watertight 55-gallon drum liner affixed with a hinged lid designed to receive a 32-gallon bail handle garbage can. The 32-gallon in-ground container shall be the normal residential garbage container used in neighborhoods or subdivisions established prior to March 1, 2006 and where garbage collection is performed from the street. After January 1, 2008, the cost of the initial installation of the 55-gallon drum liner, including hinged lid assembly, shall be funded as a solid waste general operating expense and shall be installed by the public works department, while the 32-gallon bail handle garbage can shall be paid for by the resident/tenant of the property for a fee pursuant to the service fee schedule maintained by the city. The 55-gallon drum liner, including hinged lid assembly, shall be the property of the City of Moultrie while the 32-gallon bail handle garbage can shall be the property of the resident/tenant of the property. For other than normal wear-and-tear, repair or replacement of the 55-gallon drum liner, including hinged lid assembly, due to damage, abuse, or theft shall be billed to the property owner for a fee pursuant to the service fee schedule maintained by the city. The public works department shall have final determination whether any replacement is due to normal wear-and-tear, damage, abuse, or theft. b. Thirty-two gallon roll-away container. This mobile container consists of a wheeled watertight 32-gallon container. The 32-gallon roll-away container shall be the residential garbage container used where a 32-gallon in-ground container would normally be used as noted above, but in the opinion of the public works department, an in-ground container would be impractical due to high subsurface water levels or a lack of installation space. This type of roll-away container shall be delivered by and be the property of the City of Moultrie. For other than normal wear-and-tear, repair or replacement of the 32-gallon roll-away container, due to damage, abuse, or theft shall be billed to the property owner for a fee pursuant to the service fee schedule maintained by the city. The public works department shall have final determination whether any replacement is due to normal wear-and-tear, damage, abuse, or theft. c. Sixty-four gallon roll-away container. This mobile container consists of a wheeled watertight 64-gallon container. The 64-gallon roll-away container shall be the residential garbage container used in neighborhoods or subdivisions established prior to March 1, 2006 and where garbage collection is performed from an alley. This type of roll-away container shall be delivered by and be the property of the City of Moultrie. For other than normal wear-and-tear, repair or replacement of the 64-gallon roll-away container, due to damage, abuse, or theft shall be billed to the property owner for a fee pursuant to the service fee schedule maintained by the city. The public works department shall have final determination whether any replacement is due to normal wear-and-tear, damage, abuse, or theft. d. Ninety-six gallon roll-away container. This mobile container consists of a wheeled watertight 96-gallon container. The 96-gallon roll-away container shall be the residential garbage container used in neighborhoods or subdivisions established after March 1, 2006. This type of roll-away container shall be delivered by and be the property of the City of Moultrie. For other than normal wear-and-tear, repair or replacement of the 96-gallon roll-away container, due to damage, abuse, or theft shall be billed to the property owner for a fee pursuant to the service fee schedule maintained by the city. The public works department shall have final determination whether any replacement is due to normal wear-and-tear, damage, abuse, or theft. e. Community dumpster. This permanent container consists of either a six- or eight-cubic-yard container. The community dumpster shall be the residential garbage container used where residents live in a complex, and where, in the opinion of the public works department, such a container shall be more practical than individual containers. This type container shall be delivered by and be the property of the City of Moultrie. For other than normal wear-and-tear, repair or replacement of the community dumpster, due to damage, abuse, or theft shall be billed to the property owner for a fee pursuant to the service fee schedule maintained by the city. The public works department shall have final determination whether any replacement is due to normal wear-and-tear, damage, abuse, or theft. f. Special container. A special container must be purchased and used in the following circumstances: 1. If a property owner or resident/tenant does not have a container deemed suitable under this article, and the public works department cannot install or deliver a suitable container within two week's time, the resident/tenant must purchase a 32-gallon or smaller can with tight-fitting lid to use until such time as the public works department can deliver a suitable container. The temporary container purchased shall be from a public retailer, but must be of a type approved by the public works department. 2. If a resident/tenant generates a volume of garbage that exceeds the capacity of their city-approved container(s), and if the excess volume hasn't been deemed chronic by the public works department, the resident/tenant must purchase a 32-gallon or smaller can with tight-fitting lid to contain their excess garbage. The container purchased shall be from a public retailer, but must be of a type approved by the public works department. (b) Residential household debris. (1) Customer responsibility. a. No residential customer shall place for collection any household debris item which has an airtight snap lock or similar device without first removing its door. b. A residential customer shall place household debris for collection no earlier than 6:00 p.m. of the day before collection and no later than 6:00 a.m. of the day of collection. (2) Household debris location. All household debris shall be located for collection adjacent to or on the property upon which the waste contained therein is generated. The public works department shall work with the residential customer to have the household debris placed for collection in a mutually agreeable location, but the final decision upon collection placement shall be the responsibility of the public works department. Household debris may normally be placed for collection as follows: a. On streets with curb and gutter, household debris shall be placed for collection immediately behind the curb on the street right-of-way. b. On streets without curb and gutter, household debris shall be placed for collection between the edge of the pavement and the edge of the ditch insofar as practical from the pavement so as not to impede traffic flow. c. In alleys, household debris shall be placed for collection adjacent to the alley immediately upon the property from which such household debris was generated. d. At no time shall household debris be placed in ditches, gutters, drains, walkways, alleys, or streets, on top of in-ground garbage liners or water meters, or within ten feet of a fire hydrant. (c) Residential recyclables. (1) Customer responsibility. Residential recycling is voluntary and the city strongly encourages all residents to recycle. Any residential customer desiring to recycle must remove all lids, caps, and corks from recyclables. All recyclable bottles and cans must be rinsed and their labels removed. All residential recyclables must be enclosed and maintained in containers satisfying the requirements of this article. (2) Containers. Residential recyclables shall be either enclosed in plastic garbage bags which shall be secured and purchased by the resident/tenant or the recyclables shall be contained in a recycling bin which shall be purchased from and delivered by the city and shall be paid for and be the property of the resident/tenant. The resident/tenant shall determine the number of containers needed and shall place them alongside their normal garbage container no earlier than 6:00 p.m. of the day before the scheduled collection day and no later than 6:00 a.m. of the day of collection. If a recycling bin is being used, it shall be removed no later than 7:00 p.m. of the day of collection. (3) Number of containers. The public works department, using periodic garbage volume surveys, shall determine the number of garbage containers needed per residence, and monthly collection rates shall be adjusted accordingly: a. For those residences utilizing 32-gallon in-ground containers and requesting or requiring additional or a smaller number of containers: 1. Owner-occupied residences shall have additional in-ground containers installed by the public works department as required. 2. Non-owner-occupied residences requiring additional containers shall require the resident/tenant to purchase a 32-gallon or smaller can with tight-fitting lid to use. The container purchased shall be from a public retailer, but must be of a type approved by the public works department. 3. For those residences requiring in-ground containers to be removed by the public works department, and not be replaced with another in-ground container, the property owner shall be billed a fee pursuant to the service fee schedule maintained by the city. b. For those residences utilizing city-owned roll-away containers, and requesting or requiring additional containers, the public works department shall deliver more same-sized roll-away containers. (4) Container location. All containers shall be located for collection adjacent to or on the property upon which the waste contained therein is generated. However, no container shall be placed for collection directly in ditches, gutters, drains, walkways, alleys, or streets or shall be placed within two feet of any shrub, bush, tree, or any permanent structure. No resident shall allow any shrub, bush, tree, or any permanent structure to grow or to be placed within two feet of a permanent garbage container. The public works department shall work with the resident to have the container placed for collection in a mutually agreeable location, but the final decision upon container location shall be the responsibility of the public works department. Roll-away and 32-gallon or smaller cans with tight-fitting lids bought from public retailers shall be placed as follows: a. When not being placed for collection, they shall be stored at the rear or side of a residential building. b. They shall be placed for collection no earlier than 6:00 p.m. of the day before collection and no later than 6:00 a.m. of the day of collection. c. Following collection, they shall be returned to the rear or side of the residential building no later than 7:00 p.m. of the day of collection. d. If the resident/tenant does not remove their container from it's collection location as noted above, the public works department shall place it beside the residence and the resident/tenant shall be billed a fee pursuant to the service fee schedule (5) Container maintenance responsibility and cost. All containers purchased from the city, excluding 32-gallon bail handle cans, shall carry a one-year warranty, excluding damage, abuse, or theft, from date of delivery or installation. The public works department shall perform periodic inspections of all containers. Any containers supplied by the city shall be repaired or replaced as noted above, and any responsible parties billed. Any 32-gallon or smaller cans with tight-fitting lids purchased by the resident/tenant from a public retailer shall be replaced by the resident/tenant upon notice from the public works department that the container is not suitable. (Ord. No. 792, § 1(12-8), 8-18-1998; Ord. No. 996-2006, §§ 1, 2, 9-29-2006; Ord. No. 2007-27, §§ 1—5, 12-18-2007) Sec. 94-37. - Collection. (a) Residential garbage. Residential garbage shall be collected twice per week for those residents using 32-gallon in-ground containers and 32-gallon roll-away containers. Residential garbage shall be collected once per week for those residents using 64-gallon and 96-gallon roll-away containers. Residential garbage shall be collected a minimum of once per week for those residents using a community dumpster. For those residents using special containers, residential garbage shall be collected on their regularly scheduled collection day. Fees for collecting residential garbage shall be included in the monthly residential refuse rate. (b) Residential household debris. Residential household debris items shall be collected once per week. Fees for collecting average volume household debris on the scheduled collection day shall be included in the monthly residential refuse rate. Special collections, when requested other than the normal collection day, shall entail a minimum charge of $20.00. Large volume collections shall entail a collection charge of landfill disposal costs, plus equipment, labor, and overhead costs. (c) Residential recyclables. Residential recyclables shall be collected once per week. Fees for collecting residential recyclables shall be included in the monthly residential refuse rate. (Ord.
