Sec. 94-66. - Precollection. (a) Commercial garbage. (1) Customer responsibility. A commercial customer has the following responsibilities: a. Containerization of garbage. All commercial garbage shall be enclosed and maintained in containers satisfying the requirements of this article. In certain instances, per the judgment of the public works department, commercial customers may be required to bag, bundle, or size their garbage before placing in a suitable container. Containers shall be maintained at all times with tight-fitting lids or covers provided the container was supplied with a lid or cover. Containers shall be secured in such a manner as to prevent the overturning by the elements or by dogs or other animals. Commercial customers shall ensure that all refuse is maintained in the proper container and that the container area is kept clean and free of litter. If the public works department has to remove refuse or litter from around the dumpster, the tenant shall be charged a fee pursuant to the service fee schedule maintained by the city. b. Cleanliness of containers. Commercial garbage roll-away containers shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition between scheduled collection days. (2) Container specifications and initial cost. Commercial garbage containers shall consist of the following types of containers, and unless expressly determined in this article, the public works department shall have final determination of the type container to be used at each individual property: a. Ninety-six gallon roll-away container. This mobile container consists of a wheeled watertight 96-gallon container. The 96-gallon roll-away container shall be the normal commercial garbage container used for smaller volume commercial customers or where a dumpster is not deemed practical. This type of roll-away container shall be delivered by and be the property of the City of Moultrie. For other than normal wear-and-tear, repair or replacement of the 96-gallon roll-away container, due to damage, abuse, or theft shall be billed to the property owner for a fee pursuant to the service fee schedule maintained by the city. The public works department shall have final determination whether any replacement is due to normal wear-and-tear, damage, abuse, or theft. b. Dumpster. This permanent container consists of either a six- or eight-cubic-yard container. The dumpster shall be the normal commercial garbage container used for larger volume commercial customers and where, in the opinion of the public works department, such a container shall be more practical than 96-gallon roll-away containers. Dumpsters shall be delivered by and be the property of the City of Moultrie. For other than normal wear-and-tear, repair or replacement of the dumpster, due to customer request, damage, abuse, or theft shall be billed to the property owner for a fee pursuant to the service fee schedule maintained by the city. The public works department shall have final determination whether any replacement is due to normal wear-and-tear, damage, abuse, or theft. (3) Number of containers. The public works department, using periodic garbage volume surveys, shall determine the number of garbage containers needed per commercial business. A commercial customer may use a maximum of four 96-gallon roll-away containers before being required to use a dumpster unless, in the opinion of the public works department, a customer shall be better served by 96-gallon roll-away containers. (4) Container location. Commercial customers utilizing containers for their exclusive use, as determined by the public works department, shall have their containers located for collection adjacent to or on the property upon which the waste contained therein is generated. Commercial customers utilizing containers being shared by other customers, as determined by the public work department, shall have their containers located for collection in a location predetermined by the public works department. The public works department shall work with each commercial customer to have the container placed for collection in a mutually agreeable location, but the final decision upon container location shall be the responsibility of the public works department. Roll-away containers, when not being placed for collection, shall be stored at the rear or side of a commercial building. Roll-away containers shall be placed for collection no earlier than 6:00 p.m. of the day before collection and no later than 6:00 a.m. of the day of collection. Following collection, roll-away containers shall be returned to the rear or side of the commercial building no later than 7:00 p.m. of the day of collection. (5) Container maintenance responsibility and cost. All containers purchased from the city shall carry a one-year warranty, excluding damage, abuse, or theft, from date of delivery or installation. The public works department shall perform periodic inspections of all containers. Any containers supplied by the city shall be repaired or replaced as noted above, and any responsible parties billed. (b) Commercial recyclables. (1) Customer responsibility. Commercial recycling is voluntary and the city strongly encourages all commercial customers to recycle. Any commercial customer desiring to recycle their cardboard must keep it enclosed and maintained in containers satisfying the requirements of this article. (2) Containers. Commercial cardboard recyclables shall be contained in a recycling bin which shall be installed by the city or its authorized representative and which shall be the property of the city or its authorized representative. (Ord. No. 792, § 1(12-10), 8-18-1998; Ord. No. 2007-27, §§ 7—9, 12-18-2007) Sec. 94-67. - Collection. (a) Commercial garbage. Commercial garbage shall be collected a minimum of once per week to a maximum of twice per week for those customers using 96-gallon roll-away containers. For those customers using dumpsters, commercial garage shall be collected a minimum of once per week to a maximum of six times per week. The public works department shall work with a customer to decide upon a mutually agreeable frequency of dumpster collections; however, the final decision upon frequency of dumpster collections shall be the responsibility of the public works department. Fees for collecting commercial garbage on the scheduled collection day shall be included in the monthly commercial refuse rate. Any commercial customer having their dumpster blocked by an obstruction which prevents collection at their normally scheduled time and which requires another trip to complete the collection or who requests an extra collection beyond their normal collection schedule shall be billed a fee pursuant to the service fee schedule maintained by the city. (b) Commercial special handling. Slaughterhouses, fish houses, veterinarians, or any other commercial establishments which require special handling of garbage for reasons such as daily roll-away collection or collection of dead animals weighing more than 100 pounds shall be billed a collection charge of landfill disposal costs, plus equipment, labor, and overhead costs; however, the collection charge shall not be less than the minimum commercial refuse rate. (c) Commercial recyclables. Commercial recyclables shall be collected once per week. (Ord. No. 792, § 1(12-11), 8-18-1998; Ord. No. 2007-27, § 10, 12-18-2007) Secs. 94-68—94-95. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - RESIDENTIAL AND COMMERCIAL YARD TRIMMINGS[3]
Footnotes: --- (3) --- Cross reference— Businesses, ch. 26.
Sec. 94-96. - Precollection. (a) Customer responsibility. A residential or commercial customer has the following responsibilities: (1) Customers shall separate all yard trimmings, including leaves, straw, prunings, lawn clippings, and limbs, from other solid waste such as garbage, household debris, rubbish, and scrap tires. (2) Customers shall not place yard trimmings in garbage containers. (3) Tree trimmings and shrubbery cuttings shall be cut in lengths of four feet or less and not more than four inches in diameter. When placed in bundles, the bundles shall not exceed 35 pounds and shall be placed in an orderly manner so as to be readily handled and collected. (4) Composting is voluntary and the city strongly encourages all residential and commercial customers to compost where applicable. Residential and commercial customers are encouraged to compost yard trimmings generated on their own property and to utilize that compost in their landscape. (b) Yard trimmings location. All yard trimmings shall be located for collection adjacent to or on the property upon which the waste contained therein is generated. The public works department shall work with the residential or commercial customer to have the yard trimmings placed for collection in a mutually agreeable location, but the final decision upon collection placement shall be the responsibility of the public works department. Yard trimmings may normally be placed for collection at any time as follows: (1) On streets with curb and gutter, yard trimmings shall be placed for collection immediately behind the curb on the street right-of-way. (2) On streets without curb and gutter, yard trimmings shall be placed for collection between the edge of the pavement and the edge of the ditch insofar as practical from the pavement so as not to impede traffic flow. (3) In alleys, yard trimmings shall be placed for collection adjacent to the alley immediately upon the property from which such yard trimmings were generated. (4) At no time shall yard trimmings be placed in ditches, gutters, drains, walkways, alleys, or streets, on top of in-ground garbage liners or water meters, or within ten feet of a fire hydrant. (Ord. No. 792, § 1(12-12), 8-18-1998) Sec. 94-97. - Collection. Residential and commercial yard trimmings shall be collected a maximum of once per week. Fees for collecting average volume residential/commercial yard trimmings on the scheduled collection day shall be included in the monthly residential/commercial refuse rates. Special collections, including requests for collections on other than the normal collection day or collections of mixed piles of yard trimmings and other debris, shall entail a fee pursuant to the service fee schedule maintained by the city. Large volume collections shall entail a collection charge of landfill disposal costs, plus equipment, labor, and overhead costs. (Ord. No. 792, § 1(12-13), 8-18-1998; Ord. No. 2007-27, § 11, 12-18-2007) Secs. 94-98—94-125. - Reserved. ARTICLE V. - RESIDENTIAL AND COMMERCIAL RATES[4]
Footnotes: --- (4) --- Cross reference— Businesses, ch. 26.
Sec. 94-126. - Collection rates. There is hereby established a rate for the collection of refuse by the city from residences, businesses, and other property within the city. The collection rate shall be as follows: (1) Residential rates. a. Residential in-ground and roll-away refuse. For each single-family residential unit in the city utilizing in-ground and roll-away containers, a monthly charge shall be made for the collection of refuse as follows: 1. One container or equivalent volume ..... $28.00 2. Two containers or equivalent volume ..... 39.40 3. Three containers or equivalent volume ..... 50.80 4. Four containers or equivalent volume ..... 62.20 5. Five containers or equivalent volume ..... 68.60 6. Six containers or equivalent volume ..... 85.00 b. Residential community dumpster refuse. For each single-family residential unit in the city living in a complex and utilizing a community dumpster container, the two following rate options shall apply: 1. Where complex management has elected to pay for refuse collection, the complex shall pay current commercial rates, and the single-family residential unit shall not be billed. 2. Where complex management has elected not to pay for refuse collection, each single-family residential unit shall pay a monthly charge of $17.50 for refuse collection. (2) Commercial rates. a. Commercial roll-away refuse. For each commercial unit in the city utilizing 96-gallon roll-away carts where it is the exclusive user of said carts, a monthly charge shall be made for the collection of refuse as follows: 1. One cart or equivalent volume ..... $34.40 2. Two carts or equivalent volume ..... 54.10 3. Three carts or equivalent volume ..... 73.80 4. Four carts or equivalent volume ..... 93.50 5. Five carts or equivalent volume ..... 113.20 6. Six carts or equivalent volume ..... 132.90 b. Commercial dumpster refuse. For each commercial unit in the city utilizing a dumpster container where it is the exclusive user of said dumpster, a monthly charge shall be made for the collection of refuse as follows:
c. Commercial shared container refuse. When more than one commercial establishment uses the same container, each such establishment shall pay a minimum monthly charge of $35.75. Should the volume generated exceed the container volume maximum or the maximum number of dumps, the rate shall go to the next higher fee level for that type container with the excess prorated across the customers using the container. (Ord. No. 792, § 1(12-14), 8-18-1998; Ord. No. 853, § 1, 10-3-2000; Ord. No. 868, § 1, 9-18-2001; Ord. No. 954, § 1, 9-22-2005; Ord. No. 996-2006, § 3, 9-29-2006; Ord. No. 2007-27, § 12, 12-18-2007; Ord. No. 2009-53, § 1, 2-17-2009) Sec. 94-127. - Billing. (a) Method of billing. Rates chargeable to persons, firms or corporations under this article shall be billed to such persons, firms or corporations on their utility bill, and shall be paid as a part thereof. If the person, firm or corporation is not a utility customer of the city, such person, firm or corporation shall be billed directly by the city. (b) Delinquent bills. If any rate payable under this article is not paid on or before the due date as shown on the customer's bill, a penalty of ten percent of the amount due shall be added and collected. If any amount payable under this article shall remain unpaid ten days after the due date, all services covered by the utility bill of the customer shall be suspended until payment is made. (Ord. No. 792, § 1(12-15), 8-18-1998; Ord. No. 954, § 2, 9-22-2005) Sec. 94-128. - Rate study. For the purpose of determining the amounts to be paid under this article, the public works department shall conduct an annual rate study to determine the cost of refuse collection, transportation and disposal. The city manager will annually present proposed refuse collection rates to city council at the first city council meeting in October of each year, and unless city council votes to implement other refuse collection rates, the city manager's proposed collection rates shall be adopted and implemented as of November 1 of that same year. (Ord. No. 792, § 1(12-16), 8-18-1998; Ord. No. 954, § 3, 9-22-2005)

div.head: Chapter 98 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Aviation, ch. 18; buildings and building regulations, ch. 22; cemeteries, ch. 30; environment, ch. 46; flood damage prevention, ch. 54; historic preservation, ch. 62; libraries, ch. 70; parks and recreation, ch. 78; peddlers and solicitors, ch. 82; planning, ch. 86; traffic and vehicles, ch. 106; utilities, ch. 110; vegetation, ch. 114; vehicles for hire, ch. 118; zoning, ch. 122.
Sec. 98-1. - Authority to close streets to traffic; notice. The city manager is hereby empowered to close any street or part thereof from traffic from vehicles or pedestrians, either one or both, when in the opinion of said department it is deemed necessary or advisable while street construction, improvements or repairs are being made or when traffic thereon would subject persons or property to extra hazard or danger from any cause or to effect quarantine regulations or to prevent noises in case of sickness. Such closed streets or portions of streets shall be designated by suitable signs or barriers to show that they are closed. And it shall be unlawful for any person to enter upon any street or portion of street so closed. (Code 1935, § 137; Code 1967, § 23-1) Sec. 98-2. - Permit required for embankment. No person shall, by himself, agent, servant or employee, make an embankment in any street or alley or any sidewalk in this city, without the permission, first obtained, of the city manager. (Code 1935, § 206; Code 1967, § 23-2) Sec. 98-3. - Injury to, interference with grade, embankment, markers, etc. It shall be unlawful to injure or change any street grade or embankment or any part of any street, avenue, or right-of-way or to interfere with, injure or remove any stake, post or other erected or established sign or signal device in the city, whether done by person or machine of any kind. (Code 1935, § 199; Code 1967, § 23-3) Sec. 98-4. - Damage to pavement, sanitary sewer. It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit or cause to be deposited or to burn or cause to be burned, on any street, avenue, sidewalk, ditch or gutter, in said city any rubbish or any material that might cause deterioration in the street paving or might be washed in the storm sewer system. (Ord. of 11-17-1936, § 1; Code 1967, § 23-4) Sec. 98-5. - Use by utilities. (a) Control of installations. All poles, posts, crossarms, wires, pipe, conduit and other fixtures now or hereafter placed, erected, owned or used under proper franchise or permission of the city in, on, or under any street, alley, or other public property in the city by any utility company or by any other person, firm or corporation shall be under the control, direction, and supervision of the city manager subject to the provisions of this section. (b) Permission to make installations. Before exercising any rights or privileges under any franchise heretofore granted or that may be hereafter granted, or under any rights or privileges granted by the general laws of this state relative to the use of any street, alley or other property of the city, the person, firm or corporation so desiring shall first obtain written permission from the city manager, which said written permission shall specify exactly what is to be done and such installation shall be made in strict accordance therewith. (c) Agreement to locate installation not to be interference. As a part of the consideration for the use of the street, alley or other property of the city, such user shall agree in the application for written permission to so locate or relocate its property in, on or under any street, alley or other property in the city so as not to interfere with the use thereof by the public and the city. (Code 1967, § 23-5; Ord. No. 12-1973, §§ 1—3, 4-17-1973) Cross reference— Utilities, ch. 110. Sec. 98-6. - Policy regarding payment of street improvement assessments. The policy of the city with regard to paving and other improvement of streets, assessing and collecting from adjoining property owners the cost or a portion thereof is as follows: (1) Adjoining property owners may pay one-fourth of the cost of any project assessed to such owner at the time of assessment and pay the balance in equal annual installments over a period of three years. (2) Interest shall be charged at seven percent per annum on delinquent payments only. (3) Adjoining property owners shall be afforded an opportunity to pay paving costs by the month if they so desire. (4) Any interest that has been paid by adjoining property owners under contract #1 and #2 on deferred installments which are not delinquent shall be refunded. (Code 1967, § 23-8; Ord. No. 206, § 1, 10-21-1975)

div.head: Chapter 102 - TAXATION[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Administration, ch. 2; alcoholic beverage taxes, § 6-246 et seq.; businesses, ch. 26; business licensing generally, § 26-36 et seq. State Constitution reference— Taxation power of county and municipal governments, Ga. Const. art. IX, § IV.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 102-1. - Due date for taxes. (a) All taxes shall be due on October 1 in each year and shall be paid on or before December 20 in each year. (b) The city tax collector shall give notice in the official newspaper the last week in September, when taxes will be due, and the last day for paying same before execution will issue. (Code 1935, §§ 45, 46; Ord. of 6-19-1951, § 1; Code 1967, § 25-1) Sec. 102-2. - False or incomplete returns. It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly make any false, incomplete or fraudulent returns under this article. (Code 1935, § 44; Code 1967, § 25-2) Sec. 102-3. - Penalty for failure to file return on property. All persons owning property taxable by this city, who shall fail to return the same within the time prescribed, shall be taxed an additional ten percent, and the clerk shall enter their names upon the digest, ascertaining the value of their taxable property from the best sources at his command, and submit the same to the tax assessors, who shall endeavor to arrive at a reasonable valuation of the same, on which valuation the additional taxes shall be collected. If the tax assessors shall have reason to suspect that all the property subject to tax by such defaulter is not on the digest, it shall be their duty to inquire into the matter, and for that purpose they may summon such defaulter to appear before them and examine him under oath as to the property, real and personal, of every description, owned by him in this city and the amount and kind of personal property owned by him which is not in this city. (Code 1935, § 42; Code 1967, § 25-3) Charter reference— Authority to double tax, § 81. Sec. 102-4. - Collection of taxes by execution. The collection of taxes within the city may be enforced by execution, signed by the clerk and attested by the mayor, and may be levied by the marshal to the city, who shall advertise and sell the property under the same rules that govern constable's sales, and, if real estate, under the same rules that now govern sheriff's sales. (Code 1935, § 47; Code 1967, § 25-4) Sec. 102-5. - Issuance of execution for unpaid taxes. It shall be the duty of the clerk, on December 20 of each year, to issue executions for the tax unpaid and still due the city for the current year. Such executions shall be issued against each and every person who has failed to pay his respective taxes, if such person be known, and if not known, then the execution shall be issued against the property. Such executions shall be directed to the marshal, shall bear teste in the name of the mayor and shall be returnable at the first regular meeting in January following. (Code 1935, § 48; Ord. of 6-19-1951, § 2; Code 1967, § 25-5) Sec. 102-6. - Procedure for issuance of execution for unpaid taxes. (a) Issuance. Should any person fail or refuse to pay this city tax or license, or tax and license imposed by the city authorities, within the time allowed or prescribed by this Code or the ordinances of said city, the clerk shall issue an execution against such delinquent taxpayer for the amount due by him to the city, which shall be signed by the clerk of said city in his official capacity and bear teste in the name of the mayor and city council. Said execution shall bind all property that the said defaulting taxpayer may have or own in said city on March 1 in the year for which such taxes are due. (b) Levy; advertisement for sale. Said execution shall be directed to and enforced by the marshal of said city, who, after levying the same upon the property of said defaulting taxpayer, shall, if the property be personal property upon which such execution be levied, advertise the same, by posting a notice thereof in three of the most public places within said city for ten days, giving a description of such property so levied upon and to be sold, before the sale; and, if the property be real estate, he shall advertise the sale of the same once a week for four weeks in the public gazette wherein the sheriff's sales are advertised in the county, before selling the same. (c) Conduct of sales. All such sales under such executions shall be made by the city marshal at the usual place of holding sheriff's sales, or at such places as the mayor may direct, notice of which place and the time of sale shall be contained in the notice and advertisement. The property levied upon shall be sold at public outcry, and within the legal hours of sale by law for sheriff's sales, to the highest and best bidder, for cash. Where personal property is sold, the marshal shall deliver possession thereof on the spot to the purchaser. Where real estate is sold, the marshal shall make to the purchaser a deed, which shall be as effectual in passing the title as the deed of the person against whom the execution is issued; and it shall be the duty of the marshal, upon application of the purchaser, or his agent, to put said purchaser, or his agent, in possession of the real estate sold. Provided, said marshal shall not be authorized to turn over any other person's property than such delinquent taxpayer's, his heirs, tenants, or assigns, since the lien of the city for taxes attached. (Code 1935, § 47; Code 1967, § 25-6) Sec. 102-7. - Affidavit of illegality. To any execution issued under the provisions of this Code, the defendant shall have the right to file an affidavit of illegality, denying that the whole or any part of the amount for which such execution is issued is due, the reasons why same is not due, and any amount thereof admitted to be due shall be paid before said affidavit is received, and the affidavit shall be received insofar as the balance of the execution is disputed. Said affidavit, when so received, shall be returned to the superior court of the county and there tried and the issue determined as in cases of illegalities under state laws, subject to all the penalties provided for in case of illegalities filed for delay only. (Code 1935, § 72; Code 1967, § 25-7) Sec. 102-8. - Tax on personal property; acceleration where property about to be removed from city; enforcement. When any person becomes liable for payment to the city of a tax on a personal property for any year, and such person is moving or about to move the personal property subject to such tax without the limits of the city, the tax for said year on said property shall immediately become due and execution may be issued by city clerk and levied by the marshal instanter, and said property shall be advertised and sold pursuant to provisions regarding said taxes due city. In the event the city shall not have levied a tax for the current year, the city clerk shall use the tax levied for the preceding year in issuing a fi. fa. (Code 1967, § 25-8; Ord. No. 1-1969, § 8, 1-7-1969) State Law reference— Exemption of personalty from ad valorem tax, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-42. Secs. 102-9—102-35. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - HOTEL/MOTEL EXCISE TAX
Sec. 102-36. - Levy of excise tax on charges to public for rooms, lodging and accommodations. Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-13-50 et seq. there is hereby levied an excise tax of seven percent of the charge to the public upon the furnishing for value to the public of any room, lodging or accommodations furnished by any person or legal entity licensed by or required to pay business or occupation taxes to the city for operating a hotel, motel, inn, lodge, tourist camp, tourist cabin or any other place in which rooms, lodgings, or accommodations are regularly furnished for value; provided that no such tax shall be levied upon the fees or charges for any rooms, lodgings or accommodations furnished for a period of more than ten days or for use as meeting rooms; provided further that no such tax shall be levied upon the fees or charges for any rooms, lodgings or accommodations furnished for a period of one or more days for use by state or local government officials or employees when traveling on official business; or as otherwise provided by law. This section shall become effective on July 1, 2012. (Code 1967, § 16-130; Ord. No. 537, § 1, 12-15-1987; Ord. No. 630, § 1, 9-1-1992; Ord. No. 993-2006, § 1, 9-5-2006; Ord. No. 2012-115, § 1, 5-15-2012) Sec. 102-37. - Expenditure of taxes collected. Taxes collected under section 102-36 shall be expended in conformity with the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 48-13-51(b), as the same shall now or hereafter exist. (Code 1967, § 16-131; Ord. No. 537, § 1, 12-15-1987; Ord. No. 630, § 2, 9-1-1992; Ord. No. 2012-115, § 2, 5-15-2012) Sec. 102-38. - Collection. The operator of every business subject to the tax provided for herein shall collect the tax provided in section 102-36. (Code 1967, § 16-132; Ord. No. 537, § 1, 12-15-1987) Sec. 102-39. - Due date, filing of returns and payment of taxes. (a) All taxes provided hereunder shall be due and payable to the city and shall be remitted to the city clerk on or before the 20th day of the month next following the month in which the tax became due. (b) On or before the 20th day of the month next following the month in which tax became due hereunder, the operator of the business required to pay the tax provided for hereunder shall file with the city clerk under oath a return on a form provided by the clerk showing all fees or charges made for rooms, lodgings or accommodations for said month, the portion of such fees or charges which are exempt hereunder, and the amount of tax due and collected for the period. (c) As used in this subsection, the term "estimated tax liability" means an innkeeper's tax liability under this article, adjusted to account for any subsequent change in the rate of tax imposed under this article or any substantial change in circumstances due to damage to the premises, based on his or her average monthly payments for the last fiscal year. If the estimated tax liability of an innkeeper for any taxable period exceeds $2,500.00, the innkeeper shall file a return and remit to the governing authority imposing the tax not less than 50 percent of the estimated tax liability for the taxable period on or before the twentieth day of the period. The amount of the payment of the estimated tax liability shall be credited against the amount to be due on the return required under subsection (a) of this Code section. This subsection shall not apply to any innkeeper unless during the previous fiscal year the innkeeper's monthly payments exceeded $2,500.00 per month for three consecutive months or more. (d) Operators collecting the tax due hereunder shall be allowed a percentage of the tax due and accounted for and shall be reimbursed in the form of a deduction in submitting, reporting, and paying the amount due if the amount due is not delinquent at the time of payment. The rate of deduction shall be same rate authorized for deduction from state sales and use taxes under O.C.G.A. § 48-13-52. (Code 1967, § 16-133; Ord. No. 537, § 1, 12-15-1987; Ord. No. 993-2006, § 2, 9-5-2006) Sec. 102-40. - Persons liable for tax. (a) The taxes herein are imposed on the operator of every business subject to the tax herein provided and shall be added to the room rental charge and shall be a debt due to the operator until paid, recoverable at law as other debts. Any operator who shall neglect, fail or refuse to collect the tax herein provided shall be liable for and pay the tax. (b) An operator shall not advertise or hold out to the public, in any manner, directly or indirectly, that he will absorb all or any part of the tax, or that he will relieve his customer of the payment of the tax. (c) If any operator liable for any tax, interest, or penalty imposed by this article sells his or her business or quits the business, he or she shall make a final return and payment within 15 days after the date of selling or quitting the business. The innkeeper's successor or assigns, if any, shall withhold a sufficient amount of the purchase money to cover the amount of the taxes, interest, and penalties due under this article and unpaid until the former owner produces either a receipt from the governing authority imposing the tax showing that the taxes, interest, and penalties due under this article have been paid or a certificate from the governing authority imposing the tax stating that no tax, interest, or penalty is due under this article. If the purchaser of a business fails to withhold the purchase money as required by this Code section, he or she shall be personally liable for the payment of any taxes, interest, and penalties accruing under this article and unpaid by any former owner or assignor. The personal liability of the purchaser in such a case shall not exceed the amount of the total purchase money, but the property being transferred shall in all cases be subject to the full amount of the tax lien arising from the delinquencies of the former owner. Paid executions may be transferred and enforced as otherwise provided by law. (Code 1967, § 16-134; Ord. No. 537, § 1, 12-15-1987; Ord. No. 993-2006, § 3, 9-5-2006) Sec. 102-41. - Failure to pay tax. (a) The tax imposed hereunder shall for each month become delinquent on the 20th day of each succeeding month. The city clerk is empowered and it shall be his duty when any tax becomes delinquent under this article to pursue any remedy or right allowed by law for the enforcement of the collection and payment of taxes lawfully due the city as may be provided by the laws of the state or ordinances of the city. (b) When any operator fails to make any return or to pay the full amount of the tax required by this article, there shall be imposed, in addition to other penalties provided by law, a penalty to be added to the tax in the amount of five percent or $5.00, whichever is greater, if the failure is for not more than 30 days and an additional five percent or $5.00, whichever is greater, for each additional 30 days or fraction of 30 days during which the failure continues. The penalty for any single violation shall not exceed 25 percent or $ 25.00 in the aggregate, whichever is greater. If the failure is due to providential cause shown to the satisfaction of the governing authority imposing a tax under this article in affidavit form attached to the return and remittance is made within ten days of due date, the return may be accepted exclusive of penalties and interest. In the case of a false or fraudulent return or of a failure to file a return where willful intent exists to defraud the governing authority of any tax due under this article, a penalty of 50 percent of the tax due shall be assessed. (Code 1967, § 16-135; Ord. No. 537, § 1, 12-15-1987; Ord. No. 993-2006, § 4, 9-5-2006) Sec. 102-42. - Records. It shall be the duty of each and every operator of a business subject to the tax provided hereunder to keep and preserve for a period of at least three years sufficient records of transactions covered by the tax to correctly disclose the amount of tax due hereunder, and all such records shall be open to inspection by the city clerk or his duly authorized agents at all reasonable hours. (Code 1967, § 16-136; Ord. No. 537, § 1, 12-15-1987) Secs. 102-43—102-70. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - FINANCIAL INSTITUTIONS
Sec. 102-71. - Business license tax levied. Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93, there is hereby levied for the year 1984, and for each year thereafter, an annual business license tax upon state and national banking associations, federal savings and loan associations and state building and loan associations a business license tax at the rate of one-fourth of one percent of the gross receipts of said institutions. Gross receipts shall mean gross receipts as defined in O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93. Notwithstanding any other provisions of this article, the minimum amount of business license tax due from any depository financial institution pursuant to this article shall be $1,000.00 per year. (Code 1967, § 16-126; Ord. No. 412, § 1, 11-1-1983) Sec. 102-72. - Due date; filing of return. (a) Each depository financial institution within the city shall file a return of its gross receipts with the city on March 1 of the year following the year in which such gross receipts were measured. Said returns shall be in the manner and in the form prescribed by the commissioner of the department of banking and shall be based upon the allocation method set forth in O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93(d). The tax levied pursuant to this article shall be assessed and collected based upon the information provided in said return. (b) The due date of taxes levied by this article shall be April 1, 1984, and April 1 of each subsequent year. (Code 1967, § 16-127; Ord. No. 412, § 2, 11-1-1983) Secs. 102-73—102-100. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - SECONDARY ELECTRIC SUPPLIERS
Sec. 102-101. - Gross receipts business tax established; verified statement of revenues to be filed. Each secondary electric supplier, including specifically electric membership corporations whether or not operated for profit, within the meaning of O.C.G.A. § 46-3-1 et seq., distributing and selling electric power within the city which is not otherwise paying a franchise fee pursuant to a franchise agreement, and whether or not said secondary electric supplier has, operates and maintains offices within the city shall pay a gross receipts tax at the rate of four percent on any and all gross revenue derived from distribution and sale of electric power to their customers, members, or purchasers within the city, according to the verified statement of said gross revenues which shall be submitted by said secondary electric supplier at the time said taxes are paid. This gross receipts tax is levied pursuant to authority granted the city in 1983 Ga. Laws, page 4710, at page 4729, § 5-103. (Code 1967, § 16-140; Ord. No. 684, § 1, 1-3-1995) Sec. 102-102. - Taxes payable monthly; taxes to be in lieu of certain other taxes. The taxes hereinbefore set out in this article shall be due and payable to the city on the 20th day of each month, calculated on gross revenues billed for the immediately preceding month; also, the percentage of said gross revenues hereinbefore prescribed to be collected shall be in lieu of all other license and business or occupation taxes, but shall not at any time be considered to interfere with or in any way prevent the collection of ad valorem taxes upon the property of said secondary electric supplier in the same manner as all other property, real and personal, in the city is taxed. (Code 1967, § 16-141; Ord. No. 684, § 1, 1-3-1995) Sec. 102-103. - Electric service within city. Secondary electric suppliers distributing and selling electric power within the city, and which do not have a franchise agreement with the city, do not acquire any additional rights by the payment of the tax herein levied under this article other than those rights granted under the Georgia Territorial Electric Service Act (O.C.G.A. § 46-3-1 et seq.). (Code 1967, § 16-142; Ord. No. 684, § 1, 1-3-1995) Sec. 102-104. - Enforcement and administration. (a) The city clerk shall be responsible for the administration and enforcement of this article and shall have the power to prepare and provide the necessary forms and for the collection of the tax herein levied. (b) The city clerk shall issue executions for the collection of all outstanding and unpaid taxes imposed and assessed by this article. The unpaid taxes and executions shall be collected in the manner provided by law for the collection of other taxes due the city. (Code 1967, § 16-143; Ord. No. 684, § 1, 1-3-1995) Secs. 102-105—102-200. - Reserved. ARTICLE V. - ENERGY EXCISE TAX ORDINANCE
Sec. 102-201. - Short title. This article shall be known as the "City of Moultrie Energy Excise Tax Ordinance." (Ord. No. 2012-121, § 2, 11-20-2012) Sec. 102-202. - Findings and intent. This article is adopted to address the interest of public finance. Georgia law authorizes counties and municipalities to impose an excise tax on the sale or use of energy but the imposition of said excise tax on the sale or use of energy is contingent upon the enactment of an ordinance by the city in question. In order for the city to properly impose said excise tax the city must follow all of the provisions of O.C.G.A. tit. 48, ch. 13, art. 6, one provision of which is the enactment of this article. (Ord. No. 2012-121, § 3, 11-20-2012) Sec. 102-203. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Dealer shall have the same meaning as provided for in the O.C.G.A. § 48-13-110. Energy shall have the same meaning as provided for in the O.C.G.A. § 48-13-110. Local sales and use tax shall have the same meaning as provided for in the O.C.G.A. § 48-13-110. Purchaser shall have the same meaning as provided for in the O.C.G.A. § 48-13-110. (Ord. No. 2012-121, § 4, 11-20-2012) Sec. 102-204. - Energy excise tax imposed. (a) In accordance with the provisions of O.C.G.A. tit. 48, ch. 13, art. 6, there is imposed within the territorial limits of the city, an excise tax on the sale or use of energy when such sale or use would have constituted a taxable event for purposes of sales and use tax under O.C.G.A. tit. 48, ch. 8, art. 1 but for the exemption found in the O.C.G.A. § 48-8-3.2. (b) The sale or use of energy when such sale or use would have constituted a taxable event for purposes of sales and use tax under O.C.G.A. tit. 48, ch. 8, art. 1 but for the exemption found in the O.C.G.A. § 48-8-3.2 includes, but is not limited to, the sales and use of energy that is necessary and integral to the manufacture of tangible personal property such as: (1) Machinery or equipment used to convey or transport industrial materials, work in process, consumable supplies, or packaging materials at or among manufacturing plants or to convey and transport finished goods to a distribution or storage point at the manufacturing plant. Specific examples may include, but are not limited to, forklifts, conveyors, cranes, hoists, and pallet jacks; (2) Machinery or equipment used to gather, arrange, sort, mix, measure, blend, heat, cool, clean, or otherwise treat, prepare, or store industrial materials for further manufacturing; (3) Machinery or equipment used to control, regulate, heat, cool, or produce energy for other machinery or equipment that is necessary and integral to the manufacture of tangible personal property. Specific examples may include, but are not limited to, boilers, chillers, condensers, water towers, dehumidifiers, humidifiers, heat exchangers, generators, transformers, motor control centers, solar panels, air dryers, and air compressors; (4) Testing and quality control machinery or equipment located at a manufacturing plant used to test the quality of industrial materials, work in process, or finished goods; (5) Starters, switches, circuit breakers, transformers, wiring, piping, and other electrical components, including associated cable trays, conduit, and insulation, located between a motor control center and exempt machinery or equipment or between separate units of exempt machinery or equipment; (6) Machinery or equipment used to maintain, clean, or repair exempt machinery or equipment; (7) Machinery or equipment used to provide safety for the employees working at a manufacturing plant, including, but not limited to, safety machinery and equipment required by federal or state law, gloves, ear plugs, face masks, protective eyewear, hard hats or helmets, or breathing apparatuses, regardless of whether the items would otherwise be considered consumable supplies; (8) Machinery or equipment used to condition air or water to produce conditions necessary for the manufacture of tangible personal property, including pollution control machinery or equipment and water treatment systems; (9) Pollution control, sanitizing, sterilizing, or recycling machinery or equipment; (10) Industrial materials bought for further processing in the manufacture of tangible personal property for sale or further processing or any part of the industrial material or by-product thereof which becomes a wasteful product contributing to pollution problems and which is used up in a recycling or burning process; (11) Machinery or equipment used in quarrying and mining activities, including blasting, extraction, and crushing; and (12) Energy used at a manufacturing plant. (Ord. No. 2012-121, § 5, 11-20-2012) Sec. 102-205. - Energy excise tax rate and phase-in. (a) The rate of the excise tax levied and collected pursuant to this article shall be phased in over a four-year period as directed by the O.C.G.A. §§ 48-13-112(a)(3) and 48-13-112(b) and as set forth below: (1) For the period commencing January 1, 2013, and concluding at the last moment of December 31, 2013, such excise tax shall be at a rate equivalent to 25 percent of the total amount of local sales and use tax in effect in such special district that would be collected on the sale, use, storage, or consumption of energy but for the exemption in the O.C.G.A. § 48-8-3.2; (2) For the period commencing January 1, 2014, and concluding at the last moment of December 31, 2014, such excise tax shall be at a rate equivalent to 50 percent of the total amount of local sales and use tax in effect in such special district that would be collected on the sale, use, storage, or consumption of energy but for the exemption in the O.C.G.A. § 48-8-3.2; (3) For the period commencing January 1, 2015, and concluding at the last moment of December 31, 2015, such excise tax shall be at a rate equivalent to 75 percent of the total amount of local sales and use tax in effect in such special district that would be collected on the sale, use, storage, or consumption of energy but for the exemption in the O.C.G.A. § 48-8-3.2; and (4) On or after January 1, 2016, such excise tax shall be at a rate equivalent to 100 percent of the total amount of local sales and use tax in effect in such special district that would be collected on the sale, use, storage, or consumption of energy but for the exemption in the O.C.G.A. § 48-8-3.2. (b) In accordance with O.C.G.A. § 48-8-3.2 (c)(4), if a project of regional significance under O.C.G.A. § 48-8-3(92) is started in the special district, it shall not be subject to the phase-in period contained in paragraphs (a), (b), and (c) of subsection (1) of this section, and the sale, use, storage, or consumption of energy in connection therewith shall be subject to the rate specified in paragraph (d) of subsection (1) of this section notwithstanding the January 1, 2016 limitation in that paragraph (d). (c) Following such initial imposition during the phase-in time period, on or after January 1, 2016, the rate of the excise tax levied and collected by the governing authority of the city shall be directed by the O.C.G.A. § 48-13-112(d). Such rate shall be controlled by the maximum amount of local sales and use tax in effect in the special district, but in no event more than two percent. (d) In the event the total rate of local sales and use taxes in effect in the special district decreases from two percent to one percent, the rate of the excise tax under this article shall likewise be reduced at the same time such local sales and use tax rate reduction becomes effective. (e) In the event the total rate of local sales and use taxes in effect in the special district increases from one percent to two percent, the rate of the excise tax under this article shall likewise be increased at the same time such local sales and use tax rate increase becomes effective. (Ord. No. 2012-121, § 6, 11-20-2012) Sec. 102-206. - Energy excise tax imposition, remittance and recovery. (a) The excise tax levied and collected pursuant to this article shall be imposed at the time and be recoverable as governed by the O.C.G.A. § 48-13-112(c). (b) The excise tax shall be a debt of the purchaser of energy until it is paid and shall be recoverable at law in the same manner as authorized for the recovery of other debts as governed by the O.C.G.A. § 48-13-112(c). (c) The dealer collecting the excise tax shall remit the excise tax to the city if the city is the governing authority imposing the excise tax as governed by the O.C.G.A. § 48-13-112(c). (d) Every dealer subject to an excise tax under this article shall be liable for the excise tax at an applicable rate on the charges actually collected or the amount of the excise taxes collected from the purchasers, whichever is greater as governed by the O.C.G.A. § 48-13-112(c). (Ord. No. 2012-121, § 7, 11-20-2012) Sec. 102-207. - Exemption certificates. (a) The governing authority of the city, or the collecting officer appointed under this article, shall make diligent efforts to identify all energy providers and purchasers in the city and to ascertain whether such purchasers have completed a uniform exemption certificate provided by the Georgia Department of Revenue seeking to qualify such purchaser under the exemption found in the O.C.G.A. § 48-8-32.2. Such certificate shall be utilized by such governing authority or collecting officer for the purpose of determining the applicability of the excise tax under this article. (b) An energy provider shall be authorized to rely upon such uniform exemption certificates provided by the Georgia Department of Revenue. The energy provider shall not be liable for failing to collect and remit the excise tax imposed under this article if a purchaser has failed to submit the uniform exemption certificate provided by the Georgia Department of Revenue to such energy provider. (Ord. No. 2012-121, § 8, 11-20-2012) Sec. 102-208. - Commencement of collections and due date. (a) The excise tax imposed pursuant to this article shall become effective on January 1, 2013. (b) The excise tax levied pursuant to this article shall be imposed only at the time that sales and use tax on the sale and use of such energy would have been due and payable under the O.C.G.A. § 48-8-30 but for the exemption in O.C.G.A. § 48-8-3.2. (c) The excise tax shall be due and payable in the same manner as would otherwise be required under O.C.G.A. tit. 48, ch. 8, art. 1. (d) All sales and purchases taxable under this article during the preceding calendar month shall be due and payable to the City of Moultrie monthly on or before the 20th day of every month and each respective month in which such taxes are collected, and payment shall be accompanied by a return for the preceding monthly period showing the gross sales and purchases arising from all sales and purchases taxable under this article during the preceding calendar month. (Ord. No. 2012-121, § 9, 11-20-2012) Sec. 102-209. - Expenditure of proceeds. The proceeds of the excise tax levied and collected pursuant to this article shall not be subject to any use or expenditure requirements provided for under any of the local sales and use taxes but shall be authorized to be expended in the same manner as otherwise would have been required under such local sales and use taxes or may be expended for any lawful purpose as governed by the O.C.G.A. § 48-13-112(c). Any proceeds received by the city pursuant to this article shall be deposited in the general fund of the city. (Ord. No. 2012-121, § 10, 11-20-2012) Sec. 102-210. - Termination of municipal excise tax. (a) If the city has levied and collected an excise tax within the corporate limits of city under this article because the county in which the city is located has refused or failed to enter into an intergovernmental agreement with each city wishing to participate in such excise tax as allowed by the O.C.G.A. § 48-13-115(a)(1) and then the county determines to commence proceedings for the imposition of the excise tax as allowed by the O.C.G.A. § 48-13-115(b)(2), then the excise tax levied and collected by the city shall cease to the extent as provided for by the O.C.G.A. § 48-13-115(b)(2). (b) If the county has commenced proceedings for the imposition of the excise tax as allowed by the O.C.G.A. § 48-13-115(b)(2) and the excise tax levied and collected by the city has terminated and the city has chosen to participate in the county excise tax, then this article shall remain effective for the purposes of O.C.G.A. tit. 48, ch. 13, art. 6 and particularly for the rates required by the O.C.G.A. § 48-13-112. (Ord. No. 2012-121, § 11, 11-20-2012) Sec. 102-211. - Administrative provisions and audit. (a) The city governing authority shall be authorized to designate a collecting officer for collection and administration of the excise tax under this article. (b) The collecting officer shall be authorized to provide for procedures necessary to the proper implementation of this article, including, but not limited to, periodic auditing of dealers collecting and remitting the excise tax. (c) The collecting officer, or designee, may examine the books, papers, records, financial reports, equipment and other facilities of and locations within the city of any purchaser which is required to remit the excise tax to the energy dealer under this article. (d) As part by the audit report required by the O.C.G.A. § 36-81-7 the auditor shall include, in a separate schedule, a report of the revenues pertaining to the excise tax under this article. (Ord. No. 2012-121, § 12, 11-20-2012)

div.head: Chapter 106 - TRAFFIC AND VEHICLES[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Charter reference— Authority to pass ordinances relative to vehicles and conveyances of all kinds, § 7. Cross reference— Courts, ch. 34; driving over fire hose, § 50-3; following fire truck or parking near fire, § 50-4; law enforcement, ch. 66; offenses and miscellaneous provisions, ch. 74; parades, § 74-19; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 98; vehicles for hire, ch. 118. State Law reference— Powers of city as to its municipal street system, O.C.G.A. § 32-4-92; uniform rules of the road, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-1 et seq.; equipment and inspection of motor vehicles, O.C.G.A. § 40-8-1 et seq.; jurisdiction of municipal court, O.C.G.A. § 40-13-21.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 106-1. - Uniform rules of the road. (a) Adoption by reference. Pursuant to O.C.G.A. §§ 40-6-372—40-6-376, O.C.G.A. §§ 40-6-1—40-6-395 of that chapter known as the Uniform Rules of the Road and the definitions contained in O.C.G.A. § 40-1-1 are hereby adopted as and for traffic regulations of this city with like effect as if recited herein. (b) Penalties. Unless another penalty is provided by law, every person convicted of a violation of any provision of this section shall be punished by a fine of not more than $300.00 or by imprisonment for not more than 100 days or by both such fine and imprisonment. (Code 1967, § 26-1; Ord. No. 588, §§ 1, 2, 2-20-1990) Sec. 106-2. - Obstruction of streets by railroad cars. The several companies whose railroads are in the city shall not allow any street to be obstructed by any cars or other things left on any of the crossings, and if it shall become necessary, for any reason, to stop on a crossing for a period longer than eight minutes, the conductor of such train or other person in charge of such obstruction shall open said crossing at the expiration of said time and allow all vehicles and pedestrians to cross. Any person failing to do so shall be guilty of disorderly conduct. (Code 1935, § 183; Code 1967, § 26-8) State Law reference— Occupying or blocking street grade crossing, O.C.G.A. § 46-8-197. Sec. 106-3. - Traffic plan and traffic operations program adopted. The traffic plan recommended by Traffic Planning Associates, Inc., dated February 1975 and the Traffic Operations Program recommended by Traffic Planning Associates, Inc., dated December 1975 be and the same are hereby adopted. (Code 1967, § 26-10; Ord. No. 215, § 1, 4-20-1976) Sec. 106-4. - Stop signs and yield signs. All stop and yield signs presently in place within the city and all future such signs placed under direction of the city manager shall be obeyed as provided in O.C.G.A. § 40-6-72. (Code 1967, § 26-13; Ord. No. 635, § 1, 2-2-1993) Secs. 106-5—106-30. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - EQUIPMENT ON VEHICLES
Sec. 106-31. - Mufflers; cutouts prohibited. It shall be unlawful to operate any vehicle using an explosive mixture as a motive power without a muffler to deaden the sound, which muffler shall not be disconnected or cut out. (Ord. of 5-20-1952, § 34; Code 1967, § 26-21) Sec. 106-32. - Brakes. It shall be unlawful to operate a motor vehicle unless the same shall be equipped with brakes in good working order. (Ord. of 5-20-1952, § 32; Code 1967, § 26-22) Sec. 106-33. - Warning devices; use. (a) It shall be unlawful to operate a motor vehicle unless the same is equipped with a horn or bell in good working order. (b) The use of horns, whistles or other devices operated by the engine exhaust of motor vehicles is prohibited. (c) It shall be unlawful for drivers or passengers of vehicles to blow horns, ring bells or sound whistles, unless the same shall be done as a warning to other persons. (Ord. of 5-20-1952, §§ 33, 35, 36; Code 1967, § 26-23) Sec. 106-34. - Lights required. It shall be unlawful for any person to operate any vehicle on any street at night, that is from sunset to sunrise, unless there shall be attached and displayed on said vehicles: (1) On any automobile, showing white lights and capable of revealing a person, vehicle or object at least 500 feet ahead in the darkness, and one light on the left rear end of such vehicle showing red to the rear and visible for at least 500 feet in the darkness, and a white light shining upon the license plate attached to the rear of the vehicle. (2) On a motorcycle or motorized bicycle or motor scooter, a headlight visible at least 200 feet in the direction in which it is proceeding, and one light on the left rear end of said vehicle, showing red to the rear, and a white light shining upon the license plate attached to the rear of the vehicle. (3) On a wagon, dray, or similar nonmotorized vehicle, lights from all directions, said lights to be attached underneath, on top or on the sides thereof. (4) All trucks or trailers of more than 1½ ton capacity shall have clearance lights at each extremity in the front and in the rear. If the body is the widest portion of the vehicle said clearance lights must be placed at the widest extremity of the body so as to clearly indicate the width of the vehicle to approaching traffic from either direction. Said lights not to be of any glaring or blinding nature. (5) When a vehicle is parked or ranked on a street at night, a light on the left rear end need not be burning, but in such case there must be affixed at such place an attachment which reflects red to the rear, visible for a distance of 200 feet, when such an attachment has light cast upon it from headlights of an approaching vehicle. (Ord. of 5-20-1952, § 30; Code 1967, § 26-24) Secs. 106-35—106-60. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - OPERATION OF VEHICLES
Sec. 106-61. - Driving through processions. It shall be unlawful for the operator of any vehicle, except fire, police, or ambulance vehicles, to drive between the vehicles comprising a funeral or other authorized procession while they are in motion, except by the permission of a police officer present, provided that said vehicles are conspicuously so designated. (Code 1935, § 148; Code 1967, § 26-36) Sec. 106-62. - Driving on city property. It shall be unlawful for the operator of any vehicle to drive upon the property of the city, other than streets or highways and such properties as are regularly provided for by the city for such purposes. (Ord. of 5-20-1952, § 51; Code 1967, § 26-38) Sec. 106-63. - Driving on sidewalk or side or center parks. It shall be unlawful for the operator of any motor vehicle to drive any vehicle upon any of the side parks, center parks or sidewalks within the city. Invalid chairs and/or three-wheeled electric carts may be operated on said sidewalks at speeds of five miles per hour and less, and roller skates may be used in the daytime on any sidewalk outside of the fire limits. (Ord. of 5-20-1952, § 51; Code 1967, § 26-39; Ord. No. 296, § 1, 6-5-1979) Sec. 106-64. - Riding skateboards on sidewalks, streets or other city property. It shall be unlawful for a person to ride a skateboard on the sidewalks, in the streets or on any other property of the city not specifically designated and provided for such use. (Code 1967, § 26-39.1; Ord. No. 546, § 1, 3-1-1988) Sec. 106-65. - Operation of bicycles or motorcycles. It shall be unlawful for any person to ride a bicycle or motorcycle on any sidewalk within the city. It shall be unlawful for any person, riding a bicycle or motorcycle in the city, not to use a bell or gong to give warning of the approach thereof, or to ride in a reckless, boisterous or disorderly manner. (Code 1967, § 26-109) Sec. 106-66. - Vehicles prohibited on railroad right-of-way. It shall be unlawful for the operator of any motorized vehicle to drive a motorized vehicle upon any part of the former CSX railroad right-of-way acquired by and presently owned by the city except upon public streets crossing same and upon easements specifically provided for the purpose by the city. This prohibition shall not apply to city maintenance vehicles on such right-of-way for maintenance purposes. (Code 1967, § 26-39.2; Ord. No. 662, § 1, 1-18-1994) Sec. 106-67. - Off-road vehicles. (a) It shall be unlawful to operate any off-road vehicle as defined in O.C.G.A. § 40-7-3 on the streets, sidewalks, roadways, bike trail on former CSX right-of-way and public parking lots within the city. (b) It shall also be unlawful for the parent or guardian of any minor to allow such minor to violate the provisions of subsection (a) of this section. (c) It shall be unlawful to operate any off-road vehicle, excluding aircraft and city maintenance equipment, within Spence Field, except within the confines of private property or in connection with an approved event or in connection with a business. (Ord. No. 800, §§ 1, 2, 2-16-1999; Ord. No. 878, § 1, 3-5-2002) Sec. 106-68. - Operation by minor. Only those persons above the age of 15 years shall operate any motor vehicle. Provided, however, that such person shall have in his possession a valid operator's or public chauffeur's license or learner's license; provided further that the holder of a learner's license shall be accompanied by a licensed driver as required by state law. (Ord. of 5-20-1952, § 6; Code 1967, § 26-41) State Law reference— Instruction permits, O.C.G.A. § 40-5-24. Sec. 106-69. - Dimming lights. Whenever headlights are in use, the lower or passing beam shall be used at all times when approaching within 500 feet of an oncoming vehicle. (Code 1967, § 26-46) State Law reference— Use of multiple-beam road lighting equipment, O.C.G.A. § 40-8-31. Sec. 106-70. - One-way streets designated. The following streets are designated one-way traffic streets in the direction indicated, and traffic thereon shall after such designation move only in the direction herein provided:
Between the hours of 2:45 p.m. and 3:45 p.m. from August 1 through May 31 of each year the following streets shall be one-way as indicated:
(Ord. of 7-7-1964, § 1; Code 1967, § 26-53; Ord. No. 215, § 2, 4-20-1976; Ord. No. 573, § 1, 6-20-1989; Ord. No. 849, § 2, 9-5-2000; Ord. No. 885, § 1, 9-3-2002; Ord. No. 2013-125, § 1, 3-19-2013) Sec. 106-71. - Speed limits; speed zones. (a) It shall be unlawful to operate a motor vehicle upon the streets at a speed greater than is reasonable and safe, which speed shall not exceed 35 miles per hour on all streets except as herein set out. (b) Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 40-6-183 concerning local authorities' power to alter lawful speed limits, the following speed limits are established within the city: (1) On-system. Signs shall be erected by the state department of transportation on the following streets:
Signs are to be installed by the Georgia DOT. (2) Off-system. Signs shall be erected by the city on the following streets:
School Zones:
Signs are to be installed by the City of Moultrie. (c) Any person convicted of a violation of this section shall be punished as provided by law. (Code 1967, § 26-56; Ord. No. 121, § 2, 11-6-1973; Ord. No. 203, § 1, 10-7-1975; Ord. No. 371, § 1, 5-18-1982; Ord. No. 383, § 1, 10-26-1982; Ord. No. 444, § 1, 10-2-1984; Ord. No. 467, § 1, 9-3-1985; Ord. No. 476, § 1, 11-5-1985; Ord. No. 617, § 1, 8-20-1991; Ord. No. 649, § 1, 8-17-1993; Ord. No. 694, § 1, 4-4-1995; Ord. No. 698, § 1, 5-2-1995; Ord. No. 722, § 2, 8-20-1996; Ord. No. 785, 5-5-1998; Ord. No. 786, § 1, 6-16-1998; Ord. No. 883, § 1—3, 7-16-2002; Ord. No. 888, § 1, 9-3-2002; Ord. No. 819, § 1, 11-16-1999; Ord. No. 900, §§ 1, 2, 7-1-2003; Ord. No. 2010-80, §§ 1, 2, 3-16-2010) Sec. 106-72. - Vehicles with cleats. No vehicle with the wheels so constructed as will likely cause damage or imprints upon surface of paved streets shall be allowed on any paved streets. (Code 1935, § 146(e); Code 1967, § 26-57) Sec. 106-73. - Load limits. No vehicle with a gross weight in excess of 14,000 pounds shall be operated on the following streets: First Avenue Northwest between Martin Luther King, Jr. Drive and First Street Northwest. Second Street Southeast between Mimosa Avenue and Second Avenue Southeast. Fifth Avenue Southeast between the East Bypass and the Moultrie-Quitman Highway. Tenth Street Southeast between Fifth Avenue Southeast and the south city limits. Thirteenth Avenue between South Main Street and Second Street Southeast. Seventeenth Avenue, S.E., from South Main Street to Tallokas Road. Carolyn Street between the Moultrie-Quitman Highway and 23rd Street Northeast. Doug Turner Drive between Industrial Boulevard and the end of the pavement. Hutchinson Drive between Clay Street and Rowland Drive. Hutchinson Drive between Rowland Drive and the east bypass. Mimosa Avenue between South Main Street and Second Street Southeast. Norman Street between the Moultrie-Quitman Highway and 23rd Street Northeast. WMTM Road between Doug Turner Drive and the south drive of radio station WMTM. (Code 1967, § 26-60; Ord. No. 116, § 1, 8-21-1973; Ord. No. 121, § 1, 10-16-1973; Ord. No. 195, § 1, 6-3-1975; Ord. No. 205, § 1, 10-21-1975; Ord. No. 572, § 1, 6-6-1989; Ord. No. 576, § 1, 8-1-1989; Ord. No. 678, § 1, 12-6-1994; Ord. No. 745, § 1, 4-1-1997; Ord. No. 2007-9, § 1, 7-10-2007) Sec. 106-74. - No thoroughfare streets. The following streets are hereby declared to be no thoroughfares between the hours of 8:30 a.m. and 3:30 p.m., local time, and through traffic is prohibited from using said streets between said hours: (1) Fifth Street Southwest between Seventh Avenue Southwest and Eleventh Avenue Southwest. (2) Ninth Avenue Southwest between Fourth Street Southwest and Fifth Street Southwest. (Code 1967, § 26-61; Ord. No. 192, § 1, 4-1-1975) Secs. 106-75—106-100. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING[2] Footnotes: --- (2) --- State Law reference— Authority to regulate parking, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-371(a)(1).
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 106-101. - Repair work in streets. No repair work on vehicles shall be done in the streets, except for emergency repairs. (Ord. of 5-20-1952, § 2; Code 1967, § 26-73) Sec. 106-102. - Obstructing space between curb and sidewalk or on center parks or sidewalks. It shall be unlawful to park, rank or stop any motor vehicle between the curb and the sidewalk or upon the center parks on streets or upon the sidewalks within the corporate limits of the city. (Ord. of 5-20-1952, § 51; Code 1967, § 26-75) Sec. 106-103. - Lights on parked vehicles. When a vehicle is parked or stopped on a street during the time between one-half hour after sunset and one-half hour before sunrise or at any other time when there is not sufficient light to render clearly discernible any vehicle or the street from a distance of 500 feet, there shall be displayed upon such vehicle one or more lights, projecting a light visible under normal atmospheric conditions from a distance of 500 feet to the front of such vehicle and projecting a red light visible under like conditions from a distance of 500 feet to the rear, except that such parking light need not be displayed upon any vehicle stopped or parked in accordance with other provisions of this chapter upon any brightly lighted street designated by proper authority.
